155 old {@a-kisara-lābhin@}¦, <lex>adj.</lex>, and {@°bhi-tā@}, <ab>abstr.</ab>; also in <lang>Skt.</lang> form as {@a-kṛcchra°@}, {%(state of) obtaining without difficulty%}: akṛcchra-lābhī (<ab>n. sg.</ab>) <ls>Mvy</ls> 〔2432〕 = <tib>dkaḥ pa med par thob pa</tib>, and akisara-l° 〔2433〕 = <tib>tshegs med par°</tib>, or, <tib>ṅan ṅon ma yin par°</tib>; akṛcchrākisaralābhi-tā <ls>Bbh</ls> 〔388.13〕 = (<ab>acc.</ab> to note) <lang>Tib.</lang> <tib>ṅan ṅon ma yin par thob pa daṅ tshegs med par thob pa</tib>. in the sequel, favorable sounds show the performer that, adhiṣṭhitaṃ me buddhair … tat paṭasūtraṃ (17); he reflects, buddhānāṃ … adhiṣṭhānam etat (24), {%this is the controlling power of the <ab>B.</ab>%}; {%the control that gives attainment of samādhis%} (<ab>cf.</ab> 12 samādhiṃ samāpadyante; to this verb {@samāpatti@}, <ab>q.v.</ab>, is merely a noun of action; wrongly <ls>Suzuki</ls>), and sarvakāyamukhapāṇyabhiṣekādhiṣṭhāna, {%the control that comes from sprinkling by%} (the Buddhaʼs) {%hands of the whole body and face%} (<ab>cf.</ab> 〔101.10—11〕); persons are said to be adhiṣṭhita, {%supernaturally controlled%} by Buddhas (may often be rendered {%inspired%}) <ls>SP</ls> 〔231.1〕; 〔238.2〕; 〔420.4〕; <ls>LV</ls> 〔275.2〕; <ls>Laṅk</ls> 〔4.13〕; <ab>cf.</ab> {@adhiṣṭhāna@}; this {%control%} often involves ({@3@}) {%magic transformation%}, and even the {%creation of magic appearances%}; not easily separated from the preceding; transitional is sarvabuddhādhiṣṭhito 'yaṃ … dharmaparyāyaḥ <ls>SP</ls> 〔288.13〕, {%it is under the supernatural control of all the Buddhas%} (hence marvelous effects for one who preaches it, as related above), with this <ab>cf.</ab> tasmāt tarhi … adhitiṣṭhāmīmaṃ dharmaparyāyaṃ asmiñ jambudvīpe <ls>SP</ls> 〔421.2〕, {%therefore I%} (<ab>lit.</ab> {%exercize supernatural power over this <ab n="Dharmaparyāya">Dh.</ab>%}, which however here seems to mean) {%make this <ab n="Dharmaparyāya">Dh.</ab> appear in this <ab n="Jambudvīpa">J.</ab>%} (with magical effects, some mentioned above, some in the next sentence); from such passages as this and <ls>SP</ls> 〔384.3〕, below, <ls>LaVallée Poussin, AbhidhK.</ls>, 〔Index〕, and <ab>esp.</ab> 〔vii.119, note 2〕, derives the supposed meaning {%<fr>faire durer</fr>%}, but in 〔iii.31〕, note 2, quoting the vyākhyā, he translates adhitiṣṭhati {%<fr>bénit</fr>%}, whereas it means {%takes under control, assumes control of%}; the meaning {%bless%}, assumed by <ls>Burnouf</ls> and many others, rests on <lang>Tib.</lang> <tib>byin kyi rlabs</tib>, which to be sure often means {%bless%}, but <ab>acc.</ab> to <ls>Jäschke</ls> also {%create, change into%}; this kind of change by magical mastery or control need not be a {%blessing%}, <ab>cf.</ab> (tā jarājarjarā) adhyatiṣṭhat <ls>LV</ls> 〔378.17〕, {%he changed them%} (the daughters of Māra, by magic control) {%so as to be decrepit with age%}, and later, buddhasya yo hy adhiṣṭhānaṃ śaknuyāt kartum anyathā 〔379.3〕, (I see no one) {%who could alter a magic transformation of the Buddha%}; similar passages are taken by <ls>LaVallée Poussin</ls> <ab>l. c.</ab> to mean {%faire durer%}); (Bhagavān …) jīvitasaṃskārān adhiṣṭhāya āyuḥsaṃskārān utsraṣṭum ārabdhaḥ. samanantarādhiṣṭhiteṣu jīvitasaṃskāreṣu (omens occurred) <ls>Divy</ls> 〔203.7—8〕 (in this phrase <ls>LaV-P, AbhidhK.</ls> 〔ii.122〕. renders {%<fr>stabilisé</fr>%}; with <ls>SP</ls> 〔384.3〕 <ab>cf.</ab> <ls>Dbh</ls> 〔91.28〕 sarvasattvāṃś ca ākāṅkṣan yathābhiprāyaṃ rūpāśrayālaṃkṛtān adhitiṣṭhati; in this section adhitiṣṭhati occurs many times, beginning with 〔90.21—22〕 saṃkṣiptāyā lokadhātor vistīrṇatām adhitiṣṭhati, and means always (a Bodhisattva in the tenth stage) {%makes appear magically%}, either by transformation or creation; catvāri pātrāṇi pratigṛhyaikaṃ pātram adhitiṣṭheyam <ls>LV</ls> 〔384.4—5〕, {%accepting the four bowls I will change them magically into a single bowl%}, which he does; pratigṛhya caikaṃ pātram adhitiṣṭhati sma, adhimuktibalena 〔385.4〕 (see {@adhimukti@} 2 which in such passages = adhiṣṭhāna).

1687 new {@adhitiṣṭhati@}¦, also {@adhiṣṭhahati, °ṣṭhihati@} (and noun {@adhiṣṭhāna@}, <ab>q.v.</ab>; <lang>Pali</lang> adhitiṭṭhati, adhiṭṭhāna, in general in same meanings; previous translations of <lang>BHS</lang> vary widely and are hardly worth systematic quotation; very common is {%bless%}, which I think should be deleted, see below): ({@1@}) {%masters, controls%}, in normal <lang>Skt.</lang> (<ls>BR</ls> sthā with adhi 3, 4) and also <lang>BHS</lang> (<ab>exx.</ab> <ls>LaVallée Poussin, AbhidhK.</ls> 〔vii.119 note 2, b〕); in <lang>BHS</lang> particularly {%takes possession%} or {%control of%}, <ls>MSV</ls> 〔i.248.20〕 (sāptāhikaṃ), and <ab>ff.</ab>; <ls>Bhīk</ls> 〔15a.1〕 (the newly initiated nun says to her instructress) samanvāhara upādhyāyike, aham … idaṃ cīvaraṃ saṃghāṭīm adhitiṣṭhāmi, {%I take%} (formal) {%possession of my nunʼs garments%} (similarly with other implements, below: <ls>Ridding</ls> 〔p. 124〕 calls this rite {%benediction%} of the garments, <ab>etc.</ab>; but the nun is the only speaker; she would not ‘bless’ her own belongings!); in <lang>BHS</lang> ({@2@}) the power or control is usually {%supernatural%} or {%magical%}: adhitiṣṭhantu buddhā bhagavanto idaṃ paṭasūtram <ls>Mmk</ls> 〔56.12〕, {%let the Lord Buddhas exercize their supernatural power over%} (assume control of) {%this thread%} (<ls>Lalou, Iconographie</ls> 〔p. 20〕, {%occupent%}); in the sequel, favorable sounds show the performer that, adhiṣṭhitaṃ me buddhair … tat paṭasūtraṃ (17); he reflects, buddhānāṃ … adhiṣṭhānam etat (24), {%this is the controlling power of the <ab>B.</ab>%}; <ls>Laṅk</ls> 〔100.6 ff.〕 [Page013-a], Bodhisattvas may be adhiṣṭhānadvayādhiṣṭhitāḥ, {%controlled by two supernatural powers%} (of Buddhas, <ab>cf.</ab> 11 buddhādhiṣṭhānādhiṣṭhitāḥ); these are (9) samādhisamāpattyadhiṣṭhāna; {%the control that gives attainment of samādhis%} (<ab>cf.</ab> 12 samādhiṃ samāpadyante; to this verb {@samāpatti@}, <ab>q.v.</ab>, is merely a noun of action; wrongly <ls>Suzuki</ls>), and sarvakāyamukhapāṇyabhiṣekādhiṣṭhāna, {%the control that comes from sprinkling by%} (the Buddhaʼs) {%hands of the whole body and face%} (<ab>cf.</ab> 〔101.10—11〕); persons are said to be adhiṣṭhita, {%supernaturally controlled%} by Buddhas (may often be rendered {%inspired%}) <ls>SP</ls> 〔231.1〕; 〔238.2〕; 〔420.4〕; <ls>LV</ls> 〔275.2〕; <ls>Laṅk</ls> 〔4.13〕; <ab>cf.</ab> {@adhiṣṭhāna@}; this {%control%} often involves ({@3@}) {%magic transformation%}, and even the {%creation of magic appearances%}; not easily separated from the preceding; transitional is sarvabuddhādhiṣṭhito 'yaṃ … dharmaparyāyaḥ <ls>SP</ls> 〔288.13〕, {%it is under the supernatural control of all the Buddhas%} (hence marvelous effects for one who preaches it, as related above), with this <ab>cf.</ab> tasmāt tarhi … adhitiṣṭhāmīmaṃ dharmaparyāyaṃ asmiñ jambudvīpe <ls>SP</ls> 〔421.2〕, {%therefore I%} (<ab>lit.</ab> {%exercize supernatural power over this <ab n="Dharmaparyāya">Dh.</ab>%}, which however here seems to mean) {%make this <ab n="Dharmaparyāya">Dh.</ab> appear in this <ab n="Jambudvīpa">J.</ab>%} (with magical effects, some mentioned above, some in the next sentence); from such passages as this and <ls>SP</ls> 〔384.3〕, below, <ls>LaVallée Poussin, AbhidhK.</ls>, 〔Index〕, and <ab>esp.</ab> 〔vii.119, note 2〕, derives the supposed meaning {%<fr>faire durer</fr>%}, but in 〔iii.31〕, note 2, quoting the vyākhyā, he translates adhitiṣṭhati {%<fr>bénit</fr>%}, whereas it means {%takes under control, assumes control of%}; the meaning {%bless%}, assumed by <ls>Burnouf</ls> and many others, rests on <lang>Tib.</lang> <tib>byin kyi rlabs</tib>, which to be sure often means {%bless%}, but <ab>acc.</ab> to <ls>Jäschke</ls> also {%create, change into%}; 1743 old {@adhimukti@}¦, <lex>f.</lex> (= <lang>Pali</lang> adhimutti; to {@adhimucyate@}), ({@1@}) {%strong inclination, attachment; earnest, zealous application%}; <lang>Tib.</lang> <tib>mos pa</tib> (<ls>Jäschke</ls>, {%to be pleased%}, <tib>la</tib> {%with; to wish, to have a mind; to take pleasure in, to rejoice at%}; as substantive {%pleasure, satisfaction, esteem%}; also {%to respect, to esteem, to respect with devotion, to revere, to adore%}); <ls>LaV-P. AbhidhK. Index</ls> = ruci; <ab>cf.</ab> <ls>Bbh</ls> 〔95.12—13〕 kathaṃ ca bodhisattvo 'dhimuktibahulo bhavati? iha bodhisattvo 'ṣṭavidhe 'dhimuktyadhiṣṭhāne śraddhāprasādapūrvakeṇa niścayena {%rucyā%} samanvāgato bhavati. (Other alleged meanings, as {%croyance%} <ls>Lévi Sūtrāl.</ls> 〔i.13 note 1〕; {%confiance%}, <ls>Burnouf</ls>; {%good will%}, <ls>Kern</ls>, in translation of <ls>SP</ls>; <ab>etc.</ab>, are not supported by <lang>BHS</lang> usage, except as under 2, below.) It may be (but rarely is) applied to (a) non-religious objects: sa ca puruṣas (the father) teṣāṃ kumārakāṇām (his ignorant sons) āśayajño bhaved, adhimuktiṃ ca vijānīyāt, <ls>SP</ls> 〔73.14—15〕, {%… and he understands their inclinations, what they are interested in%}. But usually the object is related to (b) a religious aim. It may be specified, syntactically (in the <lex>loc.</lex>), as in yaṃ … sugataḥ prabhāṣate, adhimuktisaṃpanna bhavāhi tatra <ls>SP</ls> 〔32.15〕, {%what the Buddha says, be perfect in zealous application to that%}. Usually it is not so specifically stated, <acr>tho</acr> the context is apt to suggest that it is {%zealous cultivation%} (study or propagation) of sacred texts or religious instruction that is meant (note-that the object of the verb {@adhimucyate@} is commonly something of this sort); <ab>cf.</ab> <ab>e.g.</ab> -lokaṃ yathādhimuktyā ({%according to their%} [varying types or degrees of] {%zeal or application%}) subhāṣitena saṃtoṣayantam <ls>LV</ls> 〔160.17〕; adhimuktisāro yo syād … saḥ, puṇyaṃ labheta yo etaṃ (most <ab>mss.</ab>) sūtraṃ vācel likheta vā <ls>SP</ls> 〔342.3—4〕. And this is probably meant as a rule when the context gives no special clue, as in many of the following: <ls>SP</ls> 〔6.13〕; 〔31.6〕; 〔93.9〕; 〔125.8〕; 〔235.10〕; 〔274.10〕; <ls>LV</ls> 〔10.11〕; 〔182.20〕; 〔432.8〕; <ls>Mvy</ls> 〔856〕; <ls>Samādh</ls> 〔22.43〕; <ls>RP</ls> 〔20.5〕; <ls>Bhad</ls> 〔7, 48〕; <ls>Bbh</ls> 〔195.12〕; anadhimukti, {%lack of%} (religious) {%zeal%} <ls>RP</ls> 〔19.18〕; 〔35.4〕; various gods in <ls>Mv</ls> 〔ii.309.14 ff.〕 see the bodhi-tree svakāye adhmuktīye, {%according to their tastes, inclinations, interests%} (<ls>Senart</ls> {%<fr>suivant ľinclination de chacun</fr>%}) as made of various [Page014-b] precious materials; one of the ten bala of a tathāgata is nānādhimuktijñānabala <ls>Mvy</ls> 〔122〕 (and <ab>cf.</ab> <ls>Mv</ls> 〔i.159.15〕 adhimuktinānātvaṃ vetti, as one of the ten bala); adhimuktivaśitā <ls>Mvy</ls> 〔776〕, one of the 10 vaśitā of a Bodhisattva; yathādhimuktyā, <lex>adv.</lex>, <ls>LV</ls> 〔160.17〕 (above) and 〔179.17〕; hīnādhimukti, {%attachment to low ends%}, <ls>SP</ls> 〔115.12〕 (<ab>cf.</ab> hīnādhimukta, °tika, <ab>s.vv.</ab> {@adhimukta, °tika@}); (in <ls>LV</ls> 〔294.4〕 for vidyādhimuktiprabhaḥ read probably vidyāvimukti°, {%having the splendor of%} (true) {%knowledge and emancipation%}, so <lang>Tib.</lang>, <tib>rnam par grol ba</tib> = vimukti); ({@2@}) {%magic transformation%}, in adhimukti-balena <ls>LV</ls> 〔385.5〕, see <ab>s.v.</ab> {@adhimucyate@} (2), and {@adhitiṣṭhati@}, end.

1855 old {@adhiṣṭhāna@}¦, (regularly) <lex>nt.</lex> (= <lang>Pali</lang> adhiṭṭhāna; see 6 below for forms of other genders; from {@adhitiṣṭhati@}, <ab>q.v.</ab>), ({@1@}) {%basis%}, as in <lang>Skt.</lang> (<ls>BR</ls> <ab>s.v.</ab> 1); having purified, adorned, and scented his body) svakam adhiṣṭhānam akarot <ls>SP</ls> 〔407.6〕, {%he made his resolution, firm mental determination%}; followed by svakam adhiṣṭhānaṃ kṛtvā svaṃ kāyaṃ prajvālayām āsa; buddhān bhagavataḥ sākṣiṇaḥ kṛtvā teṣāṃ purataḥ satyādhiṣṭhānaṃ (<ab>q.v.</ab>) karomi: yena satyena <ab>etc.</ab>, <ls>SP</ls> 〔413.7—8〕, {%… I make a truthful resolve …%} and he proceeds with an ‘act of truth’, see {@satyavacana@}; (?) <ls>LV</ls> 〔423.5—6〕 akṣaṇasattvavinayādhiṣṭhānāpratyudāvartyacakraṃ (said of the dharmacakra; text °dhiṣṭhānapraty°, but see <ab>s.v.</ab> {@apratyudāvartya@}), {%wheel that cannot be turned back because of%} (the Buddhaʼs) {%fixed determination to discipline creatures that are subject to bad births%} (? or possibly {%because of the Buddhaʼs supernatural power to discipline%} <ab>etc.</ab>; otherwise, implausibly, <ls>Foucaux</ls>); here perhaps also the ‘four adhisthāna’ ({%firm resolves?%}) of <ls>Mvy</ls> 〔1580—84〕 (satya-, tyāga-, upasama-, prajñā-) = <lang>Pali</lang> four [Page016-a] adhiṭṭhāna, <ls>DN</ls> 〔iii.229.18〕 (paññā-, sacca-, cāga-, upasama-); ({@3@}) in <lang>Skt.</lang> (<ls>BR</ls> <ab>s.v.</ab> 2) {%mastery, power%}; in <lang>BHS</lang> {%control%}, <ab>e.g.</ab> of a monkʼs own robes (<ab>cf.</ab> {@adhitiṣṭhati@} 1), <ls>MSV</ls> 〔ii.91.12〕 tricīvarādhiṣṭhānena; oftener {%supernatural, magic power%}: puṇyavipākādhiṣṭhānādhiṣṭhitās <ls>LV</ls> 〔48.21〕 (Apsarases) {%empowered%} (controlled) {%by the power of the ripening of merit%} (which enables them to disappear from their heavenly home and appear in Kapilavastu); -devatādhiṣṭhānāt <ls>LV</ls> 〔381.12〕, {%by the magic power of the … deity%} (the merchantsʼ wagons were stopped and could not be moved); usually a Buddhaʼs or Bodhisattvaʼs; it may be his {%supernatural control%} over his own destiny, <ls>SP</ls> 〔64.13〕, where bodhisattvādhiṣṭhānena goes closely with tat paurvakaṃ caryāpraṇidhānam, see <ab>s.v.</ab> {@saṃmantrita@}; but it is usually {%control%} over another person, a Bodhisattva or disciple: Maitreyasya bodhisattvasyādhiṣṭhānabalena sarveṣu teṣu kūṭāgāreṣv abhyantarapraviṣṭam ātmānaṃ saṃjānīte sma, <ls>Gv</ls> 〔512.13—14〕, {%by the force of the supernatural power of Maitreya%} (Sudhana) {%fancied that he had entered into each one of those palaces%}; buddhānāṃ … adhiṣṭhānena <ls>LV</ls> 〔163.9—10〕 (text adhisthān°; when the women were making music for the Bodhisattva) {%by the supernatural power of the Buddhas%} verses of exhortation to him came forth (in 〔163.14〕 {@āveśa@}, <ab>q.v.</ab>, or <ab>v.l.</ab> ādeśa, replaces adhi°); similarly 〔182.3〕; adhiṣṭhānena buddhānām anubhāvād (another near-synonym) vikurvitaiḥ <ls>Samādh</ls> 〔22.19〕 (the body of the Buddha can be seen); other like cases <ls>Laṅk</ls> 〔2.10〕; <ls>LV</ls> 〔31.3, 6〕; 〔237.18〕; 〔368.12〕; in 〔415.16〕, the dharmacakra is sarvabuddhādhiṣṭhānāvilopitam, {%unbroken <acr>thru</acr> the supernatural power%} (influence) {%of all the Buddhas%}; for <ls>Laṅk</ls> 〔100.6〕 and <ls>Mmk</ls> 〔56.24〕 see <ab>s.v.</ab> {@adhitiṣṭhati@} (2); etaṃ … samādhiṃ samāpannasyādhiṣṭhānam: lokadhātuvijñaptiṣu adhiṣṭhānam, <ab>etc.</ab>, long series of <lex>locs.</lex> each with adhi° repeated, stating the spheres of the {%mastery%} obtained, <ls>Gv</ls> 〔98.15 ff.〕; mamādhiṣṭhānabalādhānam <ls>SP</ls> 〔316.1〕, {%my assumption of the force of supernatural%} (magic) {%power%} (here causes people to believe that the earthly life of Śākyamuni, which was unreal, is real); but the corresponding verse, 〔323.13〕, has adhiṣṭhahāmi in the sense of {%I make appear by magic%} (see {@adhitiṣṭhati@} 3), and possibly adhiṣṭhāna may be concrete here (and in sadādhiṣṭhānaṃ mama etad īdṛśaṃ <ls>SP</ls> 〔324.11〕, resuming the same subject), {%exhibition of supernatural%} (magic) {%power = magical appearance%} or {%transformation%}; this latter is certainly the meaning in <ls>LV</ls> 〔379.3〕, see {@adhitiṣṭhati@} (3), and perhaps in Prabhūtaratnasya tathāgatasya … etad adhiṣṭhānam abhūt <ls>SP</ls> 〔241.8〕, {%this was the adhiṣṭhāna of the Tathāgata <ab n="Prabhūtaratna">P.</ab>%} (there follows a quotation of his words: {%Let this stūpa of my remains appear whenever the <ls>SP</ls> is preached%}). Does {%this adhiṣṭhāna%} mean {%this exhibition of supernatural power%}, viz, the making of the stūpa to appear? Or is it {%this fixed determination, resolution%} (2, above)? Near synonyms are {@āveśa@}, (<lang>Skt.</lang>) anubhāva, {@adhimukti@}; <ab>cf.</ab> also <ls>Laṅk</ls> 〔292.13〕 and 15, where one of the sources of abhijñā is ‘from adhiṣṭhāna’ (adhiṣṭhānān, so read in 13 for text °nāṃ, <lex>abl.</lex>, before n-), which means {%from the controlling power of the Buddhas%} and is paraphrased in 15 by buddhaprasādataḥ, {%from the grace of the Buddhas%}. <ls>Suzuki, Transl. of Laṅk</ls> passim, renders {%sustaining power%}; I think rather {%controlling power%}. Even Bodhisattvas are at times dependent on Buddhas and need their control; ({@4@}) in architecture, <lang>Skt.</lang> (see <ls>Acharya, Dict. Hindu Arch.</ls> <ab>s.v.</ab>), {%basement, foundation%} of building or {%base%} of a pillar. Here in <ls>Mvy</ls> 〔5591〕 = <lang>Tib.</lang> <tib>lan kan gyi rten ma</tib>, {%prop%} (<ab>i.e.</ab> base) {%of a railing%}; so <lang>Chin.</lang> Whatever it means here is certainly meant also in <ls>Divy</ls> 〔221.9, 10〕 adhiṣṭhānam, and <ls>Mv</ls> 〔i.195.1 ff.〕; 〔iii.227.8 ff.〕, adhiṣṭhānakam, where the context is the same as in <ls>Mvy</ls> 〔5591〕; see {@sūcī, sūcikā@}; ({@5@}) see {@pādādhiṣṭhāna@}; ({@6@}) <lex>m.</lex>, <ab>n.</ab> of a (mythical) samādhi: <ls>Gv</ls> 〔451.26〕. In this curious passage, 〔451.25—452.6〕, the word adhiṣṭhāna is further used predicatively in a series of equational sentences, varying in gender like an adjective [Page016-b] with different subjects. Bhadrottamā says to Sudhana: ahaṃ kulaputrā 'nālayamaṇḍalaṃ nāma dharmaparyāyaṃ jānāmi deśayāmy, adhiṣṭhānaś ca me samādhiḥ pratilabdho; na tatra samādhau kasyacid dharmasyā 'dhiṣṭhānam; adhiṣṭhānaṃ tatra sarvajñatācakṣuḥ pravartate, 'dhiṣṭhānaṃ sarvajñatāśrotram, adhiṣṭhānaṃ sarvajñatāghrāṇam, adhiṣṭhānā sarvajñatājihvā, 'dhiṣṭhānaḥ sarvajñatākāyo, 'dhiṣṭhānaṃ tatra sarvajñatāmanaḥ pravartate, 'dhiṣṭhānā sarvajñatormir, adhiṣṭhānā sarvajñatāvidyud, adhiṣṭhānāḥ sarvajñatāvegāḥ pravartante jagadrocanāmaṇḍalāḥ; etam ahaṃ kulaputrā 'nālayamaṇḍalaṃ dharmaparyāyaṃ jānāmi. (Punctuation introduced by me.) There is no further light from the context. I am not sure what meaning the author attributed to the word adhiṣṭhāna: presumably something like either {%basis%} or {%controlling power%}.

5947 old {@abhijñā@}¦ (= <lang>Pali</lang> abhiññā), {%higher or supernatural knowledge; intuition%} (<ls>CPD</ls>). There are 5 or 6, in both <lang>Pali</lang> and <lang>BHS</lang>, agreeing in essence <acr>tho</acr> the order and precise forms of the names vary. In <ls>Dharmas</ls> 〔20〕, five: divyacakṣus, divyaśrotra, paracittajñāna, pūrvanivāsānusmṛti, ṛddhi; in <ls>Mvy</ls> 〔201—209〕 six, same order, with variant forms, (parasya) {@cetaḥ-@} (citta-)-{@paryāya-@} (<ab>q.v.</ab>)-jñāna, for the third; the sixth is āśravakṣayajñāna, as in <lang>Pali</lang> and elsewhere when 6 are named; the fifth is ṛddhividhijñāna in <ls>Mvy</ls> 〔208〕; <ls>SP</ls> 〔134.11〕 lists 5, practically as in <ls>Dharmas</ls> except that the fifth is ṛddhivimokṣakriyā, an unusual phrase, for which no <ab>v.l.</ab> is given in <ls>KN</ls> or <ls>WT</ls>; <ls>Burnouf</ls> (<ls>Lotus</ls> 〔App. XIV, p. 821〕) cites his <ab>ms.</ab> as reading ṛddhisākṣātkriyā, which is much more plausible. Twenty abhijñā-karmāṇi are set forth in detail <ls>Mvy</ls> 〔210—230〕. In <ls>Laṅk</ls> 〔292.13—16〕 the abhijñā, collectively, are classified as to their origin in four ways (in <ab>l.</ab> 16 read with <ls>Suzuki Transl.</ls> 〔242 n. 1〕 te 'bhijñā na vipākajāḥ). 7283 old {@Amitābha@}¦, ({@1@}) <ab>n.</ab> of the Buddha who presides over the western paradise {@Sukhāvatī@} (lokadhātu); also known as {@Amitāyu(s), Amitaprabha, Amitanātha@}, and doubtless intended by the <ls>Mmk</ls> names {@Amitāyu(rjñāna)viniścayarājendra@} (or the like), even <acr>tho</acr> he is once depicted separately in a painting centering about that personage (<ls>Mmk</ls> 〔305.12—13〕, <ab>cf.</ab> 〔304.25〕). See these names separately. The two commonest names are Amitābha and Amitāyus, and they are as a rule quite equivalent and interchangeable; see notably <ls>Sukh</ls> 〔62.13—14〕; 〔95.15〕 and 20. Often Sukhāvatī is mentioned with him. He is the fourth of the ‘transcendent’ Buddhas, <ls>Dharmas</ls> 〔3〕; <ls>Mvy</ls> 〔85〕. Other occurrences: <ls>Suv</ls> 〔2.5〕; <ls>Bhad</ls> 〔49, 57, 59, 62〕; <ls>Śikṣ</ls> 〔175.6〕; <ls>Kv</ls> 〔18.7〕; 〔21.8〕 <ab>etc.</ab>; <ls>Mmk</ls> 〔42.16〕; 〔426.7〕; <ls>Gv</ls> 〔82.5〕; <ls>Laṅk</ls> 〔283.7〕; <ls>Sukh</ls> 〔1.6〕; 〔28.10〕 <ab>etc.</ab>; <ls>Sādh</ls> 〔16.10〕 <ab>etc.</ab>; ({@2@}) <ab>n.</ab> of a Bodhisattva: <ls>Gv</ls> 〔442.22〕 (one of a long list, and hardly to be identified with the Buddha <ab n="Amitābha">A.</ab>).

; <L>1924<pc>066,1<k1>artiyati<k2>ar(t)tiyati
7739 old {@ar(t)tiyati@} or {@°tīyati, °te@}¦; in one doubtful passage perhaps ārtī°, otherwise always art° when not fused in saṃdhi with preceding vowel; forms occurring include ar(t)tīyati, °yanti, °tīyate, °tiyante, °tīyanto and °taṃ (<lex>pres. pple.</lex>), aritīyeran (! read art°), artita (<lex>ppp.</lex>); also ārtīyate (? <ab>v.l.</ab> attī°); attīyantā (and probably attīyate for <ab>prec.</ab>); ṛtīyate, °yante, °yamāna (<lex>pres. pple.</lex>; for ṛt° we usually find rit° written); ardīyamāna (<lex>pres. pple.</lex>); āstīryati; and noun {@attīyanā@}. The <ab>corresp.</ab> <lang>Pali</lang> (see <ls>CPD</ls>) is written aṭṭīyati, aṭṭhī°, aḍḍhī°, addiyati. Despite all this confusion, there is no doubt that we are dealing with essentially one word, with modifications due to diverse influences, including popular etymology and hyper-<acr>Sktism</acr>. <ls>Wogihara, ZDMG</ls> 〔58.454〕, gives the ‘correct form’ as ṛtīyate (which, or rather usually rit°, is customary in <ls>Bbh</ls>, but I believe occurs nowhere else), and the <ab>mg.</ab> as {%er schämt sich%}; both statements are wrong, I believe. As to <ab>mg.</ab>, <ls>Wogihara</ls> was evidently influenced by the fact that the word is often associated in <lang>Pali</lang> with harāyati, jigucchati, and in <lang>BHS</lang> with jehrīyate, (vi)jugupsati, or equivalents. But it is also often used where {%shame%} cannot be involved. Most likely the <lang>MIndic</lang> word is a denominative from ārti (for which arti, with semi-<lang>MIndic</lang> shortening, is recorded even in <lang>Skt.</lang>). All forms are included here since the word is clearly a unit, but they are also entered under the several heading: ({@1@}) {%is grieved, perturbed, distressed%}: <ls>Mv</ls> 〔i.219.17〕 = 〔ii.21.19〕 kecit saṃsārapāśena arttiyante (〔ii.21.19〕 saṃsāracāreṇa artīyanti) yathā aham (said by the infant Bodhisattva), {%are distressed%}; <ls>Mv</ls> 〔ii.161.7〕 bodhisattvo jātīye arttīyanto, {%being pained by%} (or, {%on account of%}) {%birth%}, 11—12 … maraṇena artt°, 13 śokehi artt°; <ls>Mv</ls> 〔ii.242.13〕 arttīyati (<ls>Senart</ls> <ab>em.</ab> attī°); <ls>Mv</ls> 〔i.89.18〕 (ākīrṇavihāreṇa) nārtīyanti; <ls>Mv</ls> 〔ii.480.7〕 śokārtita; <ls>LV</ls> 〔174.14〕 [Page066-b] jarārtita; <ls>Bbh</ls> 〔166.11〕 ṛtīyamānaḥ (of a Bodhisattva); <ls>Bbh</ls> 〔171.9〕 ritīyamānaṃ. ({@2@}) In some transitional cases, leading over to the next group, the additional note of {%aversion, revulsion%} seems more or less clearly present: <ls>Bbh</ls> 〔282.7—8〕 tena pūrvakeṇādhimokṣeṇāritīyeran (read °ṇārtīyeran; but in same phrase line 23 °mokṣeṇa ritīyante), {%they would be annoyed by, sick of, disgusted with their former enthusiasm%}; <ls>Bbh</ls> 〔168.23〕 ritīyate; <ls>Mvy</ls> 〔1830〕 nārtīyate (no context); ({@3@}) like preceding but accompanied by parallel forms of hrī-, jugups-, or the like: <ls>SP</ls> 〔108.6〕 daridracintayārtīyantaṃ jehrīyamāṇaṃ jugupsamānaṃ, {%distressed, ashamed, disgusted by the thought of being poor%}; <ls>Mv</ls> 〔i.343.1〕 (tena adharmeṇa) attīyantā (<ls>Senart</ls> <ab>em.</ab> artī°) vijigupsantā or °satā (<ab>mss.</ab> °satāṃ, evidently <lex>pres. pple.</lex>, <ls>Senart</ls> <ab>em.</ab> wrongly °sitā) {%distressed and disgusted by this immorality%}; <ls>Karmav</ls> 〔47.26〕 āstīryati jihreti vigarhati vijugupsati, {%is distressed, ashamed, offended, disgusted%} (by acts he has done); 〔49.2〕; <ls>Divy</ls> 〔39.7〕 ye 'nena pūtikāyenārdīyamānā jehrīyante vijugupsamānāḥ, {%being distressed, are ashamed, disgusted%}; ({@4@}) with <lex>abl.</lex>, {%feels aversion%} (from): <ls>MadhK</ls> 〔297.2〕, text ārtīyate (ebhyo dharmebhyo), but <ab>v.l.</ab> attīyate, so <ab>prob.</ab> read; followed by jehrīyate vitarati vijugupsate; in line 4 below (see note 1) <ab>mss.</ab> dharmebhyo attīyanā (text artī°) vijugupsanā (nouns).
;

9315 old {@aśubha-bhāvanā@}¦, <lex>f.</lex> <ab>pl.</ab> °nāḥ <ls>Mvy</ls> 〔1155〕; <ls>Bbh</ls> 〔98.18〕 (read aśubha-bhāvanā for <ab>ed.</ab> aśubhā-bh°); or {@aśubhasaṃjñā@}, <ls>Bhīk</ls> 〔27a.2〕 (= <lang>Pali</lang> asubha-bhāvanā or -saññā), see {@saṃjñā@}, {%contemplation of offensive things%}, specifically of human corpses in various states of disintegration; there are nine (in <lang>Pali</lang>, <ls>Vism.</ls> 〔i.110.29—31〕 ten) such monkish disciplines, elsewhere called simply nava saṃjñāh, {%the nine concepts%} (of offensive things), <ls>ŚsP</ls> 〔59.1〕; 〔1258.5〕; a less schematized passage of the same sort in older <lang>Pali</lang>, <ls>MN</ls> 〔i.58.9 ff.〕 In <ls>Mvy</ls> 〔1156—64〕 they are listed, each <ab>cpd.</ab> with -saṃjñā: (1) {@vinīlaka-@}, (2) {@vipūyaka-@} (so read), (3) {@vipaḍumaka-@}, (4) {@vyādhmātaka-@}, (5) {@vilohitaka-@}, (6) {@vikhāditaka-@}, (7) {@vikṣiptaka-@}, (8) {@vidagdhaka-@}, (9) {@asthi-saṃjñā@} (see each of these). <ls>Bhīk</ls> 〔27a.2—3〕 agrees except that it transposes <ab>Nos.</ab> 5 and 6 and accidentally omits 8 (which perhaps should be put after 9; only <ls>Mvy</ls> has it before 9). 10641 old {@āttamana(s)@}¦, <lex>adj.</lex> (= <lang>Pali</lang> attamana(s), which is also, but less often, represented by {@āptamana(s)@}, <ab>q.v.</ab>, on which <ab>cf.</ab> <ls>CPD</ls> <ab>s.v.</ab> attamanas, which fails to note occurrence of āpta° in <lang>BHS</lang>), {%glad at heart, delighted%}; <ab>esp.</ab> in certain formulas; applied to the audience at the end of a discourse by Buddha, <ab>e.g.</ab> <ls>Mv</ls> 〔i.61.8〕 idam avocad bhagavān, āttamano (<ab>n. sg.</ab> <lex>m.</lex>) āyuṣmān Mahāmaudgalyāyano bhagavato bhāṣitam abhyanandat; <ls>Divy</ls> 〔197.26〕 idam avocad bhagavān, āttamanasas te bhikṣavo 'bhyanandan; often in a series of synonyms, as tuṣṭa udagra āttamanāḥ pramuditaḥ prītisaumanasyajātaḥ <ls>Gv</ls> 〔99.15〕; <ls>Suv</ls> 〔9.7—8〕; plurals of the same words <ls>SP</ls> 〔209.9—10〕; and variations, as hṛṣṭā tuṣṭā āttamanā (<ab>n. pl.</ab> <lex>m.</lex>) pramudita-prītisaumanasyajātā <ls>Mv</ls> 〔i.230.20〕; more briefly, tuṣṭo āttamano abhūt <ls>Mv</ls> 〔ii.195.10〕; tuṣṭo āttamanā (<ab>n. sg.</ab> <lex>m.</lex>) imaṃ udānam udānaye (<lex>aor.</lex>) 〔i.351.13〕; dātāraṃ ca dṛṣṭvā āttamanā bhavati sumanaskaḥ <ls>Bbh</ls> 〔4.24〕; sattvā āttamanaso 'bhūvan <ls>RP</ls> 〔37.8—9〕; Indra āttamanā (<ab>n. sg.</ab> <lex>m.</lex>) tasyāṃ velāyāṃ … <ls>Divy</ls> 〔195.24〕; dṛṣṭvā ca bhavati (bhoti) āttamanā (<ab>n. sg.</ab> <lex>f.</lex>) <ls>Mv</ls> 〔i.213.13〕 = 〔ii.16.16〕; doubled (intensive āmreḍita), sā 'ttamanāttamanā(ḥ) {%she, greatly delighted%}, <ls>Divy</ls> 〔2.8〕; <ls>Av</ls> 〔i.14.11〕; so 'py āttamanāttamanā(ḥ) <ls>Divy</ls> 〔2.11〕; <ls>Av</ls> 〔i.14.13〕; similarly <ls>Divy</ls> 〔440.24〕; <ab>neg.</ab> anāttamanā(ḥ) <ls>Karmav</ls> 〔22.10〕 (follows atiśayitaroṣaś caṇḍībhūto). Once printed {@attamanas@}, <ab>q.v.</ab> This word is to be analyzed as a <ab>cpd.</ab> of <lang>Skt.</lang> ātta, <lex>ppp.</lex> of ā-dā, with manas. The alternant {@āptamanas@} is analyzable as āpta, <lex>ppp.</lex> of āp (<ab>cf.</ab> {@manaāpa, manāpa@}) plus manas. <lang>Pali</lang> attamana(s) could represent both; both may be <acr>Sktization</acr>s of that <lang>MIndic</lang> form.
;

; <L>2711<pc>095,1<k1>ADipateya<k2>ADipateya
10893 old {@ādhipateya@}¦, <lex>nt.</lex> (anomalously <lex>m.</lex> <ls>Mvy</ls> 〔7192〕 °yaḥ = <lang>Tib.</lang> <tib>bdaṅ du ḥgyur ba</tib> (or <tib>bya ba</tib>), so also <ls>Mironov</ls>; = <lang>Pali</lang> ādhipateyya, see below; from adhipati, roughly = <lang>Skt.</lang> ādhipatya, which is used in <ls>AbhidhK.</ls>, see Index, in ways not closely parallel to the <lang>Pali</lang> usage), {%control, influence, mastery, prime motivation%} (<ab>lit.</ab> {%overlordship%}). In <lang>Pali</lang> <ab>esp.</ab> used of one of three influences leading to virtue, attādhi° (<ab>q.v.</ab> <ls>CPD</ls>), lokādhi°, dhammādhi°, see <ls>Childers</ls> <ab>s.v.</ab> ādhipateyya and <ls>Vism.</ls> 〔i.14.1 ff.〕 ({%the influence of oneself%}, <ab>i.e.</ab> {%conscience%} or {%self-respect; the influence of the world%} or {%public opinion; the influence of dhamma%} or {%regard for moral principles%} as authoritatively laid down). In <lang>BHS</lang> little evidence is found for the existence of these, <acr>tho</acr> <ls>Speyer</ls> (<ls>Transl.</ls> 〔114〕) renders <ls>Jm</ls> 〔80.14〕 (hrīvarṇapratisaṃyukteṣu) lokādhipateyeṣu ca (<ab>sc.</ab> upaneyam) by {%… the regard of public opinion%}, perhaps rightly. On the other hand, lokādhipateya-prāpta <ls>LV</ls> 〔425.5〕 can only mean {%arrived at the overlordship of the world%}; it is one of a long list of epithets of the Buddha as the one that has ‘turned the wheel of the Law’; it is preceded by lokagurur … lokārthakara … lokānuvartaka … lokavid ity ucyate, and it would be absurd to interpret it as {%under the control of public opinion%}. (See also <ls>LV</ls> 〔179.20—21〕 <ab>s.v.</ab> {@ādhipateyatā@}.) <ls>Mv</ls> 〔i.16.12〕 = 〔18.5, 15〕 = 〔19.5〕 = 〔20.10〕 (evaṃ khalu) punaḥ ādhipateya-mātram etaṃ tatropatteḥ, {%but this, of course, is only the principal cause%} (controlling influence) {%of rebirth there%} (<ab>viz.</ab> in one of various hells); <ls>Gv</ls> 〔19.8〕 na tad balaṃ na tad ādhipateyaṃ … (saṃvidyate), {%that%} (sort of) {%power%} or {%controlling influence%} (is not found); oftener at the end of <ab>Bhvr.</ab> <ab>cpds.</ab>, <ls>Śikṣ</ls> 〔117.3〕 mahākaruṇādhipateyaṃ, (any action of Bodhisattvas is …) {%controlled%} (influenced) {%by supreme compassion%}; <ls>Śikṣ</ls> 〔250.5〕 cakṣurindriyādhipateyā rūpārambaṇaprativijñaptiḥ, {%recognition of the sense-object form, which%} (recognition) {%is controlled by%} (= dependent on) {%the sense of sight%}; <ls>Dbh</ls> 〔11.20〕 (tac cittam utpadyate bodhisattvānāṃ) mahākaruṇāpūrvamgamaṃ prajñājñānādhipateyaṃ …; <ls>Śikṣ</ls> 〔322.15〕 dharmādhipateya, of Buddhas. ; <L>2792<pc>098,2<k1>Abfhati<k2>Abfhati
11217 old {@ābṛhati@}¦ (and āvṛhati; see also {@āvṛṃhati@}) both occur in <lang>Skt.</lang> in <ab>mg.</ab> {%extracts, draws out%}, and in <lang>Pali</lang> as abbahati, abbuhati, abbū°, abbāheti, <ab>id.</ab> (as, thorns); both are so used also in <lang>BHS</lang>; but in <lang>BHS</lang> they both (oftener, it seems, spelled with v) have also the meaning exclusively noted for {@āvarhati@}, {%restores%} (a monk to good standing), which in <lang>Pali</lang> is abbheti (noun, abbhāna), apparently from <lang>Skt.</lang> āhvayati. I shall record such <ab>mgs.</ab>, even where texts read āb°, under {@āvarhati@}; in <lang>BHS</lang> the two groups are not clearly distinguishable. They may even be identical in origin, as <ls>N. Dutt</ls> holds, <ls>MSV</ls> 〔iii.74 n. 3〕 ({%withdrawal of offences%} committed by the monk implies restoration to good standing); so also in essence, <acr>tho</acr> doubtfully, <ls>Finot, Prāt</ls> 〔488 n. 1〕. But on this theory it is hard to explain <lang>Pali</lang> abbheti (abbhāna), and I incline to believe that <lang>BHS</lang> has a secondary and confused blend, in which a form close to the <lang>Pali</lang>, meaning {%recall%}, was adapted to the word meaning {%extract, remove%}.

; <L>3061<pc>110,1<k1>ASvAsapraSvAsa<k2>ASvAsa-praSvAsa
12293 old {@āśvāsa-praśvāsa@}¦ (<lang>Pali</lang> assāsa-passāsa), <lex>m.</lex> dual or <ab>pl.</ab>, {%breath%}; usually used without clear indication of difference between the two terms, like {@ānāpāna@}, <ab>q.v.</ab>: <ls>LV</ls> 〔251.15—16〕 nāsikātaś cāśvāsapraśvāsāv uparuddhāv abhūtāṃ; 〔252.3〕 °sā ūrdhvaṃ śiraḥkapālam upanighnanti sma; as separate words, 〔259.7〕 āśvāsaviprahīnaḥ praśvāsavarjitu; <ls>Mv</ls> 〔ii.124.10 (and ff.)〕 mukhato nāsikāśrotrehi ca āśvāsapraśvāsā uparundhi (1 <ab>sg.</ab> <lex>aor.</lex>); <ls>Mv</ls> 〔iii.179.19〕 °sehi tathāgataṃ upahanati; <ls>Śāl</ls> 〔78.3, 17〕 kāyasyāśvāsapraśvāsakṛtyaṃ; <ls>Sādh</ls> 〔61.19〕 °sādikam; the verb {@uśvasati@}, <ab>q.v.</ab>, [Page110-b] corresponds to āśvāsa in <ls>Mv</ls> 〔ii.208.3—4〕 āśvāsapraśvāsā uparuddhā … no pi uśvasati na praśvasati (the two verbs repeated twice in lines 8, 9), <ab>cf.</ab> <ls>LV</ls> 〔189.12〕 ucchvasantaṃ praśvasantam, rendered by <lang>Tib.</lang> <tib>dbugs dbyuṅ zhiṅ rṅub</tib> {%breathing out and in%}, but in line 15 below praśvasantaḥ is rendered <tib>dbugs dbyuṅ</tib>, {%breathing out%} (implying that ucchvasantaṃ was understood as {%breathing in%}); {@ucchvāsapraśvāso@} (<ab>sg.</ab>) also occurs, seemingly = āśvāsa-pra°, <ls>Śikṣ</ls> 〔42.5〕; in <ls>Sādh</ls> 〔146.17 ff.〕 it is entirely certain that praśvāsa is understood as {%outbreathing%} and āśvāsa {%inbreathing%}, tadanu tan mithunaṃ praśvāsavāyurathārūḍhaṃ nāsikāvivareṇa niḥsṛtya … sattvānāṃ kāyavākcittāni viśodhya gṛhītvā ca punar āśvāsavāyum āruhya tenaiva pathā svahṛtkamalakarṇikāyāṃ praviśet; consistent with this is <lang>AMg.</lang> ussāsa (and relatives), which <lang>BHS</lang> usage would clearly have associated with āśvāsa, and which <ab>acc.</ab> to <ls>Ratnach.</ls> means {%breathing in%}; <lang>Pali</lang> tradition is indeterminate, see <ls>Vism</ls> 〔i.272.1〕 which states that <ls>Vin. comm.</ls> defines assāsa as {%outgoing%}, passāsa as {%incoming%} breath, but that in Sutta <ab>comms.</ab> (Suttantaṭṭhakathāsu) the reverse is taught (the passage is misunderstood by <ls>PTSD</ls> and <ls>Pe Maung Tin<ls>; uppaṭipāṭiyā = <lang>Pkt.</lang> upparivāḍi, {%inverted, transposed%}). <lang>Tib.</lang> regularly āśvasati = <tib>dbugs brṅubs</tib> (or cognate) {%breathe in%} <ls>Mvy</ls> 〔1173, 1175〕, <ab>etc.</ab>, praśvasati = <tib>dbugs phyuṅ</tib> (or cognate) {%breathe out%} <ls>Mvy</ls> 〔1174, 1176〕, <ab>etc.</ab>; it therefore supports <ls>Sādh</ls> 〔146.17 ff.〕, and incidentally the equation of āśvāsa with āna and praśvāsa with apāna (see {@ānāpāna@}). How old this interpretation is remains uncertain, <ab>esp.</ab> in view of the fact that in <lang>Pali</lang> the <ab>comms.</ab> differed; Buddhaghosa himself, in the <ls>Vism.</ls> passage cited, declines to arbitrate between the two opposing views. Whatever may have been the meaning of the two terms, it seems clear that the <ab>cpd.</ab> (like {@ānāpāna@}) was commonly used in the sense of {%breath%}, collectively and as a whole.
;

this <ab>mg.</ab> is not found for uttari(ṃ);] in composition, uttari-jñāna-viśeṣasūcanatāyai <ls>Gv</ls> 〔191.11〕 (prose; apparently substantially = uttara); note <ab>esp.</ab> [Page124-a] uttarottari-(<ab>v.l.</ab> °ra-)-viśiṣṭatara-kuśalamūla- <ls>LV</ls> 〔429.14〕 (prose), {%more and more exceedingly superior roots of merit%}; (ekam pudgalaṃ sthāpayitvā) śaikṣapratipady uttarikaranīyaṃ <ls>Sukh</ls> 〔2.13〕 (prose), (except one person) {%who had something left to do in the śaikṣa course%} (the rest all being arhats); note that <lang>Pali</lang> has the same <ab>cpd.</ab> uttarikaraṇīya, but <ab>acc.</ab> to <ls>PTSD</ls> only as a karmadharaya, {%an additional duty%}, not as a bahuvrīhi as here; in some of the above it is not certain whether uttari- is compounded with the following word or a separate adverb; in <ls>LV</ls> 〔246.16〕; 〔263.11〕, above, uttari must be <lex>prep.</lex>, governing manuṣyadharmād; to these passages correspond <ls>Mv</ls> 〔ii.121.7, 12〕; 〔122.2〕 uttari-manuṣyadharmasya jñānāye darśanāye saṃbodhāye; <ls>Senart</ls> takes the word as a <ab>cpd.</ab>, depending on jñānāye <ab>etc.</ab>, <ab>prob.</ab> rightly, <ab>tho</ab> the <lex>gen.</lex> manuṣyadharmasya might be dependent on <lex>prep.</lex> uttari; <ls>Divy</ls> 〔145.21, 28〕 and 〔146.16〕 uttarimanuṣyadharme (so with <ab>mss.</ab>, <ab>ed.</ab> wrongly <ab>em.</ab> uttare man°); <ls>Śikṣ</ls> 〔62.4〕 uttarimanuṣyadharmair; besides this, the same <ab>cpd.</ab> is recorded in <lang>BHS</lang> (not in <lang>Pali</lang>) as uttara-manuṣyadharma-(-pralāpa, <lex>m.</lex>), <ls>Mvy</ls> 〔8367〕, {%declaring%} (falsely the possession of) {%superhuman faculties%} (one of the {@parajika@} sins); It seems clear that {%this%} sattussada in <lang>Pali</lang> = <lang>Skt.</lang> *sattvotsada, {%abounding in living creatures%}. It seems to have been falsely <acr>Sktized</acr> in <ls>Divy</ls> (which, or its source, obviously followed closely a <lang>MIndic</lang> original very close to the <lang>Pali</lang> of <ls>DN</ls>) to saptotsada, because the adapter knew familiarly this <ab>cpd.</ab> as one of the 32 lakṣaṇa (above, 1). Presumably he thought it meant here {%containing seven elevations%} of some sort, but I see no use in speculating further as to his intentions.

<ls>SP</ls> 〔170.1〕 (<ab>vs</ab>) apāyabhūmīs (so all <lang>Nep.</lang> <ab>mss.</ab>) tada utsadāsi, {%the stages of misfortune were then superabundant%}; <ls>LV</ls> 〔276.21〕 utsadamaṇimuktivaiḍūryaśaṅkhaśilāpravāḍarajatajātarūpyaṃ (? <ab>v.l.</ab> °rūpaṃ; <ab>sc.</ab> lokadhātuṃ); <ls>RP</ls> 〔35.11〕 (<ab>vs</ab>) asaṃyatā uddhata unnatāś ca, agauravā mānina lābha-utsadā [Page127-a] (<ab>cpd.</ab>) … sudūra te tādṛśa agrabodhaye (either {%abounding in profit%} or {%having abundance of profit%}). Peculiar is saptotsada in <ls>Divy</ls> 〔620.13〕 (Utkaṭaṃ nāma droṇamukhaṃ paribhuṅkte sma) saptotsadaṃ satṛṇakāṣṭhodakaṃ dhānyasahagataṃ … brahmadeyaṃ, and 〔620.28—621.1〕, similarly, with sa-saptotsadam; a close parallel in <lang>Pali</lang>, <ls>DN</ls> 〔i.87.(6—)7〕 Ukkaṭṭhaṃ ajjhāvasati sattussadaṃ (<ab>comm.</ab> 〔i.245.20〕 sattehi ussadaṃ, ussannaṃ bahujanaṃ ākiṇṇamanussaṃ … anekasattasamākiṇṇaṃ ca) satiṇakaṭṭhodakaṃ sadhaññaṃ … brahmadeyyaṃ; <ab>cf.</ab> also <ls>Pv comm.</ls> 〔221.11〕 sattussadan ti pāpakārīhi sattehi ussannaṃ (this, in line 16, = uparūpari nicitaṃ). It seems clear that {%this%} sattussada in <lang>Pali</lang> = <lang>Skt.</lang> *sattvotsada, {%abounding in living creatures%}. It seems to have been falsely <ab>Sktized</ab> in <ls>Divy</ls> (which, or its source, obviously followed closely a <lang>MIndic</lang> original very close to the <lang>Pali</lang> of <ls>DN</ls>) to saptotsada, because the adapter knew familiarly this <ab>cpd.</ab> as one of the 32 lakṣaṇa (above, 1). Presumably he thought it meant here {%containing seven elevations%} of some sort, but I see no use in speculating further as to his intentions.

; <L>3682<pc>135,2<k1>upaDi<k2>upaDi
14783 old {@upadhi@}¦ (<lex>m.</lex>; = <lang>Pali</lang> upadhi, and also <lang>Pali</lang> upādi), ({@1@}) {%substratum%} of continued existence; {%attachment, bond%} uniting one to existence. <ab>Acc.</ab> to <ls>Childers</ls> upādi means the khandhas alone, while upadhi includes also kilesa (with which <ls>PTSD</ls> makes it ‘almost synonymous’), kāma, and kamma; but <ab>acc.</ab> to <ls>PTSD</ls> upadhi is sometimes equated with the pañca-kkhandhā. In <lang>Pali</lang>, upādi is, <ab>acc.</ab> to <ls>PTSD</ls>, used only in <ab>comp.</ab> with -sesa, in <ab>cpds.</ab> usually beginning sa- or an- and regularly epithets of nibbāna (-dhātu); these are represented in <lang>BHS</lang> by {@anupadhiśeṣa, nirupa°, sopa°@}, <ab>qq.v.</ab> But <lang>BHS</lang> also has upadhi and {@nir-up°@} (<ab>m.c.</ab> {@niropadhi@}) = <lang>Pali</lang> (nir-)upadhi. The passages here listed belong exclusively to this latter class, = <lang>Pali</lang> upadhi. (But it seems that even in <lang>Pali</lang>, upadhi and upādi are not always clearly distinguished.) upadhī-kṣīṇā <ls>LV</ls> 〔358.18〕 (<ab>vs</ab>); sarvopadhi-pratiniḥsarga {%the getting rid of all up°%} <ls>LV</ls> 〔31.21〕; <ls>Mv</ls> 〔ii.285.20〕; 〔iii.314.4〕; sarvopadhi-niḥsarga (<ab>Bhvr.</ab>, with dharma) <ls>LV</ls> 〔392.11〕; 〔395.21〕; sarvopadhikṣaya- <ls>Mv</ls> 〔i.115.8〕; <ab>cf.</ab> 〔ii.418.10〕 upadhi (<ab>mss.</ab>, <ls>Senart</ls> <ab>em.</ab> °dhiṃ) pratītya duḥkhasya saṃbhavo sarvaśopadhikṣayato (<ab>mss.</ab>, <ls>Senart</ls> <ab>em.</ab> sarvopa°) … nāsti duḥkhasya saṃbhavo; <ls>Mv</ls> 〔iii.282.6〕 upadhi-saṃkṣaye; <ls>Divy</ls> 〔224.20〕 śalyam upadhiṃ viditvā; <ls>Ud</ls> 〔ii.20〕 upadhiṃ hi loke śalyam iti matvā, {%<fr>ľattachement … cʼest la misère …</fr>%} Others <ab>s.v.</ab> {@niropadhi@}. In <ls>Mvy</ls> 〔6499〕 upadhi has three <lang>Tib.</lang> definitions; the first, <tib>phuṅ po</tib>, regularly = {@skandha@} (as <lang>Pali</lang> upādi = khandha); the third, <tib>ñon moṅs pa</tib>, regularly = {@kleśa@} (as <lang>Pali</lang> upadhi, ‘almost <ab>syn.</ab> with kilesa,’ <ls>PTSD</ls>); while the second, <tib>rdzas</tib>, {%thing, substance, matter%}, belongs to a meaning of the word <ab>app.</ab> unknown to <lang>Pali</lang>, <ab>viz.</ab> ({@2@}) {%material thing, <fr>‘chose matérielle’</fr>%} (<ls>Lévi</ls>, = <lang>Tib.</lang> <tib>dṅos</tib>, which also = <lang>Skt.</lang> vastu), <ls>Sūtrāl.</ls> 〔xvii.3〕 (〔n. 1〕 in <ls>Transl.</ls>); see also <ls>LaVallée Poussin, AbhidhK.</ls> 〔iv.15 with n. 1〕: ‘<fr>Par upadhi, il faut entendre la chose (ārāma, vihāra, <ab>etc.</ab>) donnée à un moine ou au Saṃgha: le mérite qui procède (tadbhava) de cet upadhi sʼappelle</fr> [Page136-a] {@aupadhika@}’ (<ab>q.v.</ab>). Hence, ({@3@}) in <ls>Divy</ls> 〔50.28〕 bhagavān upadhau vartate, {%the Lord was acting in regard to material things%} (of the assembly of monks), <ab>i.e.</ab> in the function of an {@upadhi-vārika@}, <ab>q.v.</ab> (= {@aupadhike@} <ls>Divy</ls> 〔542.17〕). (See also <ab>s.v.</ab> {@plotikā@}.)

; <L>3765<pc>140,1<k1>upalamBa<k2>upalamBa
15115 old {@upalambha@}¦ (<ab>cf.</ab> <lang>Skt.</lang> <ab>id.</ab>; not recorded in <lang>Pali</lang>; <ab>cf.</ab> <ab>prec.</ab>, {@an-upa°, an-upalabdhi@}, the next items, and {@aupalambhika@}), <ab>acc.</ab> to standard interpretation, {%mental perception%} or {%apperception, realization by the intellect%}; <ls>Sūtrāl.</ls> 〔xviii.92〕 <ab>comm.</ab> buddhyā pratipattiḥ; <lang>Tib.</lang> <tib>dmigs (-pa)</tib> {%thought, fancy, imagination; to construe in oneʼs mind%}, <ab>etc.</ab>; see also <ls>LaVallée-Poussin, AbhidhK.</ls> 〔Index〕 <ab>s.v.</ab> upalabdhi. Were it not for this persistent tradition, some occurrences, <ab>esp.</ab> of the <ab>neg.</ab> forms ({@an-upalambha, °labdhi@}), could easily be interpreted as related to upalabhyate (1) and <ab>mg.</ab> (non-){%occurrence%}, (non-){%existence%}. These <ab>mgs.</ab> are attributed by <ls>CPD</ls> to an-upaladdhi, °labbhana; and <acr>tho</acr> not recognized in <ls>PTSD</ls>, {%occurrence, existence%} seems to me the probable <ab>mg.</ab> of upaladdhi in the two passages cited for it, <ls>Miln.</ls> 〔268.7〕 and <ls>Vv. comm.</ls> 〔279.10〕. In many <lang>BHS</lang> places {%inconceivability%} or {%non-occurrence, non-reality%} would make equally good sense for an-upa°. I do not, however, venture to abandon what [Page140-b] seems to have been the standard tradition. Reliance on upalambha, {%mental perception, fancy%}, is an error, stigmatized as upalambha-dṛṣṭi, {%the heresy that relies on upalambha%}, <ls>LV</ls> 〔35.6〕 (or as <ab>Bhvr.</ab>, {%one who adheres to that heresy%}, <ls>SP</ls> 〔383.12〕); see also °dṛṣṭika. Similarly upalambha-saṃjñin <ls>Śikṣ</ls> 〔315.1〕, {%having the%} (false) {%notion of upalambha%}; upalambha-yogena, {%by the%} (erroneous) {%method of upalambha%}, <ls>ŚsP</ls> 〔1042.16〕, repeated formulaically (<ab>cf.</ab> anupalambha-yogena <ab>s.v.</ab> {@anupalambha@}).
;

one alternative <lang>Tib.</lang> rendering of upasaṃhāraḥ at <ls>Mvy</ls> 〔6395〕 is <tib>ñe bar</tib> ({%near%}, a <ab>lit.</ab> rendering of upa) <tib>bsgrub pa</tib> ({%make, provide, supply%}), <ab>cf.</ab> <ls>KP</ls> 〔3.6〕 <ab>s.v.</ab> {@upasaṃharati@} 3; ({@3@}) (<ab>cf.</ab> {@upasaṃharati@} 4, 5) specialized as {%production in words, presentation%} (orally), {%statement, declaration, proclamation%}, <ab>esp.</ab> of something of religious nature: <ls>Mvy</ls> 〔8502〕 śikṣopasaṃhārapratikṣepaḥ, {%rejection of a statement of instruction%} (<ab>prob.</ab> refers to the case of <lang>Pali</lang> <ls>Vin.</ls> 〔iv.143.16〕. ; <L>4540<pc>170,2<k1>karmapaTa<k2>karmapaTa
18233 old {@karmapatha@}¦, <lex>m.</lex> (<lex>nt.</lex> noted only <ls>Kv</ls> 〔46.1—2〕 daśa kuśalāni karmapathāny; = <lang>Pali</lang> kammapatha; seems to be a fundamentally Buddhist term, <acr>tho</acr> recorded once by <ls>BR</ls> in <ls>Mbh.</ls> <ed>Calc.</ed> 〔13.583〕, which is followed by a list of the ten items substantially as in Buddhism, belief in the law of fruition of actions taking the place of 〔No. 10〕, abstention from heresy), {%course of action%}; almost always, as in <lang>Pali</lang>, of a set of ten good (kuśala) actions consisting in avoidance of ten bad (akuśala) actions, three of body (taking life, theft, fornication or adultery), four of speech (lying, harsh speech, spiteful speech, idle or silly, disconnected speech), and three of mind (covetousness, malevolence, heresy); these are listed without use of the term karmapatha, as daśākuśalāni and or daśa kuśalāni, in <ls>Dharmas</ls> 〔56〕 and <ls>Mvy</ls> 〔1681—4, 1685—1698〕; but the same list is given in texts as the ten (a)kuśala karmapatha, so <ls>Mv</ls> 〔i.107.13—15〕; <ls>Divy</ls> 〔301.22—25〕; 〔302.7—10〕; <ls>Śikṣ</ls> 〔69.13 ff.〕 and <ls>Dbh</ls> 〔23.6 ff.〕, in both of which each item is treated at some length, <ab>esp.</ab> in <ls>Śikṣ</ls> which describes the torments suffered in hell by those guilty of each of the 10 sins; in <ls>Mv</ls> 〔ii.99.5—12〕 the ten karmapatha are slightly different; a fourth sin of the body (use of liquor) is added, and the number ten is kept by omitting one of the 4 sins of speech (harshness), also avidyā, {%ignorance%}, replaces abhidhyā, {%covetousness%} (this seems likely to be a mere corruption of [Page171-a] tradition); in <ls>Mv</ls> 〔i.26.12〕 akuśala karmapatha is used more loosely, of sinful acts in general, specifically exemplified by the five {@ānantarya@}, <ab>q.v.</ab>; in <ls>Mv</ls> 〔i.282.14〕 the term ten kuśala karmapatha (in prose) is immediately followed (in verses) by a list of ten vaśitā, apparently implying that they are the same (not the usual 10 karmapatha); in <ls>Suv</ls> 〔6.11〕 the expression is daśakuśalamūlakarmapatha; often a form of the verb sam-ā-dā-, {%adopt, take to, adhere to%}, governs the noun, as in <ls>Mv</ls> 〔ii.77.11〕 daśa kuśalakarmapathāṃ (<lex>acc.</lex> <ab>pl.</ab>) samādāya; <ls>Suv</ls> 〔6.11〕 … °thaṃ samādāpayet; in <ls>Mv</ls> 〔ii.425.10〕 read with <ab>mss.</ab> daśa-kuśalakarmapatha-samādānaṃ vartitvā (= vartayitvā, {%having practised the taking-upon-oneself, the vow, of …%}); <ab>cf.</ab> {@samādiyati, °dāpayati, °dāna@}; other references to the 10 kuśala, or akuśala, karmapatha, without listing, are found <ls>Mv</ls> 〔i.3.1〕; 〔46.10〕; 〔101.18〕; 〔193.15〕; 〔iii.357.14〕; <ls>Divy</ls> 〔318.22〕; <ls>Karmav</ls> 〔31.13, 14〕; <ls>Gv</ls> 〔521.4〕.
;

19365 old {@Kāśyapa@}¦ (= <lang>Pali</lang> Kassapa; <lang>Tib.</lang> <tib>ḥod sruṅs</tib>, {%light-guard%}, <ab>e.g.</ab> on <ls>Mvy</ls> 〔93〕), ({@1@}) <ab>n.</ab> of a former Buddha, the one immediately preceding Śākyamuni: often mentioned as having predicted the latter, and <ab>esp.</ab> as one of a group of three, the others being {@Krakucchanda@} and {@Kanakamuni@}, or equivalents; see the former for list of such references; also alone (it being not always certain that this particular Buddha is meant, <ab>cf.</ab> <ls>Mv</ls> 〔i.58.8〕, <ab>ref.</ab> to 90,000 Buddhas of this name), <ls>Mv</ls> 〔i.307.4 ff.〕; 〔312.2〕; 〔318.7 ff.〕; [Page182-a] 〔iii.249.8〕; <ls>Divy</ls> 〔22.4 ff.〕; 〔54.12, 25〕; 〔76.26 ff.〕; 〔192.25 ff.〕; 〔233.21 ff.〕; 〔336.21〕; 〔337.17〕; 〔344.4 ff.〕; 〔347.1 ff.〕; 〔465.25 ff.〕; 〔504.26〕; <ls>Av</ls> 〔i.237.11〕; 〔247.15〕, et alibi; <ls>Karmav</ls> 〔159.7〕; <ls>LV</ls> 〔172.9〕; 〔260.10〕; <ls>Mmk</ls> 〔104.17 ff.〕; ({@2@}) <ab>n.</ab> of one of Buddhaʼs leading disciples, also called {@Mahā-k°@} (= <lang>Pali</lang> Kassapa or Mahā-k°), <ab>q.v.</ab>; there is no doubt that the same person is, as a rule at least, meant by the two forms, notably Kā° in <ls>Mvy</ls> 〔1031〕; <ls>Mv</ls> 〔iii.48.2〕; <ls>SP</ls> 〔116.4〕; 〔121.3 ff.〕; 〔144.2 ff.〕; 〔206.8 ff.〕; <ls>Divy</ls> 〔83.10 ff.〕; 〔396.1〕; <ab n="Kāśyapa">K.</ab> is given the title dhutaguṇāgrapāraga <ls>Mv</ls> 〔i.64.14 (ff.)〕, where he is involved as an interlocutor at the First Council, perhaps its presiding officer (as in <lang>Pali</lang>, <ls>DPPN</ls>); he then and there causes Kātyāyana to discourse on the 10 bhūmi; similarly <ls>Divy</ls> 〔61.28〕 calls him dhūtaguṇa-vādinām agro, and <ab>cf.</ab> <lang>Pali</lang> <ls>AN</ls> 〔i.23.19〕 where Mahākassapa is dhutavādānaṃ (<ab>v.l.</ab> dhūtaṅgadharānaṃ) agga; mentioned in Candropama Sūtra, <ls>Hoernle MR</ls> 〔40 ff.〕, = <lang>Pali</lang> <ls>SN</ls> 〔ii.197 ff.〕 where (Mahā) Kassapa corresponds; among mahāśrāvakas, <ls>Divy</ls> 〔182.22〕; 〔268.6〕; in <ls>Divy</ls> 〔573.8〕 it appears, strangely, that āryakāśyapasya is an epithet of (the next word) Kātyāyanasya (pañcaśataparivārasya; in the story which follows only Mahākātyāyana appears!); it is not clear whether the same person is meant by āyuṣmān daśabalaḥ Kāśyapaḥ <ls>Divy</ls> 〔275.5〕, and 7 daśabala-Kāś°;* no monk of this title is recorded in <lang>Pali</lang>; in <ls>Vv. comm.</ls> 〔148.24〕 Kassapassa dasabalassa kāle refers to the Buddha Kāś°, <acr>tho</acr> I find no evidence to support <ls>PTSD</ls> and <ls>DPPN</ls> in stating that dasabala was ‘especially’ an epithet of his, ‘to distinguish him from other Kassapas’ as <ls>DPPN</ls> says; dasabala (<lang>BHS</lang> daśa°) of course usually refers to a Buddha, and in <lang>Pali</lang> generally to the <ab>B.</ab> Gotama; there are at least four other disciples of his having this name, see {@Uruvilvā-k°, Kumāra-k°, Gayā-k°, Nadī-k°@}; ({@3@}) <ab>n.</ab> of an ascetic (ṛṣi) who once lived in the Himālaya: <ls>Mv</ls> 〔ii.106.16〕, a previous birth of {@Mahākāśyapa@}, <ab>q.v.</ab>, 〔114.12〕; ({@4@}) <ab>n.</ab> of another (?) ascetic (ṛṣi) who lived in the hermitage {@sāhaṃjanī@} (<ab>q.v.</ab>; this is not mentioned in connection with the <ab>prec.</ab> Kā°, and the stories told of them are different): <ls>Mv</ls> 〔iii.143.13 ff.〕 (in story of Ekaśṛṅga and Nalinī; = <lang>Pali</lang> Kassapa 9 in <ls>DPPN</ls>); <ab>prob.</ab> the same (at least also living in Sāhaṃjanī) <ls>Mv</ls> 〔iii.362.14〕; 〔363.19〕. See also {@Pūraṇa Kāśyapa; Jaṅghā-k°@}; {@Vṛddha-k°@}. —*Correction in proof: <ls>MPS</ls> 〔49.16〕 names four mahāsthavirāḥ in the world (pṛthivyāṃ) at the time of Buddhaʼs death; two of them were Daśabala-Kāśyapa (one word) and Mahā-Kāśyapa. This settles the above question; <ab n="Daśabala-Kāśyapa">D.K.</ab> is a separate person.

21133 old {@kaukṛtya@}¦, <lex>nt.</lex> (<lang>Skt.</lang> <ab>Lex.</ab>; <ab>cf.</ab> <ab>prec.</ab>; = <lang>Pali</lang> kukkucca, of which or of a <lang>MIndic</lang> antecedent this is surely a <acr>Sktization</acr>), usually {%regret, remorse, worry, mental disturbance, ‘difficulties of conscience’%} (<ls>SBE</ls> 〔13.51〕 for <lang>Pali</lang> kukkucca). This is the usual <ab>mg.</ab> in <lang>Pali</lang>; but sometimes the etymological <ab>mg.</ab>, seemingly {%wickedness, evil deeds%}, must apparently be assumed (as in <ls>Jāt.</ls> 〔i.119.29〕 hattha-kukkuccaṃ vā pādakukkuccaṃ vā). <ab>Cf.</ab> <ls>LaVallée Poussin, trnsl. of AbhidhK.</ls> 〔ii.166〕: ‘<fr>le regret</fr> (kaukṛtya) <fr>… au propre … est la nature de ce qui est méfait</fr> (kukṛtabhāva); <fr>mais on entend par kaukṛtya un mental qui a pour objet</fr> (ālambana) <fr>le</fr> kaukṛtya <fr>au sens propre, à savoir le regret</fr> (vipratisāra) <fr>relatif au méfait … Le</fr> kaukṛtya <fr>au sens propre est le point ďappui, la raison ďêtre du regret; donc le regret est nommé</fr> kaukṛtya’. In <lang>BHS</lang> this is the only certain <ab>mg.</ab> of the word: <ls>Mvy</ls> 〔1358〕; 〔1980〕; 〔5237〕 = <lang>Tib.</lang> <tib>ḥgyod pa</tib>, {%regret, remorse%}, in 〔5237〕 = vipratisāra; similarly <lang>Chin.</lang>; <ls>Prāt</ls> 〔504.9〕 bhikṣūṇāṃ kaukṛtyāya vilekhāya …; 〔518.3〕 bhikṣoḥ saṃcintya kaukṛtyam upasaṃharet, {%shall consciously cause disturbance of conscience%} (but see below) {%to a monk%}; <ls>Mvy</ls> 〔8487〕 kaukṛtyopasaṃhāraḥ, {%the causing of disturbance of conscience%}; <ls>KP</ls> 〔3.6〕 (<ab>vs</ab>) pareṣu kaukṛty' (= °tyam) upasaṃharanti; <ls>SP</ls> 〔285.9, 11〕 kaukṛtyam upasaṃharati; 〔287.2〕 kaukṛtyasthānaṃ (here <lang>Tib.</lang> <tib>the tshom gnas</tib>, {%position of doubt%}, but better {%occasion for mental disturbance%} in another) ca na jātu kuryān, na lapsyase jñānam anuttara(ṃ) tvam; <ls>Mv</ls> 〔iii.48.14〕 °tyam utpādetsuḥ; 〔173.9〕 cauro ahan ti tasya kaukṛtyam utpannaṃ; 〔173.19〕 mā kaukṛtyaṃ janehīti; <ls>Kv</ls> 〔80.5〕 (mā tvaṃ …) kaukṛtyam utpādayasi; <ls>Śikṣ</ls> 〔138.1〕 lajjābhiḥ kaukṛtyasaṃpannaiḥ paralokāvadyabhayadarśibhir; <ls>LV</ls> 〔32.19〕 anupanāho … akaukṛtyāya saṃvartate, {%… leads to freedom from remorse%}; <ls>SP</ls> 〔71.4〕 bhikṣūṇāṃ kaukṛtyavinodanārthaṃ, yathā … niṣkāṅkṣā nirvicikitsā bhaveyuḥ (see below); <ls>Śikṣ</ls> 〔135.16〕 tena niṣkaukṛtyena bhūtvā nirvicikitsakena …; <ls>Bbh</ls> 〔83.14〕 kaukṛtyaprativinodana-paricaryā; 〔137.24〕 niṣkaukṛtyo bhavati; 〔250.20〕 sva-kaukṛtye samutpanne … yā lajjā; one of a list of upakleśa, <ls>Dharmas</ls> 〔69〕, and elsewhere associated with such things as vyāpāda, styāna-middha, auddhatya, vicikitsā, <ls>Bbh</ls> 〔173.1〕; auddhatya-kau°, one of the 5 {@nīvaraṇa@}, <ab>q.v.</ab>; {@paryavasthāna@} (<ab>q.v.</ab>) or {%possession by, fixation in%}, these ‘depravities’ leads to misery and must be avoided, <ls>Bbh</ls> 〔145.10 f.〕; 〔223.14〕; 〔243.22〕; kaukṛtya{@paryutthānam@} (= paryavasthānam) <ls>Śikṣ</ls> 〔178.14〕; similarly, dṛṣṭi-kaukṛtya-pratiṣthitasya <ls>KP</ls> 〔96.4〕, where <lang>Tib.</lang> renders as usual by <tib>ḥgyod</tib>, {%regret, remorse%}, which tends against interpretation of the word in this connection (as an upakleśa) etymologically, as {%state of wickedness%}; <ls>Śikṣ</ls> 〔191.7〕 a-kaukṛtya-tā, immediately followed by a-paryutthāna-tā (<ab>cf.</ab> <ls>Śikṣ</ls> 〔178.14〕 above); <ls>Śikṣ</ls> 〔171.4〕 āpatti-kaukṛtya-sthānaṃ viśodhayituṃ, perhaps {%to wipe away any occasion for remorse due to sin%} (but <ls>Bendall and Rouse</ls> {%state of sin and wickedness%}, taking kaukṛtya etymologically; the <lang>Tib.</lang> is not cited); <ls>Laṅk</ls> 〔139.(13—)14, 15〕 (yasya kasyacid anyasyānantaryakāriṇaḥ) kaukṛtyaṃ, tasya kaukṛtyadṛṣṭivinivartanārthaṃ nikṣiptadhurasya kaukṛtyadṛṣṭyabhāvārtham (<ls>Suzuki</ls> {%wickedness%}; but {%remorse, troubles of mind%} or {%conscience%} would seem preferable); <ls>Sādh</ls> 〔17.11〕 kaukṛtyam ājīvamalaṃ ratiṃ saṃgaṇikāsu ca (here {%wickedness%} seems more likely than in any other passage, but even here the word may mean only something like {%mental perturbation%}; note association with vicikitsā, kāṅkṣā, above; Chinese translations sometimes are said to render kau° by {%doubt%}, <ab>e.g.</ab> <ab>acc.</ab> to <ls>Finot on Prāt</ls> 〔518.3〕; so perhaps understand <ls>SP</ls> 〔71.4〕, above).

; <L>5393<pc>201,1<k1>kzepayati<k2>kzepayati
21649 old {@kṣepayati@}¦, ({@1@}) {%spends, passes%} (time, with <lex>acc.</lex> kālam or some expression of time), is found in <lang>Skt.</lang> (<ls>BR</ls> 〔5.1349〕), and the simple kṣipati is commoner in that sense (ibidem). It is strange that <ls>Senart</ls>, <ls>Mv</ls> 〔i. n. 492〕, <ls>PTSD</ls> on khepeti (<ab>s.v.</ab> khipati), and others have overlooked that fact, regarded the usage as specifically <lang>Pali</lang>-<lang>BHS</lang>, and assumed confusion with kṣi, {%destroy%}. I have, to be sure, found no record of kṣepayati used absolutely in this sense in <lang>Skt.</lang>, as it is in <ls>LV</ls> 〔276.11〕 (<ab>vs</ab>) brahmaśakrabhavane nityaṃ sukhaṃ kṣepituṃ, {%to spend%} (time) {%happily forever in the home of <ab n="Brahman">B.</ab> and <ab n="Śakra">Ś.</ab>%} ({@2@}) {%exhausts, brings to an end, obliterates%}; here influence of kṣi, {%destroy%}, might more reasonably be suspected, yet <lang>Skt.</lang> kṣip is sometimes used in nearly or quite the same sense, <ls>BR</ls> <ab>s.v.</ab> kṣip 7 (〔2.549〕; but as <ls>BR</ls> suspected, <ls>Mbh.</ls> <ed>Calc.</ed> 〔3.1094〕 should be read kṣīyeran, not kṣiperan, see <ab>Crit. ed.</ab> 〔3.30.30〕); it <ab>prob.</ab> is an extension of the meaning {%spend%} (time). So <ls>Divy</ls> 〔367.8〕 (narakavedanīyāni karmāṇi) kṣepayitvā, {%having spent (exhausted) their deeds that had to be suffered-for in hells%}, which may illustrate the transition from {%spend%} (time) to {%exhaust%}; the change is complete in <ls>LV</ls> 〔237.13〕 (<ab>vs</ab>) saptarātra bhaṇamānu … sā viyūha na pi śakya kṣepituṃ, {%<acr>tho</acr> described for a week, this splendor could not be exhausted (‘spent’)%}. But it is doubtful whether any of these uses are strictly non-<lang>Skt.</lang>
;
21649 new {@kṣepayati@}¦, ({@1@}) {%spends, passes%} (time, with <lex>acc.</lex> kālam or some expression of time), is found in <lang>Skt.</lang> (<ls>BR</ls> 〔5.1349〕), and the simple kṣipati is commoner in that sense (ibidem). It is strange that <ls>Senart</ls>, <ls>Mv</ls> 〔i. n. 492〕, <ls>PTSD</ls> on khepeti (<ab>s.v.</ab> khipati), and others have overlooked that fact, regarded the usage as specifically <lang>Pali</lang>-<lang>BHS</lang>, and assumed confusion with kṣi, {%destroy%}. I have, to be sure, found no record of kṣepayati used absolutely in this sense in <lang>Skt.</lang>, as it is in <ls>LV</ls> 〔276.11〕 (<ab>vs</ab>) brahmaśakrabhavane nityaṃ sukhaṃ kṣepituṃ, {%to spend%} (time) {%happily forever in the home of <ab n="Brahman">B.</ab> and <ab n="Śakra">Ś.</ab>%} ({@2@}) {%exhausts, brings to an end, obliterates%}; here influence of kṣi, {%destroy%}, might more reasonably be suspected, yet <lang>Skt.</lang> kṣip is sometimes used in nearly or quite the same sense, <ls>BR</ls> <ab>s.v.</ab> kṣip 7 (〔2.549〕; but as <ls>BR</ls> suspected, <ls>Mbh.</ls> <ed>Calc.</ed> 〔3.1094〕 should be read kṣīyeran, not kṣiperan, see <ab>Crit. ed.</ab> 〔3.30.30〕); it <ab>prob.</ab> is an extension of the meaning {%spend%} (time). So <ls>Divy</ls> 〔367.8〕 (narakavedanīyāni karmāṇi) kṣepayitvā, {%having spent (exhausted) their deeds that had to be suffered-for in hells%}, which may illustrate the transition from {%spend%} (time) to {%exhaust%}; the change is complete in <ls>LV</ls> 〔237.13〕 (<ab>vs</ab>) saptarātra bhaṇamānu … sā viyūha na pi śakya kṣepituṃ, {%<ab>tho</ab> described for a week, this splendor could not be exhausted (‘spent’)%}. But it is doubtful whether any of these uses are strictly non-<lang>Skt.</lang>

; <L>5854<pc>216,1<k1>gotra<k2>gotra
23497 old {@gotra@}¦, <lex>m.</lex> and <lex>nt.</lex> (in <lang>Skt.</lang> only <lex>nt.</lex>, and not in these <ab>mgs.</ab>; <lang>Pali</lang> <ab>Dictt.</ab> also fail to record these <ab>mgs.</ab> except in <ab>cpd.</ab> {@gotrabhū@}, <ab>q.v.</ab>; but <lang>Pali</lang> gotta seems clearly used in <ab>mg.</ab> 1, below, in <ls>Vism.</ls> 〔i.138.4—5〕, in definition of gotrabhū: tam parittagottābhibhavanato mahaggatagottabhāvanato ca gotrabhū ti pi vuccati; note how <lang>Pali</lang> here associates the <acr>Sktized</acr> gotra-bhū with the <lang>MIndic</lang> gotta! contrast <ls>Léviʼs note</ls> on <ls>Sūtrāl.</ls> 〔iii.1〕), ({@1@}) <ab>lit.</ab> {%family%}, but in special technical sense of {%religious group%} or {%communion%}: pañcagotrāḥ <ls>Mvy</ls> 〔1260〕, listed 〔1261—5〕 śrāvaka-yānābhisamayagotraḥ, pratyekabuddha-yānā°, tathāgata-yānā°, aniyatagotraḥ, a-gotraḥ; same five, with -gotraṃ, <lex>nt.</lex>, <ls>Laṅk</ls> 〔63.2—5〕 (pañcābhisamaya-gotrāṇi); for the fourth, aniyataikatara-gotram, 〔63.4〕; in the sequel <ls>Laṅk</ls> explains at length the first three; aniyata-, {%<fr>le gotra qui nʼest pas définitif</fr>%}, <ls>Lévi, Sūtrāl.</ls> 〔iii.1, note〕, is briefly treated in <ls>Laṅk</ls> 〔65.2 f.〕, aniyata-gotrakaḥ punar … triṣv apy eteṣu deśyamāneṣu yatrānunīyate tatrānuyojyaḥ syāt; apparently this is the class of people who may be drawn to whichever of the three yānas happens to be presented. The a-gotra is not explained but evidently means people outside of any Buddhist communion; in this sense understand gotrāgotraṃ kathaṃ <ls>Laṅk</ls> 〔25.2〕, (religious) {%family and lack of it%} (dvandva <ab>cpd.</ab>). Only the first three gotras are listed <ls>AbhidhK. LaV-P.</ls> 〔vi.175〕; similarly <ls>Bbh</ls> 〔223.5—6〕 contrasts śrāvaka-pratyekabuddha-gotrāṃ (<lex>acc.</lex> <ab>pl.</ab>) with tathāgata-gotrān. In <ls>KP</ls> 〔102.9〕; 〔103.1, 8〕 āryāṇāṃ gotraṃ is described as a state in which all normal conditions and activities are at an end, and in 〔104.1—2〕 (continuation of the same) it is said, anulomaṃ tad gotraṃ nirvāṇasya. The relation of this to the three or five gotras is not quite clear. In the question, kena pravartitā gotrāḥ suvarṇamaṇimuktajāḥ <ls>Laṅk</ls> 〔26.3〕, gotra is <ab>prob.</ab> used in this same sense, but the <lex>adj.</lex>, {%sprung from gold, gems, and pearls%}, is obscure in application; one is tempted to see an allusion (metaphorically) to the next <ab>mg.</ab>, <ab>cf.</ab> especially suvarṇagotra-vat <ls>Sūtrāl.</ls> 〔iii.9〕 and suratna-gotra-vat 10, with <ls>Léviʼs note</ls>; but {%producing gold%} <ab>etc.</ab>, which one would expect, seems philologically impossible; ({@2@}) {%mine%}, of gems or ores: <ls>Sūtrāl.</ls> 〔iii.9, 10〕, above; sarvaratnasaṃbhavotpattigotrākaramūlyajñāneṣu <ls>Gv</ls> 〔451.2〕; dhātu-gotrāṇi, {%mines of ores%} (metals), °ṇi yaṃ paktvā suvarṇa-rūpya-vaiḍūryāṇy (°vaid°) abhinivartante <ls>Divy</ls> 〔111.20〕, and (°ūrya-sphaṭikāny°) 〔111.28—29, 112.12—13〕; catvāro dhātu-gotrāḥ pradarśitāḥ <ls>MSV</ls> 〔i.106.16〕; ({@3@}) like <lang>Skt.</lang> ākara, also {%origin%}: nikāyagati-gotrā ye <ls>Laṅk</ls> 〔292.16〕, paraphrasing nikāyagati saṃbhavāt (labhyante) 〔292.13〕; {%basis, source, cause, seed%} <ls>Bbh</ls> 〔2.25〕 punar etad gotram ādhāra ity ucyate, upastambho hetur niśraya upaniṣat pūrvaṃgamo nilaya ity ucyate … (〔3.1〕 gotraṃ dvividhaṃ, prakṛtisthaṃ samudānītaṃ ca, {%natural and acquired …%}); 〔3.6 f.〕 tat punar gotraṃ bījam ity apy ucyate, dhātuḥ prakṛtir ity api (<ab>cf.</ab> gotra = bīja, hetu, <ls>AbhidhK. LaV-P.</ls> 〔vii.49〕); ({@4@}) <ab>prob.</ab> as special development of <ab>prec.</ab>, {%kind, class, category%} (like <lang>Skt.</lang> jāti, of similar origin and <ab>lit.</ab> <ab>mg.</ab>): nānāratna-gotra-puṣpapratimaṇḍite <ls>Laṅk</ls> 〔1.7〕, {%adorned with flowers%} (made of) {%various kinds of jewels%}; so <ab>prob.</ab> vijñapti-gotra-saṃchannam <ls>Laṅk</ls> 〔269.12〕, {%covered by%} (various) {%classes of relative%} (worldly, practical) {%knowledge%} (see {@vijñapti@}).

23497 new {@gotra@}¦, <lex>m.</lex> and <lex>nt.</lex> (in <lang>Skt.</lang> only <lex>nt.</lex>, and not in these <ab>mgs.</ab>; <lang>Pali</lang> <ab>Dictt.</ab> also fail to record these <ab>mgs.</ab> except in <ab>cpd.</ab> {@gotrabhū@}, <ab>q.v.</ab>; but <lang>Pali</lang> gotta seems clearly used in <ab>mg.</ab> 1, below, in <ls>Vism.</ls> 〔i.138.4—5〕, in definition of gotrabhū: tam parittagottābhibhavanato mahaggatagottabhāvanato ca gotrabhū ti pi vuccati; note how <lang>Pali</lang> here associates the <ab>Sktized</ab> gotra-bhū with the <lang>MIndic</lang> gotta! contrast <ls>Léviʼs note</ls> on <ls>Sūtrāl.</ls> 〔iii.1〕), ({@1@}) <ab>lit.</ab> {%family%}, but in special technical sense of {%religious group%} or {%communion%}: pañcagotrāḥ <ls>Mvy</ls> 〔1260〕, listed 〔1261—5〕 śrāvaka-yānābhisamayagotraḥ, pratyekabuddha-yānā°, tathāgata-yānā°, aniyatagotraḥ, a-gotraḥ; same five, with -gotraṃ, <lex>nt.</lex>, <ls>Laṅk</ls> 〔63.2—5〕 (pañcābhisamaya-gotrāṇi); for the fourth, aniyataikatara-gotram, 〔63.4〕; in the sequel <ls>Laṅk</ls> explains at length the first three; aniyata-, {%<fr>le gotra qui nʼest pas définitif</fr>%}, <ls>Lévi, Sūtrāl.</ls> 〔iii.1, note〕, is briefly treated in <ls>Laṅk</ls> 〔65.2 f.〕, aniyata-gotrakaḥ punar … triṣv apy eteṣu deśyamāneṣu yatrānunīyate tatrānuyojyaḥ syāt; apparently this is the class of people who may be drawn to whichever of the three yānas happens to be presented. The a-gotra is not explained but evidently means people outside of any Buddhist communion; in this sense understand gotrāgotraṃ kathaṃ <ls>Laṅk</ls> 〔25.2〕, (religious) {%family and lack of it%} (dvandva <ab>cpd.</ab>). Only the first three gotras are listed <ls>AbhidhK. LaV-P.</ls> 〔vi.175〕; similarly <ls>Bbh</ls> 〔223.5—6〕 contrasts śrāvaka-pratyekabuddha-gotrāṃ (<lex>acc.</lex> <ab>pl.</ab>) with tathāgata-gotrān. In <ls>KP</ls> 〔102.9〕; 〔103.1, 8〕 āryāṇāṃ gotraṃ is described as a state in which all normal conditions and activities are at an end, and in 〔104.1—2〕 (continuation of the same) it is said, anulomaṃ tad gotraṃ nirvāṇasya. 23801 old {@grahaṇa@}¦, <lex>nt.</lex>, confused with {@gahana@}, {%thicket, entanglement%} (?): in <ls>Mv</ls> 〔i.34.7〕 (prose) -durga-saṃsāra-kāntāragrahaṇa-dāruṇāto mahā-prapātāto uddharitvā, <ls>Senart</ls> thinks that grahaṇa is a copyistʼs hyper-<lang>Skt.</lang> alteration of gahana, which is a near-synonym of kāntāra (<ab>esp.</ab> in <lang>Pali</lang>, where diṭṭhi-kantāra and diṭṭhi-gahana are often closely associated); in spite of this, I think grahaṇa may be sound and <ab>orig.</ab>: {%rescuing from a great abyss that is dreadful because of the grip of the forest of the saṃsāra <ab>etc.</ab>%} In <ls>Mv</ls> 〔i.91.14—17〕 occur four lines of verse in which the <ab>mss.</ab> repeatedly vary between gahana and grahaṇa; the text is both very corrupt and fragmentary; <ls>Senartʼs note</ls> is a very earnest effort to disentangle it, but I find it hardly convincing, <acr>tho</acr> I am inclined to agree that puns are here contained, involving gahana, {%entanglement, obstruction, difficulty%}, as well as {%thicket%}, and grahaṇa, {%seizure, imprisonment%} (perhaps also {%eclipse%}, as by Rāhu, so <lang>Skt.</lang>); the text, with the most important <ab>vv.ll.</ab>, reads: 14 vanagahanaṃ (<ab>mss.</ab> °grahanaṃ or °ṇaṃ) balagahanaṃ (3 <ab>mss.</ab> °grah°) girigahanāni (<ab>em.</ab>; 5 <ab>mss.</ab> °gahanaṃ, one °grahaṇaṃ) tyāgagrahaṇāni (3 <ab>mss.</ab> °gahanāni), 15 viṣamāprati- (<ab>mss.</ab> viṣamapati-)-saṃniṣaṇṇavanāni tu manuṣyagahanāni (5 <ab>mss.</ab> °graha°), 16 tṛṇagulmakaṇṭakalatākulāni vṛkṣagrahaṇā- (<ab>mss.</ab> °grahaṇya- or °nya-)gahanāni (3 <ab>mss.</ab> grahaṇāni), 17 śaṭhanikṛtipaiśunyāni tu manuṣyagahanāni (5 <ab>mss.</ab> °grahanāni or °ṇāni). Tho <ls>Senart</ls>ʼs interpretation seems very dubious, I cannot suggest with confidence any improvements. The meter is meant for āryā. See also {@gahana, gahana-tā@}.

24169 new {@caṅkrama@}¦, <lex>m.</lex> and (less regularly) <lex>nt.</lex> (= <lang>Pali</lang> caṅkama; to {@caṅkramati@}), ({@1@}) {%act of walking%}, in purely physical sense: vivṛtaḥ śobhate ārya āsana-sthāna-caṅkrame <ls>LV</ls> 〔157.15〕 (<ab>vs</ab>), {%when uncovered%} (unveiled), {%a noble person shines%} (is distinguished) {%in sitting, standing, and walking%}; these are three of the (usually four) modes of physical behavior (the fourth being lying down), see <ab>s.v.</ab> {@īryāpatha@} 4; <ls>AsP</ls> 〔520.13〕; <ls>RP</ls> 〔45.18〕; cognate <lex>acc.</lex> °maṃ caṅkramyate or °mati, see (4) below; ({@2@}) {%walking, wandering%}, as an occupation or mode of life: in <ls>Karmav</ls> 〔104.14〕 one of the daśa guṇāḥ paiṇḍapātikatve, {%ten advantages in the mendicantʼs life%}, is, caṅkramo 'sya upārjito bhavati, {%he has acquired%} (a life of) {%walking, wandering about%}; ({@3@}) {%place of walking, promenade%} (in the sense of {%ground where walking is done%}): of walks in groves or parks (secular), ekaikaṃ caṅkrama-varaṃ … kalpayatha <ls>Mv</ls> 〔ii.18.16〕 (<ab>vs</ab>), Śuddhodana says, {%adorn%} (or with <ab>mss.</ab> kalpayama, {%let us adorn%}) {%every excellent promenade%} (in the Lumbinī grove, in preparation for Māyāʼs visit); ; <L>6142<pc>225,2<k1>cari<k2>cari
24653 old {@cari@}, or {@carī@}¦ (ī chiefly or wholly <ab>m.c.</ab>), <lex>f.</lex> (not recorded in <lang>MIndic</lang>; = <lang>Skt.</lang> {@caryā@}, <lang>Pali</lang> {@cariyā@}, both also in <lang>BHS</lang>, see <ab>s.vv.</ab>; <ab>cf.</ab> 〔§ 3.115〕), {%course of conduct, regular system of action%} (<ab>esp.</ab> {%religious%}); particularly with reference to the {%programmatic course%} of a Bodhisattva, leading to enlightenment; (on its four aspects or stages see <ab>s.v.</ab> {@caryā@};) these forms chiefly, but not exclusively, in verse; see also {@cāri, cārikā@}; in prose the usual expression is (Bodhisattva-)caryā, <ab>e.g.</ab> <ls>SP</ls> 〔7.1〕; 〔65.5〕; <ls>LV</ls> 〔90.10〕; <ls>Gv</ls> 〔58.9〕; but even in prose note (bo)dhisattva-cari-niṣpanda- <ls>LV</ls> 〔5.1〕 (all <ab>mss.</ab>, only <ed>Calc.</ed> °carita°), and <ab>cf.</ab> Bhadracari-vidhipūrvakaṃ <ls>Śikṣ</ls> 〔139.13〕 (prose; the bhadra-cari is the bodhisattva-cari; the work of this name is elsewhere called Bhadra-caryā in the prose of <ls>Śikṣ</ls>, 〔290.8〕; 〔291.9〕; 〔297.1〕); in <ls>Bhad</ls> itself the form is Bhadracari wherever meter does not require ī, as in the <ab>cpd.</ab> °cari-praṇidhāna 2, 49, 54, 61, where in the seam of the <ab>cpd.</ab> the consonant cluster makes the preceding syllable long; <ab>cf.</ab> also the <lex>acc.</lex> <ab>sg.</ab> °cariṃ (not °carīṃ) 17, 22, 26, 51, 62; <ls>Watanabe</ls> wrongly regards the title as primarily °carī. (All remaining citations in this article are from verses.) caryā may be used even in <ab>vss</ab>, where meter is indifferent (so <ls>SP</ls> 〔67.13〕) or requires long first syllable (<ls>SP</ls> 〔68.6〕), <acr>tho</acr> in the latter case {@cāri (°ī)@} and {@cārikā@}, <ab>qq.v.</ab>, are also found; nearly all the cases here cited refer to the {%religious course%} leading to enlightenment, to Buddhahood or Bodhisattvahood, but occasionally the term is applied to any or all human courses of action, including such as are disapproved; iya bāla-carī, {%this foolish%} (or {%childish%}) {%course%} <ls>LV</ls> 〔174.9, 11〕 (<ab>vs</ab>); jāniya te cariṃ ca <ls>SP</ls> 〔45.3〕, {%knowing them%} (all the creatures of the world) {%and their%} (various) {%course%}(s) {%of action%}; cariṃcariṃ jāniya nityakālaṃ vadāmi sattvāna tathā-tathāhaṃ <ls>SP</ls> 〔326.11〕, {%knowing the various modes of conduct%} (of beings) {%always, I speak to creatures in this or that way%} (<ls>Kashgar rec.</ls>, <ls>Thomas ap. Hoernle MR</ls> 〔133.1〕, cari acari, metrically impossible, and uninterpretable; Thomas {%the moving and not-moving%} [of living beings], which seems unacceptable); jagataḥ prajānase yā carir yatha ca karmasaṃbhavaḥ <ls>RP</ls> 〔6.1〕; otherwise, referring to the {%course%} of Bodhisattvas, also called the {%true%} (bhūta), {%subtle%} (sūkṣma), {%pure%} (viśuddha), {%supreme%} (uttama) {%course, the course of%} (leading to) {%enlightenment%} (bodhi-), {%of morality%} (śīla-), or other similar epithets; also duṣkara-, referring to Śākyamuniʼs temporary experiment with severe austerities; often {%former, ancient%} (pūrva, {@purima@}) with allusion to the length of it <acr>thru</acr> many past births; frequently a form of the cognate verb car (also ā-car) is used with it: sūkṣmāṃ cariṃ <ls>SP</ls> 〔12.7〕; te (<ab>sc.</ab> of the Buddha) ātmana yādṛśī carī 〔63.13〕; bhūtāṃ cariṃ 〔64.2〕 (but in adjoining prose, 〔64.13, 65.5〕, caryā); 〔127.10〕; 〔193.6〕; yathā carī mahya sutena cīrṇa 〔203.4〕; smara cari purimāṃ <ls>LV</ls> 〔161.21〕; yām evā varacari (<lex>acc.</lex>) caritas tvaṃ tām evā cari vibhaja jagasya 〔164.16〕; purimāṃ praṇidhāna-carīṃ 〔175.14〕; tāṃ pūrvacarīm [Page226-a] anusmarā 〔178.5〕; pūrvacariṃ carantaḥ 〔219.13〕; ṣaḍvarṣāṇi caritva duṣkaracariṃ 〔276.1〕; bodhicari sarva (<ab>n. sg.</ab>) 〔341.2〕; svacarī viśuddhacari pāragatā 〔360.3〕; nigadottamāṃ cariṃ <ls>RP</ls> 〔9.6〕; uttamacariṃ prakāśaya 〔9.14〕; cari buddhasutānāṃ <ls>Śikṣ</ls> 〔2.16〕; cariṣyāmy amitāṃ cariṃ 〔13.19〕; cari (<lex>acc.</lex>) samanta-bhadrāṃ <ls>Gv</ls> 〔57.17—18〕; purimacariṃ pariśuddha ācaritvā <ls>Sukh</ls> 〔23.14〕; śīlacariṃ <ls>Bhad</ls> 〔17〕; bodhicariṃ 〔22, 26, 28〕.

; <L>6213<pc>228,1<k1>cArika<k2>-cArika
24937 old {@-cārika@}¦, <lex>adj.</lex> or <lex>subst.</lex> <lex>m.</lex> (= <lang>Skt.</lang> and <lang>Pali</lang> -cārin, <ab>ifc.</ab>; see also {@piṇḍa-cārika@}), {%moving; practising%}: pattracārikā ṛddhyā harita-cārikā bhājana-cārikāś cāgatāḥ <ls>Divy</ls> 〔45.17〕; similarly 〔45.20〕; it seems clear that the reference [Page228-b] is to persons who magically {%ride%} or {%move%} <acr>thru</acr> the air on {%leaves%}, some sort of {%plants%} or {%trees%} (harita, <ab>cf.</ab> <lang>Skt.</lang> haritaka), and {%jars%} (bhājana), <ab>cf.</ab> 〔45.27—30〕. <ab>Acc.</ab> to <ls>Burnouf, Introd.</ls> 〔261 note 2〕, <lang>Tib.</lang> renders -cārikā(ḥ) by <tib>ḥdri ma</tib>, which the <ab>Dictt.</ab> of <lang>Tib.</lang> do not interpret satisfactorily; I suggest <tib>dri bo</tib>, {%magician%}. <lang>Tib.</lang> renders harita by <tib>śiṅ tshe</tib>, apparently some tree or shrub. There is a <ab>v.l.</ab> -vārika, which <ls>pw</ls> 〔7.365〕 adopts for bhājana-cārika, identifying it with °vārika in <ls>Mvy</ls> 〔9069〕, which however means something like {%superintendent of vessels%} and cannot be intended in the <ls>Divy</ls> passage. In <ls>Śikṣ</ls> 〔332.4〕 cārika seems to mean {%practiser, follower%} (<ab>cf.</ab> <lang>Skt.</lang> and <lang>Pali</lang> cārin), <ab>sc.</ab> of a heretical religion.
;

; <L>6287<pc>230,2<k1>citrIkaroti<k2>citrI-karoti
25233 old {@citrī-karoti@}¦ (= <lang>Pali</lang> citti°, perhaps also cittī°, see next; derived by <ls>Childers</ls> and <ls>PTSD</ls> from <lang>Skt.</lang> citta-; <ls>Senart</ls>, <ls>Mv</ls> 〔i.444〕, accepts this and regards <lang>BHS</lang> citrī° as false <acr>Sktization</acr>; later, he emends the forms occurring in <ls>Mv</ls> 〔ii and iii〕 to cittī°; whatever the history of the word may be, the <lang>BHS</lang> form is only citrī° or citri°); ({@1@}) <lex>ppp.</lex> {%respected, honored%}: (vayaṃ hi …) loke 'tīva citrīkṛtāḥ <ls>SP</ls> 〔215.6〕 (prose, no <ab>v.l.</ab>); ({@2@}) {%pays heed%}: na °kariṣyati <ls>MSV</ls> 〔i.8.1, 10〕, {%he will pay no heed%}; <lex>caus.</lex>, {%causes to pay heed, gets the attention of%} (<lex>acc.</lex>): (Māra tried to distract the Bodhisattva,) na ca taṃ bodhisattvaṃ citrīkāresi (<lex>aor.</lex>; so <ab>mss.</ab>, <ls>Senart</ls> <ab>em.</ab> cittī°) <ls>Mv</ls> 〔ii.268.11〕; with non-<lex>caus.</lex> <ab>mg.</ab>, and °kar° with short a in <ab>mss.</ab> except in the first passage, <ls>Mv</ls> 〔iii.282.6, 12〕; 〔283.2, 7〕, <ab>prob.</ab> read in all approximately: na ca sānaṃ bhagavāṃ citrīkāraye (or °karaye), {%and the Lord paid no heed to them%} (the daughters of Māra who were seeking to distract him); the <ab>mss.</ab> are variously corrupt; <ls>Senart</ls> <ab>em.</ab> cittīkāraye; ({@3@}) citrīkṛta in a quite different sense: hastau saṃpuṭākārau kṛtvā anyonyāv āveṣṭya citrīkṛtau ātmorasi sthāpayet (in a certain mudrā) <ls>Mmk</ls> 〔400.28〕; similarly, hastāv udveṣṭya citrīkṛtāv abhayāvasthitau 〔401.20〕; hastāv ubhayāṅguṣṭhavinyastau citrīkṛtau lalāṭe darśayed 〔401.25〕; punaḥ citrīkṛtau karau, svastikaṃ … bandhitavyam 〔407.21〕. It is clear that citrīkṛtau here applies always to the two hands in various mudrā-positions, but the <ab>mg.</ab> is not evident to me; possibly {%made elaborate%}, by intertwining the fingers (which is apparently characteristic of these mudrās)?
;

; <L>6339<pc>232,2<k1>cetaHparyAya<k2>cetaHparyAya
25441 old {@cetaḥparyāya@}¦, <lex>m.</lex>, {%way of thought, manner of mind%}; less often citta-pa°; commonly preceded by para- or parasya, {%of others%}; knowledge of {%otherʼs mental make-up%} is one of the {@abhijñā@}, <ab>q.v.</ab>; so also in <lang>Pali</lang>, where Buddha is parassa (para-)ceto-(citta-)-pariyāya-kusala (-kovida), as one of the abhiññā. In <ls>Bhīk</ls> 〔27a.5〕 cetaḥparyāyasya is not preceded by para- or equivalent, but the meaning is certainly the same, since other abhijñā precede and follow it (divyasya śrotrasya, pūrvanivāsasya). In <ls>Mv</ls> 〔iii.321.13〕 Buddhas are called cetaḥparyāyasaṃpannāḥ, probably also with implication of para-, <acr>tho</acr> here most of the other abhijñā are not listed; but the next following epithet is ṛddhiprātihāryasaṃpannā(ḥ), which recalls one of them.
;

; <L>6342<pc>232,2<k1>cetayati<k2>cetayati<h>2
25453 old <hom>2</hom> {@cetayati@}¦ (the verb on which is based <lang>Pali</lang> <lex>caus.</lex> cetāpeti, below), {%buys%}: cetayitvā, <lex>ger.</lex>, <ls>Prāt</ls> 〔492.13〕; 〔493.2, 4, 9〕 <ab>etc.</ab>, see {@cetanaka@}. In <ls>Lang.</ls> 〔22.98〕 it was stated that the subject of <lang>Pali</lang> cetāpeti, {%causes to be bought, has bought%}, ‘is always a monk or nun, who instigates (a layman) to buy (something for himself or herself).’ This is true only in <ls>Vin.</ls> 〔iv.250.14—15〕; in <ls>Vin.</ls> 〔iii.216.13〕 and 〔237.10〕 the subject is a layman, <acr>tho</acr> the <ab>mg.</ab> is certainly {%causes to be bought, has bought%} (for the benefit of a monk). <ls>Vin.</ls> 〔iii.216.13〕 is the same passage as <ls>Prāt</ls> 〔492.13〕 (see {@cetanaka@}) where cetayitvā, {%having bought%}, replaces <lang>Pali</lang> cetāpetvā, {%having had%} (ordered) {%bought%} (for a monk). The non-<lex>caus.</lex> form of <ls>Prāt</ls> proves the meaning of the <lex>caus.</lex> <lang>Pali</lang> form, which <lang>Pali</lang> interpreters have not understood. The former is not recorded in <lang>Pali</lang>, nor the latter in <lang>BHS</lang>. The etymology is unknown but the <ab>mg.</ab> is clear from the contexts.
;
25453 new <hom>2</hom> {@cetayati@}¦ (the verb on which is based <lang>Pali</lang> <lex>caus.</lex> cetāpeti, below), {%buys%}: cetayitvā, <lex>ger.</lex>, <ls>Prāt</ls> 〔492.13〕; 〔493.2, 4, 9〕 <ab>etc.</ab>, see {@cetanaka@}. In <ls>Lang.</ls> 〔22.98〕 it was stated that the subject of <lang>Pali</lang> cetāpeti, {%causes to be bought, has bought%}, ‘is always a monk or nun, who instigates (a layman) to buy (something for himself or herself).’ This is true only in <ls>Vin.</ls> 〔iv.250.14—15〕; in <ls>Vin.</ls> 〔iii.216.13〕 and 〔237.10〕 the subject is a layman, <ab>tho</ab> the <ab>mg.</ab> is certainly {%causes to be bought, has bought%} (for the benefit of a monk). <ls>Vin.</ls> 〔iii.216.13〕 is the same passage as <ls>Prāt</ls> 〔492.13〕 (see {@cetanaka@}) where cetayitvā, {%having bought%}, replaces <lang>Pali</lang> cetāpetvā, {%having had%} (ordered) {%bought%} (for a monk). The non-<lex>caus.</lex> form of <ls>Prāt</ls> proves the meaning of the <lex>caus.</lex> <lang>Pali</lang> form, which <lang>Pali</lang> interpreters have not understood. The former is not recorded in <lang>Pali</lang>, nor the latter in <lang>BHS</lang>. The etymology is unknown but the <ab>mg.</ab> is clear from the contexts.
