As a measure of length or <ab>esp.</ab> height, {@tāla@}, {%palm-tree%}, occurs also in <lang>Skt.</lang> (<ls>BR</ls>), and much oftener in <lang>BHS</lang>, where previous translators often erroneously render {%span%}, <ab>esp.</ab> in the <ab>cpd.</ab> sapta-tāla; but this (= <lang>Pali</lang> satta-tāla) means, as in <lang>Pali</lang>, {%seven palm-trees%}, and so tāla regularly (confirmed by <lang>Tib.</lang>, regularly <tib>śiṅ ta la</tib>, {%tāla-tree%}). <ab>Acc.</ab> to <ls>Mv</ls> 〔ii.313.3 ff.〕 a tāla is one-eighth of a krośa, and eight times a {@pauruṣeya@} 3, <ab>q.v.</ab> In <ls>LV</ls> 〔14.11〕 the cakra-ratna of the cakravartin is saptatālam uccaiḥ; in <ls>LV</ls> 〔154.5〕 a metal figure of a boar (ayasmayī varāhapratimā) measures 7 tālas (read saptatālā as one word); in <ls>LV</ls> 〔273.19〕 a vedikā is saptatālān uccaistvena; in <ls>Av</ls> 〔ii.104.4, 14〕 a throne is saptatālodgataṃ; in <ls>SP</ls> 〔428.10〕 kūṭāgāram abhiruhya vaihāyase saptatālamātreṇa, {%having mounted a tower-house seven tālas high in the air%}. Most commonly used as a measure of height to which someone, <ab>esp.</ab> Buddha, magically rises in the air; one tāla only, tālamātraṃ (vaihāyasam …) <ls>Mv</ls> 〔i.239.18〕; 〔iii.107.12, 13〕; 〔108.5〕; 〔411.13, 15〕; oftener sapta-tāla-mātraṃ vaihāyasam abhyudgamya, or variations on this, <ls>SP</ls> 〔459.11〕; 〔465.7〕; <ls>LV</ls> 〔18.16〕 (here a Pratyekabuddha, rising 7 tālas, passes <acr>thru</acr> the ‘fire-element’, tejodhātu, and disappears); 〔350.20—21〕; <ls>Laṅk</ls> 〔16.6〕; <ls>Divy</ls> 〔252.16〕.

28049 old {@tīrthika@}¦ (also {@para-t°@}; see <ab>prec.</ab> and next items; <ab>prob.</ab> <acr>Sktized</acr> from <lang>MIndic</lang> (<lang>Pali</lang>) titthiya, see {@tīrthya@}; both are very common in prose as well as <ab>vss</ab>), ({@1@}) {%heretic%}; like its relatives, pejoratively used; there is one seeming exception, tīrthikā vā bhavanti bhavasūdanāḥ <ls>Mv</ls> 〔i.106.8〕 (<ab>vs</ab>), where if the text is correct it seems to be said of Bodhisattvas in the 8th bhūmi that they {%become religious prophets%} (or the like), {%destroying%} (the states of normal) {%existence%}. ; <L>7706<pc>276,1<k1>Darma<k2>Darma<h>2
30935 old <hom>2</hom> {@dharma@}¦, normally <lex>m.</lex> as in <lang>Skt.</lang>; occasionally (as in <lang>Pali</lang>, see <ls>Childers</ls> <ab>s.v.</ab> dhammo) <lex>nt.</lex>: <ls>SP</ls> 〔70.2〕 (<ab>vs</ab>) <ab>acc.</ab> to <ls>Kashgar rec.</ls> duḥśrāddheyam idaṃ dharmaṃ deśitam adya śāstṛṇām (<ab>ms.</ab>), but <lang>Tib.</lang> seems to support <lang>Nep.</lang> <ab>mss.</ab> which lack dharma; idam … dharmaṃ śrutvā <ls>SP</ls> 〔71.3〕 (prose; <ls>KN</ls> <ab>em.</ab> to imaṃ, which <ls>WT</ls> keep without note); aśrutvaiva … idam … dharmaṃ <ls>SP</ls> 〔60.4〕 (here kept with all <ab>mss.</ab> in both <ab>edd.</ab>); mā … a-dharmaṃ utpadyate <ls>LV</ls> 〔15.10〕 (prose), {%may no wickedness arise%}; idaṃ dharmaṃ <ls>LV</ls> 〔396.1〕 (prose; <lex>acc.</lex> <ab>sg.</ab>); paramaṃ dharmaṃ <ls>Mv</ls> 〔ii.99.5〕 (<ab>n. sg.</ab>; in next sentence dharmo). —({@1@}) {%characteristic, quality%}, substantially as in <lang>Skt.</lang> (<ls>BR</ls> <ab>s.v.</ab> 2), but used in <lang>BHS</lang>, as in <lang>Pali</lang> dhamma, very commonly and in a way which seems specially pointed and deserving of special [Page276-b] mention: asti-dharma, see <ab>s.v.</ab> <hom>1</hom> {@asti@}; vināśa-dharmeṇa ({%subject to destruction, perishable%}) mānsena <ls>Mv</ls> 〔i.94.12〕; divyāś ca kāyāḥ parihāṇa- (<ab>v.l.</ab> °ṇi-)dharmāḥ <ls>SP</ls> 〔162.3〕 (<ab>vs</ab>), {%and divine bodies were characterized by diminution%}, <ab>i.e.</ab> became few (meaning proved by parallel 〔170.2〕; wrongly <ls>Burnouf</ls> and <ls>Kern</ls>); māreṇa … īrṣyādharmaparītena <ls>LV</ls> 〔267.2〕 (prose), {%full of the quality of jealousy%}; catvāra ime … duḥkhavipākā dharmāḥ <ls>RP</ls> 〔19.16〕 (prose), {%qualities that result in misery%}, <ab>i.e.</ab> vices; in <ls>Mv</ls> 〔iii.200.5〕 are mentioned eight āścaryādbhuta dharma, {%marvelous qualities%}, of the Buddha, seven of which (the eighth apparently being omitted by mistake) are listed 〔200.6—202.2〕; they correspond imperfectly to the eight yathābhucca vaṇṇa of <lang>Pali</lang> <ls>DN</ls> 〔ii.222.7〕, listed 〔222.13—224.14〕 (<ls>DN</ls> nos. 2, 4, 5, 6, and 8 = <ls>Mv</ls> nos. 2, 7, 3, 4, 6); śuddhāvāsā ca devā aṣṭādaśa āmodanīyāṃ dharmān ({%the eighteen ‘qualities of rejoicing’%}, here {%conditions of, elements%} or {%matters for rejoicing%}) pratilabhanti <ls>Mv</ls> 〔ii.259.10〕 (they are listed in the sequel); ({@2@}) like <lang>Pali</lang> dhamma, dharma (or dharmāyatana) is the object of manas (as rūpa of cakṣus, <ab>etc.</ab>); sometimes rendered {%idea%}; it seems likely that, at least in origin, it meant {%quality, characteristic%} (= 1), as that element in the outside world which the indriya manas (as distinguished from the five external organs of perception) concerned itself with; see <ls>AbhidhK. LaV-P.</ls> 〔i.45〕, where it is explained that ‘<acr>tho</acr> all the āyatanas are dharmas’ ({%qualities%}), ‘because it includes many and the chief (agra) dharma, one āyatana is specifically so called;’ in any case this exclusively Buddhist use occurs: dharmāyatanam <ls>Mvy</ls> 〔2039〕; <ls>Dharmas</ls> 〔24〕; dharmadhātuḥ <ls>Mvy</ls> 〔2057〕 (after manodhātuḥ, as dharmāyatanam 〔2039〕 follows mana-āy°); manendriyaṃ dharmavicāraṇeṣu <ls>Suv</ls> 〔56.12〕; similarly 〔57.8〕, <ab>etc.</ab>; see also dharmāyatanika, <ab>s.v.</ab> {@āyatanika@}; ({@3@}) in <ls>Laṅk</ls> used in a peculiar sense; pañcadharmāḥ <ls>Laṅk</ls> 〔229.6〕; °rma- <ab>id.</ab> 〔2.2〕; the list of them is given <ab>id.</ab> 〔228.5〕 pañcadharmo (<ab>v.l.</ab> °mā, which seems surely correct), nimittaṃ nāma vikalpas tathatā samyagjñānaṃ ca, which are then defined in the sequel, but I confess I find the definitions hard to understand; <ls>Suzuki, Studies</ls> 〔155 ff.〕, discusses the passage and renders dharma by {%category%}; it seems likely that it started out as a specialized application of <ab>mg.</ab> (1), {%quality%}; ({@4@}) very commonly, as with <lang>Pali</lang> dhamma, {%state of existence, condition of being%}; 33189 old {@nipaka@}¦, ({@1@}) <lex>m.</lex>, {%chief%} (<ab>cf.</ab> Jain <lang>Skt.</lang> nipa, doubtless semi-<lang>Skt.</lang> for <lang>AMg.</lang> ṇiva = <lang>Skt.</lang> nṛpa, <ls>Ind. Stud.</ls> 〔14.386〕): <ls>Divy</ls> 〔447.27〕; 〔451.20〕; ({@2@}) <lex>adj.</lex>, = <lang>Pali</lang> <ab>id.</ab>, in <lang>Pali</lang> tradition <ab>app.</ab> always interpreted as {%wise, prudent%}, and so nepakka, {%wisdom, prudence%}; occurs in <ls>Ud</ls> several times, mostly in <ab>vss</ab> which also occur in <lang>Pali</lang> with the same word, <ab>viz.</ab> 〔vi.8〕; 〔xii.18〕; 〔xiv.13, 14〕; 〔xv.6〕 (here text nṛpaka, not corrected in <ab>ed.</ab>; if genuine, could only be hyper-<acr>Sktism</acr>; the <lang>Pali</lang> <ab>vs</ab>, <ls>It.</ls> 〔47.3〕, has nipako); in all these occurrences {%zealous%} (see 3 below) would make quite as good sense; ({@3@}) in phrase nipakasyāṅgasaṃbhāraiḥ <ls>Mvy</ls> 〔7023〕 and <ls>Bbh</ls> 〔145.23〕, {%with the collection of parts of the nipaka%} (man)? <ab>Acc.</ab> to <lang>Tib.</lang> on <ls>Mvy</ls>, <tib>ḥgru skyaṅ</tib>, {%zealously attending (?), zealous%}, and so <lang>Chin.</lang> on <ls>Mvy</ls> appears to take nipaka; <ls>Wogiharaʼs Index to Bbh</ls> renders it by two <lang>Chin.</lang> characters which may mean {%constantly self-possessed%} (possibly associating the word with <lang>Pali</lang> niya, niyaka, = <lang>Skt.</lang> nija, {%own?%}). It would be possible to identify this occurrence of the word with <ab>mg.</ab> 2; it might mean {%prudent, wise%}, here; or contrariwise the occurrences under 2 might mean {%zealous%}. Further complication is caused by {@niyaka@}, which <lang>Tib.</lang> seems to interpret as the same as nipaka, suggesting graphic confusion; this is proposed in the <ls>Index to Mvy</ls> and in <ls>pw</ls> 〔7.352〕, where niyaka is assumed to stand for nipaka and the <ab>mg.</ab> {%wise%} is given for both <ls>Mvy</ls> passages, but doubtfully for the one here under discussion.

33189 new {@nipaka@}¦, ({@1@}) <lex>m.</lex>, {%chief%} (<ab>cf.</ab> Jain <lang>Skt.</lang> nipa, doubtless semi-<lang>Skt.</lang> for <lang>AMg.</lang> ṇiva = <lang>Skt.</lang> nṛpa, <ls>Ind. Stud.</ls> 〔14.386〕): <ls>Divy</ls> 〔447.27〕; 〔451.20〕; ({@2@}) <lex>adj.</lex>, = <lang>Pali</lang> <ab>id.</ab>, in <lang>Pali</lang> tradition <ab>app.</ab> always interpreted as {%wise, prudent%}, and so nepakka, {%wisdom, prudence%}; occurs in <ls>Ud</ls> several times, mostly in <ab>vss</ab> which also occur in <lang>Pali</lang> with the same word, <ab>viz.</ab> 〔vi.8〕; 〔xii.18〕; 〔xiv.13, 14〕; 〔xv.6〕 (here text nṛpaka, not corrected in <ab>ed.</ab>; if genuine, could only be hyper-<ab>Sktism</ab>; the <lang>Pali</lang> <ab>vs</ab>, <ls>It.</ls> 〔47.3〕, has nipako); in all these occurrences {%zealous%} (see 3 below) would make quite as good sense; ({@3@}) in phrase nipakasyāṅgasaṃbhāraiḥ <ls>Mvy</ls> 〔7023〕 and <ls>Bbh</ls> 〔145.23〕, {%with the collection of parts of the nipaka%} (man)? <ab>Acc.</ab> to <lang>Tib.</lang> on <ls>Mvy</ls>, <tib>ḥgru skyaṅ</tib>, {%zealously attending (?), zealous%}, and so <lang>Chin.</lang> on <ls>Mvy</ls> appears to take nipaka; <ls>Wogiharaʼs Index to Bbh</ls> renders it by two <lang>Chin.</lang> characters which may mean {%constantly self-possessed%} (possibly associating the word with <lang>Pali</lang> niya, niyaka, = <lang>Skt.</lang> nija, {%own?%}). It would be possible to identify this occurrence of the word with <ab>mg.</ab> 2; it might mean {%prudent, wise%}, here; or contrariwise the occurrences under 2 might mean {%zealous%}. Further complication is caused by {@niyaka@}, which <lang>Tib.</lang> seems to interpret as the same as nipaka, suggesting graphic confusion; this is proposed in the <ls>Index to Mvy</ls> and in <ls>pw</ls> 〔7.352〕, where niyaka is assumed to stand for nipaka and the <ab>mg.</ab> {%wise%} is given for both <ls>Mvy</ls> passages, but doubtfully for the one here under discussion.

; <L>9110<pc>328,1<k1>pariBoga<k2>pariBoga
36571 old {@paribhoga@}¦, <lex>m.</lex> (commonly, as in <lang>Skt.</lang> and <lang>Pali</lang>, {%enjoyment, usufruct, use%}, also {%article of enjoyment%}; <ab>e.g.</ab> bodhisattvasya paribhogārtham <ls>LV</ls> 〔95.15〕, °gāya 16), {%property to be enjoyed%}, in <ls>LV</ls> 〔60.18 ff.〕 … ratnavyūhaṃ bodhisattvaparibhogaṃ draṣṭuṃ yo mātuḥ kukṣigatasya bodhisattvasya paribhogo 'bhūt, refers to a physical (<acr>tho</acr> of course magical) structure, described in detail 〔63.1 ff.〕, which houses the Bodhisattva in his motherʼs womb; it had three turrets or apartments, kūṭāgāra, one within the other, and within the third a couch or litter, paryaṅka; it was hard ‘like vajra’ yet soft to the touch (〔64.7—8〕); all the bhavana-vyūha of the kāmāvacara gods appeared in it (〔64.9〕); it always develops or appears in the right side of a Bodhisattvaʼs mother in his last earthly existence (〔65.20〕, here called {@ratnavyūhaḥ@}, <ab>q.v.</ab>, kūṭāgāro); in 〔73.3〕 referred to again, drakṣasi (so text and <ab>app.</ab> all <ab>mss.</ab>) tvam Ānanda ratnavyūhaṃ bodhisattvaparibhogaṃ yatra bodhisattvo mātuḥ kukṣigato vyāhārṣīt. <lang>Tib.</lang> on <ls>LV</ls> 〔60.18〕 renders literally, {%complete enjoyment%}, <tib>yoṅs su spyad pa</tib>, <ab>cf.</ab> <ls>Mvy</ls> 〔7369〕 paribhogaḥ = <lang>Tib.</lang> <tib>yoṅs su spyod</tib>. <ls>SP</ls> 〔337.13〕. kūṭāgāraparibhogeṣu cātra bodhisattvān nivasato drakṣyati, [Page328-b] does not refer to this magical structure in the womb, but to structures occupied by bodhisattvas while attending on the Buddha Śākyamuni.
;

37515 old {@pāṃśulika@}¦, <lex>nt.</lex>, or {@°kā@} (= <lang>AMg.</lang> paṃsuliyā; <ab>cf.</ab> <lang>Pali</lang> phāsulī, °likā; the aspiration in <lang>Pali</lang> ph- is unhistorical), {%rib%}: °likāni °likāntarāṇi <ls>Mv</ls> 〔ii.125.15〕; 〔127.2〕; 〔128.8〕; 〔129.10〕; to be read thus, or else pāṃśulikāntarāṇi (omitting °likāni), {%(ribs and) interstices between the ribs%}; so the <ab>mss.</ab> clearly indicate <acr>tho</acr> with various corruptions; confirmed by <lang>AMg.</lang>; <ls>Senart</ls> <ab>em.</ab> pārśuli°. ; <L>9393<pc>340,1<k1>pAtayantika<k2>pAtayantika
37703 old {@pātayantika@}¦, <lex>adj.</lex>, and {@°kā@}, <lex>subst.</lex> (for alternative <lang>Pali</lang> and <lang>BHS</lang> forms see below), {%causing fall%} (to an evil existence, if not repented and expiated); this is clearly the usual Northern interpretation; one of the three main kinds of monkish transgressions, the others being {@pārājika@} and {@saṃghāvaśeṣa@}, <ab>qq.v.</ab>: as <lex>adj.</lex>, °ka with dharma, (trayāṇāṃ dharmāṇām anyatamānyatamena dharmeṇa vadet pārājikena vā saṃghāvaśeṣeṇa vā) pātayantikena vā <ls>Prāt</ls> 〔489.(1—)3, and ff.〕; there are 30 offenses called {@niḥsargikāḥ@} (<ab>q.v.</ab>) pātayantikā dharmāḥ 〔490.8〕, listed in the following where each is called °gikā °yantikā (<lex>subst.</lex> <lex>fem.</lex>), 〔490.11—12 and ff.〕; they are followed by 90 pātayantikā dharmāḥ 〔502.13〕, each again styled pātayantikā (<lex>subst.</lex> <lex>fem.</lex>) 〔502.15 ff.〕; °tikā dharmāḥ also <ls>Mvy</ls> 〔8417〕 = <lang>Tib.</lang> <tib>ltuṅ byed</tib>, <ab>lit.</ab> {%making fall%}, usually rendered {%transgression%}; the <lang>Pali</lang> correspondents are 30 nissaggiyā pācittiyā dhammā <ls>Vin.</ls> 〔iii.195.1〕, each one styled nissaggiyaṃ pācittiyaṃ (<lex>nt.</lex>, not <lex>f.</lex>) <ab>id.</ab> 18, <ab>etc.</ab>, followed by 92 pācittiyā dhammā, <ls>Vin.</ls> 〔iv.1〕, each one styled pācittiyaṃ 〔2.14 ff.〕 On the various forms of <lang>Pali</lang> and <lang>BHS</lang> see (besides older treatments, now obsolete) <ls>S. Lévi, JA. Nov.—Dec. 1912</ls>, 〔506—8〕, and <ab>esp.</ab> <ls>Waldschmidt, Kl. Skt. Texte 3</ls>. 〔116 f.〕, who says inter alia: In den späteren Turfanfragmenten erscheint ganz allgemein als Sanskritform pātayantikā' (so <ab>e.g.</ab> <ab>op. cit.</ab> 〔41.1〕). He notes that pāteti is used in <lang>Pali</lang> in explaining pācittiya, <ls>Vin.</ls> 〔v.148.30〕, and that pātayati is similarly used in <lang>BHS</lang> in explaining the <ab>mg.</ab> of other (substitute) forms, see below. He states that <lang>Chin.</lang>, like <lang>Tib.</lang> (regularly <tib>ltuṅ byed</tib>, above), supports this <ab>mg.</ab> On the other hand he reports a <lang>BHS</lang> <ab>ms.</ab> reading pāca(tt)i, which reminds one of the <lang>Pali</lang> form; and shows that pātayantika, and other alternative forms, are rendered in ways which suggest association (certainly unhistorical) with root pac-; he cites a passage (〔p. 117〕) reading pātayantikā, pacati dahati uddahati avyutthitasyāvaraṇakṛtyaṃ karoti, tenāha pātayantikā, and compares <ls>Divy</ls> 〔544.10〕 pāyantiketi (text pāpānti°, as also 〔543.24〕; in 〔544.15〕 <ab>mss.</ab> pāyantikām, read thus all three times with <ls>Lévi</ls> <ab>l. c.</ab> above) dahati pacati pātayati (so with <ls>Lévi</ls> for text yāt°). Besides the popular etymology pāpāntikā of the <ls>Divy</ls> <ab>mss.</ab>, just cited, <ls>Das</ls> gives pāpātmikā for <lang>Tib.</lang> <tib>ltuṅ byed</tib>. The same word is read pāyattikāḥ (<ab>sc.</ab> dharmāḥ) [Page340-b] <ls>Mvy</ls> 〔8360〕; (naiḥsargikāḥ, <ab>q.v.</ab>, = niḥsa°) pāyattikāḥ 〔8383〕, and pāpattikā (<lex>f.</lex>) 〔9223〕, but with <ab>vv.ll.</ab> in one or more of these places (besides pāyattikā in the last) pāyantika (pāyantikām āpattim, <lex>acc.</lex>, <ls>MSV</ls> 〔ii.174.9〕), pāpantika, pāṭāyantika, pātavantika, (<ab>acc.</ab> to <ls>Waldschmidt</ls> also pādayantika,) and with °kā as <lex>subst.</lex> <lex>f.</lex> (pāyantikayā, <lex>instr.</lex>, <ls>MSV</ls> 〔iii.109.20〕). There is moreover (besides pācatti cited by <ls>Waldschmidt</ls> above) prāyaścittikāḥ (<ab>sc.</ab> dharmāḥ) <ls>Mvy</ls> 〔8418〕 (śuddha-p°, <ab>acc.</ab> to <lang>Tib.</lang> {%only, merely prāy°%}, <tib>ḥbaḥ zhig tu ḥgyur ba</tib>); (snāna-)prāyaścittikaṃ 〔8484〕 (both these = <lang>Tib.</lang> <tib>ltuṅ byed</tib>); and prāyaścittikaḥ (<ab>sc.</ab> dharmaḥ) <ls>Mvy</ls> 〔9307〕 (= <lang>Tib.</lang> <tib>ltuṅ ba</tib>, {%fall%}), which is followed by śuddha- (<lang>Tib.</lang> <tib>ma ḥdres pa</tib>, {%unmixed%}) -pāpattikaḥ (<ab>sc.</ab> dharmaḥ; <lang>Tib.</lang> again <tib>ltuṅ ba</tib>, = <ab>prec.</ab>) 〔9308〕, <ab>cf.</ab> 〔8418〕 above, and <ab>s.v.</ab> {@śuddhaka@}. <ls>Lévi</ls> <ab>l. c.</ab> points out the phonetic difficulty of deriving <lang>Pali</lang> pācittiya from <lang>BHS</lang> prāyaścittika, and proposes an <ab>orig.</ab> *prākcitta plus -ika, <acr>thru</acr> *paccittika to pāci°, {%<fr>la pensée en avant</fr>%}, = either (<fr>des actes commis</fr>) {%<fr>avec précipitation</fr>%}, or {%<fr>qui précipitent</fr>%} (<fr>aux enfers</fr>). He cites a <lang>Tocharian</lang> loan <toch>pāyti</toch>, which he says goes back to <toch>pāyantika</toch>. It is obvious that the <ab>orig.</ab> form and <ab>mg.</ab> of the word can not be confidently reconstructed.

39811 old {@praṇidhāna@}¦, <lex>nt.</lex> (<lex>m.</lex> modifiers <ls>Bhad</ls> 〔58〕; = <lang>Pali</lang> paṇidhāna; like {@praṇidhi@}, <ab>n. act.</ab> to {@praṇidadhāti, praṇidheti@}), {%fixation%} of mind (ceto-pra° <ls>Mv</ls> 〔i.239.5〕; 〔iii.138.19〕; <lang>Pali</lang> ceto-paṇidhi), and so {%ardent desire, earnest wish, vow%}; sometimes (but rarely) of purely worldly desires, which are reprobated, praṇidhāna-vivarjitam <ls>SP</ls> 〔142.8〕 (<ab>vs</ab>); usually religious at least in basis, fulfilment being expected on the ground of acts of merit, which are often mentioned in a solemn declaration of wish; the thing desired may nevertheless be worldly (wealth, or special marks of grace), <acr>tho</acr> often the intention is stated to use it for religious-purposes: <ls>Mv</ls> 〔i.302.19〕 (magic possession of garlands); 〔iii.414.12〕 (fortunate rebirths); <ls>Divy</ls> 〔23.17〕; 〔65.10〕 (to become a cakravartin); or it may be truly religious, yet not Buddhahood or Bodhisattvahood, <ls>SP</ls> 〔242.4〕 (here made by a past Buddha, to do services to Buddhas to come); most commonly to win enlightenment, <ab>i.e.</ab> to become a Buddha, <ls>SP</ls> 〔43.12〕; <ls>LV</ls> 〔31.22〕 (°na-paripūryai, so with <ab>mss.</ab>; <ab>cf.</ab> {@praṇidhi-@}paripūriye); 〔180.1〕; 〔415.15〕; <ls>Mv</ls> 〔i.39.8〕; 〔104.3〕; 〔239.5〕; 〔iii.138.19〕; <ls>Divy</ls> 〔66.22〕; 〔90.3〕; <ls>Av</ls> 〔i.8.12〕; praṇidhāna-caryā, {%a whole course of praṇidhānas%}, <ls>Mv</ls> 〔i.1.3〕, see <ab>s.v.</ab> {@caryā@}; when made by a Bodhisattva it may mean rather the vow to follow the Bodhisattva-course, and may then be called specifically caryā-pra° <ls>SP</ls> 〔64.13, 14〕, or bhadracarī-pra° <ls>Bhad</ls> 〔2〕, <ab>etc.</ab>; praṇidhāna is one of the ten bala of a Bodhisattva, <ls>Mvy</ls> 〔764〕, and one of his vaśitā, <ls>Mvy</ls> 〔778〕; anuloma-pra° <ls>Mv</ls> 〔i.1.11〕, {%continued successive pra°%}, seems to mean a pra° repeated by the same individual (Śākyamuni in previous incarnations as cakravartin), in similar terms, as described later in 〔i.48.17 ff.〕; there are ten mahāpraṇidhāna of a Bodhisattva, <ls>Dbh</ls> 〔14.15 ff.〕, described at length (ten such are referred to in <ls>Sūtrāl.</ls> 〔iv.12〕, but the list quoted from another source by <ls>Lévi, note to Transl.</ls>, is quite different from the <ls>Dbh</ls> list); four pūrva-praṇidhāna-padāni <ls>LV</ls> 〔204.16〕, each described in the sequel in an entire paragraph; three kinds of pra° <ls>Dharmas</ls> 〔112〕, <ab>viz.</ab> susthāna-prābandhikam (see {@prābandhika@}), sattvārtha-prābandhikam, buddhakṣetra-pariśodhakam. Rarely {@prārthanā@}, <ab>q.v.</ab>, appears to be used of the {%‘earnest wish’%} for enlightenment.

vācayā yatha vadanti te budhās tatra caiva pratipattiyā ({%in actual practice%}) sthitāḥ <ls>RP</ls> 〔11.1〕 (<ab>vs</ab>); śrutvā ca tasmin pratipattiye sthito 〔36.12〕 (<ab>vs</ab>), {%and having heard it he remains steadfast in it by his behavior%}; <ls>Bbh</ls> 〔3.22〕; 〔4.2〕 (see <ab>s.v.</ab> {@pratipanna@}); [Page364-b] 〔213.18〕; pratipatti-kāmo <ls>Dbh.g.</ls> 〔16(352).17〕; <ls>Dbh</ls> 〔25.13 ff.〕; note <ab>esp.</ab> line 15, … anavakāśo yad ātmā vipratipattisthitaḥ parān samyak-pratipattau sthāpayet …, {%it is inconceivable that myself remaining in evil behavior should establish others in good behavior%}; 41119 old {@pratyaya@}¦, <lex>m.</lex> (once {@praccaya@}, <ab>q.v.</ab>; in <ab>mg.</ab> 1 <lang>Skt.</lang>; in all <ab>mgs.</ab> = <lang>Pali</lang> paccaya), ({@1@}) {%cause%}; often clearly a synonym of hetu, <acr>tho</acr> metaphysical writers try to distinguish the two in various ways; see <ab>e.g.</ab> <ls>AbhidhK. LaV-P.</ls> 〔ix.241〕, note 3, vyākhyā: hetur āsannaḥ pratyayaḥ, viprakṛṣṭas tu pratyaya eva; janako hetuḥ, pratyayas tv ālambanamātram ity apare; paryāyāv etāv ity apare, {%hetu is the proximate cause%} (pratyaya), {%the remote one is pratyaya rather; others say hetu is what generates (produces), pratyaya only the underlying condition; others say the two are synonyms%}; where hetu and pratyaya occur together in parallel phrases older interpreters (<ls>Burnouf</ls>, <ls>Kern</ls> on <ls>SP</ls>, <ls>Foucaux</ls> on <ls>LV</ls>) often mistakenly render pratyaya by {%effect%}: ko … hetuḥ kaḥ pratyayaḥ <ls>SP</ls> 〔8.5〕; ayaṃ … hetur ayaṃ pratyayo <ls>LV</ls> 〔120.19〕; so, the two being clearly synonyms, <ls>LV</ls> 〔128.11〕; <ls>Mv</ls> 〔i.66.7〕; 〔153.7〕; 〔ii.283.19〕 (taddhetos tatpratyayāt); <ls>Divy</ls> 〔204.7〕 <ab>etc.</ab> (ko … hetuḥ kaḥ pratyayo, common here); <ls>Divy</ls> 〔199.12〕 (ahetu-pratyayaṃ, <ab>mss.</ab> °yāṃ, <lex>adv.</lex>); <ls>Mv</ls> 〔iii.57.15〕 (hetu-pratyaya-cārikā, <ab>Bhvr.</ab>); <ls>Av</ls> 〔i.82.4〕 (taddhetu tatpratyayaṃ ca, adverbs); with the further synonym nidāna, sahetu sapratyayaṃ ca sanidānaṃ <ls>LV</ls> 〔376.21〕 (<ab>vs</ab>), {%with%} (good) {%ground, cause, and reason%}; with kāraṇa (<lang>Skt.</lang>), dvau kāraṇau tasya … dvau ca pratyayau <ls>Suv</ls> 〔11.9〕 (<ab>vs</ab>), {%two causes and reasons%}; technically there are four pratyaya listed, <ab>viz.</ab> hetu-pr°, samanantara-pr°, {@ālambana-@}pr°, {@adhipati-@}pr° (equivalents among 24 paccaya in <lang>Pali</lang>, <ls>Vism.</ls> 〔532.11〕), elaborately discussed <ls>AbhidhK. LaV-P.</ls> 〔ii.299 ff.〕; listed <ls>Mvy</ls> 〔2266—2270〕; <ls>Bbh</ls> 〔98.26 ff.〕 (brief definitions); seemingly in corrupt form <ls>ŚsP</ls> 〔80.4〕 ālambanāmateya-samanantara-hetupratyayatā (see <ab>s.v.</ab> {@adhipati@}); in <ls>Bbh</ls> 〔13.21 ff.〕 a (totally unrelated) list of 4 pratyaya and 4 (different) hetu of cittotpāda in a Bodhisattva are listed, the pratyaya being {%occasions%}, conjunctions of events which stimulate cittotpāda; they are external to the Bodhisattva, while the 4 hetu seem more personal and mostly internal (the 4 hetu are gotrasaṃpad, buddha-bodhisattva-kalyāṇamitra-parigrahaḥ, sattveṣu kāruṇyam, and saṃsāraduḥkhād … abhīrutā, 〔15.11 ff.〕); kadācit pratyayaṃ nārāgayiṣyāmi <ls>MSV</ls> 〔ii.14.11〕, {%perhaps I shall not get an occasion%} ({%opportunity%}, = avakāśa); in <ls>Mv</ls> 〔iii.338.2, 8〕 are listed three pratyaya, <ab>viz.</ab> āśravā(ḥ), vighātā(ḥ), and paridāghā(ḥ), for each of the five {@skandha@}, <ab>q.v.</ab>; -pratyayā (<ab>ifc.</ab>), for °yāt (= <lang>Pali</lang> paccayā), <lex>abl.</lex> as <lex>adv.</lex>, {%because of …%} (what precedes in <ab>comp.</ab>), kiṃpratyayā, {%because of what?%} <ls>Mv</ls> 〔iii.65.13, 15〕; avidyāpratyayā, <ab>etc.</ab>, various <ab>cpds.</ab>, <ab>id.</ab> 〔15 ff.〕; idaṃpratyayā 〔66.1〕; <ab>esp.</ab> in the {@pratītya-samutpāda@}, <ab>q.v.</ab> for lists, the regular formula begins avidyāpratyayāḥ (<ab>Bhvr.</ab>) saṃskārāḥ yāvaj jātipratyayaṃ jarāmaraṇam iti <ls>Śāl</ls> 〔76.14〕, and similarly as a rule when the formula is cited in full in prose, as <ls>Mv</ls> 〔ii.285.8 ff., iii.448.12 ff.〕 (but even in prose it may be modulated with avoidance of this stock terminology, as <ls>Dbh</ls> 〔48.25 ff.〕); with rather clear reference to this but not in the standard formula, pratyayasaṃbhava (<ab>Bhvr.</ab> <lex>adj.</lex>, {%dependent in origin%}) <ls>Suv</ls> 〔57.14〕; 〔60.6〕; 〔61.2〕; otherwise used quite as in <lang>Skt.</lang>, {%cause%}, <ab>e.g.</ab> dveṣa-pratyayopasaṃhāraḥ <ls>Av</ls> 〔ii.129.14〕, see {@upasaṃhāra@} (1); svapratyayān ({%based on themselves%}) dharmān prakāśayati <ls>SP</ls> 〔29.8〕, and similarly 〔131.9〕 (<ab>vs</ab>); ({@2@}) in glāna-pratyaya-bhaiṣajya, {%medicine to cure the sick%}, the fourth of a monkʼs 4 {@pariṣkāra@}, <ab>q.v.</ab> for lists (in <ls>Kv</ls> 〔19.9〕; 〔20.20〕; 〔40.17〕 yāna is misprinted for glāna); here the word pratyaya (<lang>Tib.</lang> on <ls>Mvy</ls> 〔5893〕 misprinted <tib>gos</tib>, read <tib>gso</tib> with <lang>Tib.</lang> Index and 〔6139〕) means substantially {%cure%}, <ab>orig.</ab> however clearly {%(required) means (of treatment)%}; note that pratyaya in <lang>BHS</lang> is {%not%} used as equivalent of {@pariṣkāra@} in this sense, as <lang>Pali</lang> paccaya is alleged to be used by both <ls>Childers</ls> and <ls>PTSD</ls>; bhojana-gilānapraccayaṃ (semi-<lang>MIndic</lang>) <ls>Mv</ls> 〔i.117.7〕 (<ab>vs</ab>); ({@3@}) pratyayabuddha, one who becomes {%a Buddha by%} (understanding of) {%causes%}, = a {@pratyeka-buddha@}, <ab>q.v.</ab>: <ls>Śikṣ</ls> 〔344.7〕 (<ab>vs</ab>), [Page376-a] where a marginal gloss has pratyekabuddha (which would be <ab>unmetr.</ab>); so also pratyaya-jina <ls>Dbh.g.</ls> 〔51(77.)2〕; and pratyaya-yāna = pratyeka-(buddha-)yāna <ls>Śikṣ</ls> 〔328.8〕 (<ab>vs</ab>; follows śrāvakayāna, and followed by uttama-yāna = mahāyāna; misunderstood by <ls>Bendall and Rouse</ls>); the same <ab>mg.</ab> is expressed by pratyayair jinā(ḥ) <ls>LV</ls> 〔443.17〕 (<ab>vs</ab>; refers to pratyekabuddhas, mentioned two lines before); the application of the term is made clear by a passage in <ls>SP</ls> 〔<ab>ch.</ab> 3, p. 80〕, where first, 〔line 5 f.〕, we read: tatra kecit sattvāḥ paraghoṣaśravānugamanam ākāṅkṣamāṇā ātmaparinirvāṇahetoś caturāryasatyānubodhāya tathāgataśāsane 'bhiyujyante, ta ucyante śrāvakayānam ākāṅkṣamāṇās … (the hīnayāna followers); then, 〔8 f.〕, anye sattvā anācāryakaṃ jñānaṃ damaśamatham ākāṅkṣamāṇā ātmaparinirvāṇahetor hetu-pratyayānubodhāya tathāgataśāsane 'bhiyujyante, ta ucyante pratyekabuddhayānam ākāṅkṣamāṇās …; and finally, 〔11 ff.〕, apare punaḥ sattvāḥ sarvajñajñānaṃ … ākāṅkṣamāṇā … sarvasattvaparinirvāṇahetos tathāgatajñānabalavaiśāradyānubodhāya tathāgataśāsane 'bhiyujyante, ta ucyante mahāyānam ākāṅkṣamāṇās …; here it is very clearly characteristic of pratyekabuddhas that they seek {%to understand%} (anubodhāya) {%grounds and reasons%}, whereas śrāvakas seek to understand only {%the four noble truths%}, and mahāyānists seek to understand the whole {%knowledge%}, <ab>etc.</ab>, {%of Tathāgatas%}. The śrāvakas are also said to be content with following what they hear said by others (<ab>i.e.</ab> of the gospel); pratyekabuddhas go deeper, but not so deep as mahāyānists. In <ls>Prāt</ls> 〔520.9〕 pratyaya-pravāraṇāyā (see {@pravāraṇā@}) is, in a <ab>v.l.</ab>, read pratyeka-prav°, which seems to have been the reading used by <lang>Chin.</lang> ({%<fr>secrète</fr>%}); the <lang>Pali</lang> parallel, however, <ls>Vin.</ls> 〔iv.102.38〕, has cātumāsapaccaya-pavāraṇā, and the old <ab>comm.</ab>, <ls>Vin.</ls> 〔iv.103.4 ff.〕, understands paccaya = gilāna-paccaya, <ab>i.e.</ab> our 2 above; it may be that some confusion has occurred in the tradition; did the <ls>Prāt</ls> redactor, reading pratyaya-, have in mind both the above-mentioned use of pratyaya-buddha for pratyeka-b°, and at the same time the curious use of {@pratyeka@} described under that word (and did he even substitute pratyaya for it)?

42703 old {@prahāṇa@}¦, <lex>nt.</lex> (besides the <ab>mgs.</ab> here noted, also as in <lang>Skt.</lang> <ab>id.</ab>, {%getting rid of, abandonment%}; only this <ab>mg.</ab> seems to be recognized by <lang>Tib.</lang> which regularly renders <tib>spoṅ ba</tib>; <ab>mg.</ab> 1 = <lang>Pali</lang> padhāna, <lang>BHS</lang> also {@pradhāna@}, <ab>q.v.</ab>, here in Pktic form, <ab>cf.</ab> <lang>AMg.</lang> pahāṇa-vanta, <ls>Ratnach.</ls> = <lang>Hindi</lang> saṃyama samādhivālā; rendered {%one who concentrates on self-restraint%}, better {%… on strenuous exertion%}; <ab>mg.</ab> 2 = <lang>AMg.</lang> pahāṇa, <lang>Skt.</lang> pradhāna), ({@1@}) {%exertion, strenuosity%}: four such <ls>Mvy</ls> 〔957—961〕 (as in <lang>Pali</lang>, see <ab>s.v.</ab> pradhāna for list); oftener called samyakprahāṇa (also °pradhāna; <lang>Pali</lang> sammappadhāna); <ls>Dharmas</ls> 〔45〕 (with list); <ls>Śikṣ</ls> 〔105.14〕; <ls>KP</ls> 〔95.6〕; <ls>Divy</ls> 〔208.8〕; in long <ab>cpds.</ab> containing lists of virtues and religious requirements, <ls>LV</ls> 〔8.5〕; 〔426.7〕; prahāṇa less technically, of zealous religious activity, in a series of <ab>vss</ab> similar, <acr>tho</acr> not quite identical, in <ls>Mv</ls> 〔ii.238.3 ff.〕, <ls>LV</ls> 〔261.2 ff.〕, and <lang>Pali</lang> <ls>Sn</ls> 〔425 ff.〕: <ls>LV</ls> 〔4〕 prahāṇāyodyataṃ … dṛḍhavikramaṃ (subject), <ab>cf.</ab> <ls>Mv</ls> 〔4〕 prahāṇaṃ prahitaṃ (<ab>q.v.</ab>) mayā, <ls>Sn</ls> 〔425〕 maṃ padhāna pahitattaṃ; <ls>Mv</ls> 〔8〕 saṃhara mahā-prahāṇaṃ, {%restrain your great%} (ascetic) {%exertion!%} (Māra speaks), not in <ls>LV</ls> or <ls>Sn</ls> <ls>LV</ls> 〔13〕 kiṃ prahāṇe kariṣyasi, (<acr>Sktization</acr> of) <ls>Mv</ls> 〔12〕 kiṃ prahāṇena kāhisi, <ls>Sn</ls> 〔428〕 kiṃ padhānena kāhasi; <ls>LV</ls> 〔14〕 duḥkhaṃ mārgaṃ praháṇasya, <ls>Mv</ls> 〔13〕 text dūraṃ (<ab>mss.</ab> duraṃ, duraṃgaṃ, read <ab>perh.</ab> duḥkham?) āśā prahāṇasya, <ls>Sn</ls> 〔429〕 duggo maggo padhānāya; similarly, prahāṇāya gamiṣyāmi <ls>Mv</ls> 〔ii.199.18〕 (<ab>vs</ab>) = <lang>Pali</lang> <ls>Sn</ls> 〔424〕 padhānāya gamissāmi; in a prose passage not found in <ls>LV</ls> or <ls>Sn</ls>, but introducing the above series of <ab>vss</ab>, <ls>Mv</ls> has (in words said by Māra to the Bodhisattva) kiṃ prahāṇena kariṣyasi 〔ii.237.18〕, prahāṇam ca duṣkaram 21; bodhisattvaḥ [Page390-a] prahāṇārthī viharati <ls>LV</ls> 〔246.8〕, which supports reading of <ab>v.l.</ab> at <ls>Mv</ls> 〔ii.124.1〕 (alaṃ punaḥ me …) kulaputrasya prahāṇārthikasya prahāṇāye, yan nūnāhaṃ ihaiva (<ab>mss.</ab> °vaṃ) prahāṇaṃ hareyaṃ (so <ab>mss.</ab>, <ls>Senart</ls> prahar°; better would perhaps be vihareyaṃ, {%dwell in …%}, see <ab>s.v.</ab> {@vyapakṛṣṭa@}, where cliché is cited with prahitātmā and forms of viharati); the first part of this <ls>Mv</ls> passage is supported by <lang>Pali</lang> <ls>MN</ls> 〔i.167.6—7〕 alaṃ vat' idaṃ kulaputtassa padhānatthikassa padhānāyā ti; prahāṇaṃ {@pradadhāti@} (so <ab>prob.</ab> read for <ls>Senart</ls>ʼs <ab>em.</ab> pratidadhāti, <ab>mss.</ab> corrupt) <ls>Mv</ls> 〔ii.208.1〕; -prahāṇa-jñāna- <ls>LV</ls> 〔434.9〕; lūhaprahāṇena <ls>Mv</ls> 〔ii.126.12〕 and in sequel (= rūkṣa{@pradhāna@}, see the latter); °ṇa-śālā, {%hall of religious exercise, concentration%}, in a monastery, <ls>MSV</ls> 〔iv.74.4 ff.〕; śaithiliko bāhulikaḥ prahāṇa-vibhraṣṭaḥ ({%fallen away from religious exertions%}) <ls>LV</ls> 〔407.19〕; <ls>Mv</ls> 〔iii.329.3—4〕 (here text with <ab>mss.</ab> vikrānto, <ab>prob.</ab> intending vibhrānto, for vibhraṣṭaḥ, <ab>cf.</ab> <lang>Pali</lang> bāhuliko padhānavibbhanto <ls>Vin.</ls> 〔i.9.1〕 and <ls>Jāt.</ls> 〔i.68.2〕, in the same incident); {@utkuṭuka-pra°@}, see {@utku°@}; in the formula of the four {@ṛddhipāda@}, <ab>q.v.</ab>, always -samādhi-prahāṇa-saṃskāra-samanvāgata (<lang>Pali</lang> samādhi-padhāna-saṃkhāra-samannāgata, <ab>e.g.</ab> <ls>DN</ls> 〔ii.213.7〕); ({@2@}) twice I believe prahāṇa (= <lang>AMg.</lang> pahāṇa) = <lang>Skt.</lang> pradhāna, {%the chief thing%}, at end of <ab>Bhvr.</ab> <ab>cpds.</ab> = {%chiefly consisting of%} or {%characterized by%}: kuhana-lapanaprahāṇaṃ māyā-mātsarya-doṣa-irṣyādyaṃ, (iha te kleśāraṇyaṃ chinnaṃ …) <ls>LV</ls> 〔372.17〕 (<ab>vs</ab>), {%here you have cut down the forest of the impurities, consisting chiefly of%} {@kuhana@} {%and%} {@lapana@} (<ab>qq.v.</ab>), {%including deceit, malice, hatred, jealousy%}, <ab>etc.</ab>; tasya tahiṃ āśramapade prativasato kṣama-dama-prahāṇasya <ls>Mv</ls> 〔ii.221.15〕 (<ab>vs</ab>), {%while he was dwelling … characterized by …%} In both these the <lang>Skt.</lang> <ab>mg.</ab> {%abandonment%} is manifestly impossible (<acr>tho</acr> <ls>Foucaux</ls> tries to adopt it in <ls>LV</ls>, by flagrant violation of the text), and {%exertion%} in the sense of <lang>Pali</lang> padhāna seems certainly implausible. The word is very common in <lang>AMg.</lang> in this <ab>mg.</ab>; note that <lang>BHS</lang> has usually this <lang>AMg.</lang>-like form for <lang>Pali</lang> padhāna.

; <L>10686<pc>391,2<k1>prAtihArakapakza<k2>prAtihAraka-pakza
42875 old {@prātihāraka-pakṣa@}¦, <lex>m.</lex> (only once, <ls>Mmk</ls> 〔79.19〕, is pakṣa not expressed), more rarely {@prati°, prātihāra-, °hārika-@} (= <lang>Pali</lang> pāṭihārika-pakkha or pāṭihāriya-p°, inaccurately defined <ls>PTSD</ls>; the <ab>mg.</ab> is evidently related to that of {@prātihārya@}, <ab>q.v.</ab>, but {%<fr>quinzaine du miracle</fr>%}, <ls>Lalou, Iconographie</ls> 〔24〕, is hardly likely to be the true <ab>mg.</ab>, <acr>tho</acr> it is the <ab>lit.</ab> <ab>mg.</ab> of the <lang>Tib.</lang> cited, <tib>cho phrul gyi …</tib>), {%extraordinary, exceptional half-month%}. The <lang>Pali</lang> <ab>comms.</ab> vary greatly in their explanations; see citations in <ls>PTSD</ls>; note specially <ls>AN comm.</ls> 〔ii.234.25 ff.〕 on <ls>AN</ls> 〔i.144.2〕 (cited <ls>PTSD</ls> °hārika-, but actually °hāriya-) in contrast with <ls>Vv. comm.</ls> 〔71.26 ff.〕 on <ls>Vv.</ls> 〔15〕 <ab>vs</ab> 6 (same stanza as in <ls>AN</ls>, wholly discordant glosses in <ab>comms.</ab>; at least one of them clearly a baseless guess). Evidently the tradition of the true <ab>mg.</ab> was lost at an early time. In <lang>BHS</lang> noted only in <ls>Mmk</ls>, where it is fairly common, but I have found no evidence as to <ab>mg.</ab>, except that pakṣa has its usual <ab>mg.</ab> {%half-lunar-month%} (not {%holiday%} with <ls>PTSD</ls>); this is proved by prātihāraka-pakṣa-pūrṇamāsyāṃ <ls>Mmk</ls> 〔669.19—20〕, {%on the full-moon day of …%} Otherwise, usually °raka-pakṣe [Page392-a] <ls>Mmk</ls> 〔58.11〕; 〔75.10〕; 〔289.19〕; 〔669.22—23〕 (°rakapakṣe pūrṇamāsyāṃ); 〔675.28〕; 〔676.28〕; 〔715.6〕, et alibi; śuklapūrṇamāsyāṃ prātihāraka-pratipūrṇāyāṃ 〔79.19〕, {%on the full-moon day of a bright fortnight, when%} (the moon) {%is full in a prātihāraka%} (<ab>sc.</ab> pakṣa; the only case noted in which this is omitted); prātihārika-pakṣe 〔290.1〕; śuklapakṣe prātihārapakṣe vā 〔145.21〕 (prose; is the omission of -ka a mere corruption?), {%in a bright fortnight, or in a prāti° one%}; pratihāraka-pakṣe 〔36.25〕; 〔675.7〕 (<ab>foll.</ab> by śuklatrayodaśyāṃ; evidently the ‘extraordinary’ fortnight could be either ‘light’ or ‘dark’); pratihāraka-pakṣam ārabhya 〔675.22〕 (passages with prati° all prose).
;

; <L>11355<pc>412,2<k1>BOtika<k2>BOtika
45561 old {@bhautika@}¦, (<lex>adj.</lex>?) <lex>subst.</lex> <lex>nt.</lex> (<ab>cf.</ab> <lang>Skt.</lang> <ab>id.</ab>; here in specialized <ab>mgs.</ab>), ({@1@}) possibly <lex>adj.</lex>, {%real%} or {%material%}, in <ls>Laṅk</ls> 〔17.5〕, but the reading is very doubtful and the sense at least equally so, see <ab>s.v.</ab> {@abhauti@} and below; ({@2@}) <lex>subst.</lex> <lex>nt.</lex>, {%object of sense%}: in <ls>Dharmas</ls> 〔40〕 = viṣaya or indriyārtha (five are listed: rūpa, śabda, gandha, rasa, and sparśa, corresponding, <acr>tho</acr> in different order, to the five mahābhūtāni listed in 39 just before). <ab>Acc.</ab> to <ls>Suzukiʼs Index to Laṅk</ls>, the <lang>Chin.</lang> versions of <ls>Laṅk</ls> indicate bhautika = {%the%} [Page413-a] {%4 viṣaya%} or {%color, odor, flavor, contact%} (note omission of {%sound%}, and the fact that in <ls>Laṅk</ls> 〔124.8〕 ākāśa is added only parenthetically; <ab>cf.</ab> the 4 dhātu of <lang>Pali</lang>, paṭhavī-, āpo-, tejo-, vāyo-dhātu, <ls>Childers</ls>, <ab>s.v.</ab>); in <ls>Laṅk</ls> 〔205.10〕 (omit bhūta-with 2 <ab>mss.</ab>) bhautika-svalakṣaṇa-vināśānupalabdhir, evidently {%products of the bhūtāni%}, presumably as in <ls>Dharmas</ls> 〔40〕. The passage <ls>Laṅk</ls> 〔123.11—124.16〕 must, it seems, somehow be interpreted in the light of these passages, but is obscure to me (<ab>cf.</ab> also <ls>Laṅk</ls> 〔355.1〕). <ls>Suzuki</ls> is not very helpful on it; <ab>e.g.</ab> 〔124.13〕 na tu mahābhūtānām certainly cannot mean {%which%} (primary elements) {%are non-existent%}, but rather: (the mahābhūtāni are the causes of the bhautikāni), {%but not%} (the bhautikāni) {%of the mahābhūtāni%}, <ab>i.e.</ab> {%but not vice versa%}. In <ls>Mvy</ls> 〔1847〕 bhautika-rūpam appears to be parallel and complementary to 〔1846〕 {@upādāya-rūpam@}, <ab>q.v.</ab>; this suggests that bhautikarūpam = <lang>Pali</lang> bhūta-rūpa (<ls>Childers</ls> and <ls>PTSD</ls> <ab>s.v.</ab> rūpa), which <ab>acc.</ab> to <ls>Vism.</ls> = the four mahābhūtāni, earth, water, fire, and air (listed <ls>Mvy</ls> 〔1838—1841〕), contrary to <ls>Dharmas</ls> and the <lang>Chin.</lang> as cited by <ls>Suzuki</ls>, above; for the viṣayas are included among the 24 upādā(ya)-rūpa of <lang>Pali</lang>. On the basis of <ls>Mvy</ls> 〔1846—7〕 we might conjecture that in <ls>Laṅk</ls> 〔17.5〕 (see {@abhauti@}) abhautika = upādāya(-rūpam), and bhautika = bhautika (<lang>Pali</lang> bhūta)-rūpam. But if <ls>Dharmas</ls> and <lang>Chin.</lang> are right, bhautika would mean virtually the opposite of <lang>Pali</lang> bhūta(-rūpa).
;

45617 old {@bhrūṇa-dheya@}¦ (see {@-dheya@}), in °yam idaṃ cittaṃ niḥsāram anidarśanam <ls>Ud</ls> 〔xxxi.4〕. This word the <lang>Pali</lang> <ab>comms.</ab> seem evidently to misunderstand. <ab>Cf.</ab> <ls>Renou, JA 1939</ls>, 〔p. 348 with n. 1〕, who connects the <lang>Pali</lang> word with <lang>Vedic</lang> and <lang>Skt.</lang> bhrūṇa-han; <ab>acc.</ab> to his note 1, the <lang>Skt.</lang> form is to be ‘restored’ in Dharmasamuccaya 〔16.8〕. The <lang>Pali</lang> <ab>comms.</ab> interpret the <lang>Pali</lang> as {%destroying prosperity%} or {%welfare%}.

The two <ab>mgs.</ab> cannot always be distinguished with certainty but ({@1@}) is doubtless regularly meant when the word is associated with {@iñjana, °nā@}, or {@iñjita@}, <ab>qq.v.</ab> for passages like <ls>Gv</ls> 〔128.6〕; 〔253.14〕; <ls>Dbh</ls> 〔64.13〕; so in <ls>LV</ls> 〔259.9〕 (<ab>vs</ab>) where read na ceñjanaṃ nāpi manyana-(<ab>m.c.</ab> for °nā)pracāraṃ (<ls>Lefm.</ls> manyena, <ab>metr.</ab> impossible), and <ab>prob.</ab> in <ls>KP</ls> 〔136.8〕 (<ab>vs</ab>) iñjanā-manyana-, <acr>tho</acr> <lang>Tib.</lang> here <tib>rlom sems</tib>, {%pride%}; <ab>prob.</ab> in <ls>Gv</ls> 〔199.20〕 sarva-manyanā-samudghātitasya bodhisattva-vimokṣasya; certainly in <ls>Laṅk</ls> 〔127.2〕; 〔278.1〕; 〔300.4〕; and <ab>esp.</ab> note the <ab>vs</ab> 〔265.9, 10〕: asārakā ime dharmā manyanāyāḥ samutthitāḥ, sāpy atra manyanā śūnyā yayā śūnyeti manyate; ({@2@}) {%pride%}: in <ls>LV</ls> 〔332.14〕 (<ab>vs</ab>) read with best <ab>mss.</ab> (and <lang>Tib.</lang>, <tib>rlom sems</tib>) sarvamanyanā-(<ls>Lefm.</ls> manyunā)-prahīnāḥ; in <ls>LV</ls> 〔371.13〕 (<ab>vs</ab>) read, with <ab>vv.ll.</ab> and <ls>Foucaux</ls>, iha me hatā navavidhā mānavidhī (<ab>m.c.</ab>, <ab>mss.</ab> all °vidhi) manyanāpur' aniketāḥ, {%here I have destroyed the nine-fold varieties of conceit, which have pride as their home%} (or {%body%}, pura) {%and%} (now are left in me) {%without any resting-place%}; in <ls>LV</ls> 〔374.5〕 (<ab>vs</ab>) read manyanāś with <ab>v.l.</ab> for mamiyitā; <ls>Mvy</ls> 〔7082〕 = <lang>Tib.</lang> <tib>rlom(s) sems</tib>; <ls>Śikṣ</ls> 〔251.8〕 (<lang>Tib.</lang> cited as <tib>rlom sems</tib>); śīlamanyanā <ls>KP</ls> 〔135.7〕 (prose), {%pride in%} (oneʼs own) {%morality%}, = <lang>Tib.</lang> <tib>tshul khrims kyis rlom sems</tib>; <ls>Bbh</ls> 〔207.14〕; <ls>AsP</ls> 〔389.20〕; avamanyana-manyana (<lex>acc.</lex> <ab>sg.</ab>; a <ab>m.c.</ab>) tyaktvā <ls>RP</ls> 〔21.4〕 (<ab>vs</ab>). See also {@a-manyana-tā@}.

; <L>11731<pc>423,1<k1>mahAnagna<k2>mahA-nagna
47067 old {@mahā-nagna@}¦, <lex>m.</lex> (<ab>cpd.</ab> of mahā and {@nagna@}, <ab>q.v.</ab>; seems to correspond to <lang>Pali</lang> mahānāga, <ls>DN</ls> 〔i.51.10〕 °gā, <ab>n. pl.</ab>, in a list of kinds of fighting men which includes uggā rājaputtā … sūrā cammayodhino <ab>etc.</ab>; <ab>comm.</ab> 〔i.157.6〕 mahānāgā viya mahānāgā; hatthiādisu pi abhimukham āgacchantesu anivattitayodhānaṃ etaṃ adhivacanaṃ, all of which only proves that the <ab>comm.</ab> did not understand the term; it is omitted in <ls>PTSD</ls>, <acr>altho</acr> <ls>Childers</ls> properly refers to <ls>Burnouf, Lotus</ls>, 〔452, n. 4〕, who in translating the <lang>Pali</lang> suggests equivalence to <lang>BHS</lang> mahānagna, which he takes to be the older form; <lang>Skt.</lang> nagna would give <lang>MIndic</lang> nagga, for which nāga might be substituted; <ls>Burnouf</ls> also compares the <lang>Skt.</lang> <ab>n. pr.</ab> Nagnajit, <ab>perh.</ab> {%conquering champions%}; <ls>pw</ls> and <ls>Speyer, Av Index</ls>, render {%athlete%}, but this is only an attempt to explain the word etymologically; it is implausible in several passages, and opposed by <lang>Tib.</lang>), {%great man, champion%} (<ab>orig.</ab> in warfare); between māna and mada (after which comes krodha) <ls>LV</ls> 〔52.13〕; 〔411.16〕; after māna and mada <ls>Mv</ls> 〔ii.229.20〕; between mātsarya and māna <ls>SP</ls> 〔481.4〕; after māna and mada, (before paridāha) <ls>Śikṣ</ls> 〔198.8〕, (before krodha) <ls>KP</ls> 〔7.3〕; krodha upanāhaḥ śāṭhyam īrṣyā pradāso (<ab>ed.</ab> °dāno) mrakṣo mātsaryaṃ … <ls>Dharmas</ls> 〔30〕. <lang>Tib.</lang>, in all passages known to me (<ls>Mvy</ls>, <ls>LV</ls>, <ls>KP</ls>), renders <tib>ḥchab pa</tib>, {%concealment%}, which is somewhat etymological (mrakṣ, {%smear, anoint%}), but not erroneous, only incomplete; it means primarily {%concealment of the good qualities of others%}, not (as nearly all have assumed) of oneʼs own faults.

= paraguṇa-makkhana-lakkhaṇo, tesaṃ vināsana-raso, tadavacchādanapaccupaṭṭhāno (see {@pratyupasthāna@}) <ls>MN comm.</ls> 〔i.106.26 f.〕, on <ls>MN</ls> 〔i.15.35〕; similarly <ab>tho</ab> less fully <ab>comm.</ab> on <ls>Dhp.</ls> 〔150 and 407〕; <ls>AN comm.</ls> 〔ii.162.28〕, on <ls>AN</ls> 〔i.95.15〕; in <ls>Pugg.</ls> 〔18.25, 22.29 f.〕 read niṭṭhuriya for niddhunīya; <ls>AN</ls> and <ls>MN</ls> <ab>comms.</ab> <ab>l. c.</ab> define the associated paḷāsa, our {@pradāsa@}, <ab>q.v.</ab>, by yugaggāha, {%grasping after preëminence for oneself over others%}), despite usual rendering {%hypocrisy%} or the like, never has that <ab>mg.</ab>; primarily, {%concealment of the good qualities of others, jealous disparagement, nasty disposition, ill-will%}, finally (like {@mrakṣya@}, <ab>q.v.</ab>) virtually = krodha, {%anger%}: this last development seems clearly complete in <ls>Karmav</ls> 〔37.19〕 text krodhaḥ, upanāhaḥ, mrakṣaḥ, pradāśaḥ, but for the last read with <ab>ms.</ab> paridāghaḥ, <ab>cf.</ab> <ls>Śikṣ</ls> 〔198.8〕 below; yet <ls>Mvy</ls> 〔1963〕 and <ls>Dharmas</ls> 〔69〕 mrakṣaḥ after krodha, upanāha, and before pradāsa (°śa); <ab>prob.</ab> same <ab>mg.</ab> in <ls>LV</ls> 〔262.17〕 (<ab>vs</ab>) krodha-mrakṣau; usually in rather <ab>misc.</ab> lists of vices; between māna and mada (after which comes krodha) <ls>LV</ls> 〔52.13〕; 〔411.16〕; after māna and mada <ls>Mv</ls> 〔ii.229.20〕; between mātsarya and māna <ls>SP</ls> 〔481.4〕; after māna and mada, (before paridāha) <ls>Śikṣ</ls> 〔198.8〕, (before krodha) <ls>KP</ls> 〔7.3〕; after māna <ls>Mv</ls> 〔i.166.20〕; <ls>Ud</ls> 〔xvi.23〕 (= <lang>Pali</lang> <ls>Dhp.</ls> 〔150〕 māno makkho); after śāṭhya, vakratā, kauṭilya, māna <ls>SP</ls> 〔107.1〕; krodherṣyā-śāṭhya-mrakṣādayaś <ls>Bbh</ls> 〔20.15〕; krodha upanāhaḥ śāṭhyam īrṣyā pradāso (<ab>ed.</ab> °dāno) mrakṣo mātsaryaṃ … <ls>Dharmas</ls> 〔30〕. <lang>Tib.</lang>, in all passages known to me (<ls>Mvy</ls>, <ls>LV</ls>, <ls>KP</ls>), renders <tib>ḥchab pa</tib>, {%concealment%}, which is somewhat etymological (mrakṣ, {%smear, anoint%}), but not erroneous, only incomplete; it means primarily {%concealment of the good qualities of others%}, not (as nearly all have assumed) of oneʼs own faults.

This seems to prove that the <ls>Prāt</ls> intended ūḍhacīvaro, <ab>altho</ab> the repetition in 〔492.6〕 has vā rūḍhacīvareṇa. Neither rūḍhanor ārūḍha- seems to make any possible sense. We must either emend to vā ūḍha°, or understand vā-r-ūḍha° with hiatus-bridging r.]

51749 old {@lakṣa@}¦ (<lang>Skt.</lang>), {%mark%}: anena ca lakṣa-nikṣepeṇa <ls>SP</ls> 〔316.10〕 (prose), {%and by this depositing of the sort just described%}, <ab>lit.</ab> {%by this mark-deposit%}, or, perhaps better, {%by this depositing on the%} (designated) {%mark%} (target, lakṣa). <ab>Acc.</ab> to <ls>Senart</ls>, lakṣa is read for {@lakṣaṇa@} (4) by <ab>mss.</ab> at <ls>Mv</ls> 〔i.207.16〕, where he keeps it, <acr>tho</acr> in the repetition 〔ii.12.6〕 he keeps lakṣaṇa with <ab>mss.</ab> there; in 〔i.62.12〕 he <ab>em.</ab> lakṣa for lakṣaṇa, alleging metrical grounds, but the resulting meter is not correct; read rather maha-(<ab>m.c.</ab> for mahā-)-puruṣalakṣaṇavarāṇāṃ; and in 〔i.207.16〕 we must also read, with 〔ii.12.6〕, dvātriṃśallakṣaṇadharo (or °śa-lakṣaṇadharo?). 51749 new {@lakṣa@}¦ (<lang>Skt.</lang>), {%mark%}: anena ca lakṣa-nikṣepeṇa <ls>SP</ls> 〔316.10〕 (prose), {%and by this depositing of the sort just described%}, <ab>lit.</ab> {%by this mark-deposit%}, or, perhaps better, {%by this depositing on the%} (designated) {%mark%} (target, lakṣa). <ab>Acc.</ab> to <ls>Senart</ls>, lakṣa is read for {@lakṣaṇa@} (4) by <ab>mss.</ab> at <ls>Mv</ls> 〔i.207.16〕, where he keeps it, <ab>tho</ab> in the repetition 〔ii.12.6〕 he keeps lakṣaṇa with <ab>mss.</ab> there; in 〔i.62.12〕 he <ab>em.</ab> lakṣa for lakṣaṇa, alleging metrical grounds, but the resulting meter is not correct; read rather maha-(<ab>m.c.</ab> for mahā-)-puruṣalakṣaṇavarāṇāṃ; and in 〔i.207.16〕 we must also read, with 〔ii.12.6〕, dvātriṃśallakṣaṇadharo (or °śa-lakṣaṇadharo?). ; <L>12899<pc>458,1<k1>lakzaRa<k2>lakzaRa
51753 old {@lakṣaṇa@}¦, <lex>nt.</lex>, {%mark%} (<lang>Skt.</lang>); ({@1@}) in <ls>Laṅk</ls> 〔37.10 ff.〕; 〔38.5 ff.〕, {%external mark, manifested aspect%}, of the vijñāna (<ab>cf.</ab> <ls>Suzuki, Studies</ls>, 〔183〕); contrasted with {@prabandha@}, <ab>q.v.</ab>; fuller expression seems to be svajāti-lakṣaṇa, see <ls>Laṅk</ls> 〔38.16 ff.〕, <ab>esp.</ab> 〔18 f.〕, svajātilakṣaṇe punar nirudhyamāne (<ab>mss.</ab>) ālayavijñānanirodhaḥ syāt, suggesting that with its suppression, the ālaya-vijñāna itself is suppressed; for the aṣṭalakṣaṇa {@vijñāna@} see {@vij°@} 2; ({@2@}) in <ls>Divy</ls> 〔513.15, 24〕, sauvarṇena lakṣaṇena laḍḍīś (<ab>sc.</ab> of a state horse) chorayati, {%removes the dung with a golden …%} (? some sort of implement; <ab>acc.</ab> to Index, {%spoon?%}), <ab>perh.</ab> {%shovel%} or the like; ({@3@}) = {@svabhāva@} (2), <ab>q.v.</ab>, {%characteristic%}, of existing things, there being three such, <ab>viz.</ab> {@parikalpita, paratantra, pariniṣpanna@}, <ab>qq.v.</ab>: <ls>Mvy</ls> 〔1662〕 (to 〔1665〕 <ab>incl.</ab>); <ls>Sūtrāl.</ls> 〔xi.38—41〕 (<ls>Lévi</ls>, {%indice%}); svabhāva-lakṣaṇa-trayakuśalena bhavitavyam <ls>Laṅk</ls> 〔67.2〕; ({@4@}) {%characteristic mark%} of a superior person (a cakravartin or a Buddha), of which there are standardly 32 (anomalously 28 in <ls>Gv</ls> 〔353.7〕, aṣṭaviṃśatibhir mahāpuruṣalakṣaṇair upeto; no list). There are various lists; in <lang>Pali</lang> (lakkhaṇa), <ls>DN</ls> 〔ii.17.10 ff.〕 and 〔iii.143.5 ff.〕 (here followed by lengthy treatments of each item); <ls>MN</ls> 〔ii.136.6 ff.〕; in <lang>BHS</lang>, <ls>LV</ls> 〔105.11 ff.〕 [Page458-1b] (here referred to as <ls>LVa</ls>) and 〔429.3 ff.〕 (<ls>LVb</ls>); <ls>Mvy</ls> 〔235 ff.〕; <ls>Dharmas</ls> (here abbreviated <ab>Dh</ab>) 83; <ls>Gv</ls> 〔399.20 ff.〕, with valuable brief explanations of each term; <ls>Bbh</ls> 〔375.9 ff.〕, with a few brief glosses, but followed on 〔378.3 ff., 381.8 ff.〕, by more extensive treatments of the various items, with a few minor variants which are mostly not recorded here; finally, <ls>Mv</ls> 〔i.226.16 ff.〕 = 〔ii.29.19 ff.〕 has, in 7 lines of verse, extremely brief one-word designations for the 32 items, in part so corrupt in the text that I have failed to identify a few items (here, <ls>Mv</ls> without reference refers to this list); again, <ls>Mv</ls> 〔ii.304.14 ff.〕 has a very loose, inaccurate, and incomplete list, mingled with some {@anuvyañjana@} and other extraneous materials; this is cited below by page and line when it is important. Finally, a few stray lakṣaṇa are unsystematically mentioned in <ls>RP</ls> 〔46.13—47.12〕, and again 〔50.11—51.5〕; they will be referred to by page and line under the appropriate items. In modern literature, correlations of various <lang>Pali</lang> and <lang>BHS</lang> lists (but without the <ls>Gv</ls>, <ls>Bbh</ls>, and <ls>Mv</ls> lists) have been recorded by <ls>Burnouf, Lotus</ls>, 〔558 ff.〕; <ls>Müller, note on Dharmas</ls> 〔83〕 (but note that in a number of cases <ls>Müller</ls> here cites <ls>Dharmas</ls> itself inconsistently with his own text). In <ls>Mvy</ls> and <ls>LVa</ls> (as also in the stray fragmentary lists of <ls>RP</ls>) the order of all other texts is reversed, so as to begin with the head instead of the feet; in citing numbers I have reversed the numbering of these two lists, to facilitate comparison with the other lists; therefore when I cite ‘<ls>Mvy</ls> 〔32〕, <ls>LVa</ls> 〔32〕’, I refer to <ls>Mvy</ls> and <ls>LVa</ls> 〔1〕; ‘<ls>Mvy</ls> 〔31〕, <ls>LVa</ls> 〔31〕’ means <ls>Mvy</ls> 〔2〕, <ls>LVa</ls> 〔2〕, <ab>etc.</ab> I believe the following list is substantially correct and original, <acr>tho</acr> the precise language is not always certain; all important variants are cited. The order of the items in <lang>BHS</lang> varies greatly, no two lists being alike; but the relative order in the <lang>Pali</lang> lists is, I believe, always or nearly always supported by some <lang>BHS</lang> evidence, and I see no serious reason to doubt that it represents the original; it is therefore adopted here. {@1@}. supratiṣṭhitapāda (<lang>Pali</lang> suppatiṭṭhitapāda), <ls>Mvy</ls> 〔3〕; [Page459-a] <ls>LVb</ls>, <ls>Gv</ls>, <ls>Bbh</ls> 〔1〕; <ls>LVa</ls> 〔1〕 inserts sama before pāda; <ls>Mv</ls> <ab>prob.</ab> means this by 1 samā; <ls>Mv</ls> 〔ii.304.14〕 samā … caraṇā supratiṣṭhitā; <ls>Dh.</ls> 〔2〕 -pāṇipādatala(tā) for -pāda. —{@2@}. adhastāt pādatalayoś cakre jāte … (epithets), so <ls>Bbh</ls> 〔2〕, similarly <ls>LVa</ls>, <ls>Gv</ls> 〔2〕; <lang>Pali</lang> heṭṭhāpādatalesu cakkāni jātāni … (epithets); <ls>Mv</ls> 〔2〕 heṣṭā, also heṣṭā … <ls>Mv</ls> 〔ii.304.16〕; <ls>LVb</ls> 〔2〕 compresses the epithets into a long <ab>cpd.</ab> ending cakrāṅkitapādatala; <ls>Mvy</ls> 〔4〕 cakrāṅkita-hasta-pāda, and so <ls>Dh.</ls> 〔1〕 adding -tala and with pāṇi for hasta, which, <acr>tho</acr> supported by <lang>Tib.</lang> <tib>phyag</tib>, is only a false interpretation of adhastāt or semi-<lang>MIndic</lang> heṣṭā. —{@3@}. āyatapādapārṣṇi (<lang>Pali</lang> āyatapaṇhi), so <ls>Mvy</ls> 〔2〕, <ls>Bbh</ls> 〔4〕, <ls>Gv</ls> 〔5〕 (<ls>LVa</ls> 〔6〕 āyatapārṣṇipāda); or āyatapārṣṇi, <ls>LVb</ls> 〔3〕, <ls>Dh.</ls> 〔7〕, with <lang>Pali</lang>; <ls>Mv</ls> 〔4〕 āyatā. —{@4@}. dīrghāṅguli (<lang>Pali</lang> dīgha°), <ls>LVb</ls> 〔4〕, <ls>LVa</ls> 〔7〕, <ls>Mvy</ls> 〔5〕, <ls>Dh.</ls> 〔6〕, <ls>Gv</ls> (<ed>2d ed.</ed>) 6 dīrghā asyāṅgulayo, <ls>Bbh</ls> 〔3〕; <ls>Gv</ls> 〔4〕 hastapādatale jālinī (<ed>2d ed.</ed>); <ls>Mv</ls> 〔12〕 jālā. —{@7@}. ucchaṅkha-(?)pāda (<lang>Pali</lang> ussaṅkha°), so <ls>Gv</ls> 〔3〕, and so read (ucchaṅkha) <ls>Mv</ls> 〔5〕 and <ls>Mv</ls> 〔ii.304.19〕, also with <ls>Mironov</ls> <ls>Mvy</ls> 〔8〕; ;
51753 new {@lakṣaṇa@}¦, <lex>nt.</lex>, {%mark%} (<lang>Skt.</lang>); ({@1@}) in <ls>Laṅk</ls> 〔37.10 ff.〕; 〔38.5 ff.〕, {%external mark, manifested aspect%}, of the vijñāna (<ab>cf.</ab> <ls>Suzuki, Studies</ls>, 〔183〕); contrasted with {@prabandha@}, <ab>q.v.</ab>; fuller expression seems to be svajāti-lakṣaṇa, see <ls>Laṅk</ls> 〔38.16 ff.〕, <ab>esp.</ab> 〔18 f.〕, svajātilakṣaṇe punar nirudhyamāne (<ab>mss.</ab>) ālayavijñānanirodhaḥ syāt, suggesting that with its suppression, the ālaya-vijñāna itself is suppressed; for the aṣṭalakṣaṇa {@vijñāna@} see {@vij°@} 2; ({@2@}) in <ls>Divy</ls> 〔513.15, 24〕, sauvarṇena lakṣaṇena laḍḍīś (<ab>sc.</ab> of a state horse) chorayati, {%removes the dung with a golden …%} (? some sort of implement; <ab>acc.</ab> to Index, {%spoon?%}), <ab>perh.</ab> {%shovel%} or the like; ({@3@}) = {@svabhāva@} (2), <ab>q.v.</ab>, {%characteristic%}, of existing things, there being three such, <ab>viz.</ab> {@parikalpita, paratantra, pariniṣpanna@}, <ab>qq.v.</ab>: <ls>Mvy</ls> 〔1662〕 (to 〔1665〕 <ab>incl.</ab>); <ls>Sūtrāl.</ls> 〔xi.38—41〕 (<ls>Lévi</ls>, {%indice%}); svabhāva-lakṣaṇa-trayakuśalena bhavitavyam <ls>Laṅk</ls> 〔67.2〕; ({@4@}) {%characteristic mark%} of a superior person (a cakravartin or a Buddha), of which there are standardly 32 (anomalously 28 in <ls>Gv</ls> 〔353.7〕, aṣṭaviṃśatibhir mahāpuruṣalakṣaṇair upeto; no list). There are various lists; in <lang>Pali</lang> (lakkhaṇa), <ls>DN</ls> 〔ii.17.10 ff.〕 and 〔iii.143.5 ff.〕 (here followed by lengthy treatments of each item); <ls>MN</ls> 〔ii.136.6 ff.〕; in <lang>BHS</lang>, <ls>LV</ls> 〔105.11 ff.〕 [Page458-1b] (here referred to as <ls>LVa</ls>) and 〔429.3 ff.〕 (<ls>LVb</ls>); <ls>Mvy</ls> 〔235 ff.〕; <ls>Dharmas</ls> (here abbreviated <ls>Dh</ls>) 83; <ls>Gv</ls> 〔399.20 ff.〕, with valuable brief explanations of each term; <ls>Bbh</ls> 〔375.9 ff.〕, with a few brief glosses, but followed on 〔378.3 ff., 381.8 ff.〕, by more extensive treatments of the various items, with a few minor variants which are mostly not recorded here; finally, <ls>Mv</ls> 〔i.226.16 ff.〕 = 〔ii.29.19 ff.〕 has, in 7 lines of verse, extremely brief one-word designations for the 32 items, in part so corrupt in the text that I have failed to identify a few items (here, <ls>Mv</ls> without reference refers to this list); again, <ls>Mv</ls> 〔ii.304.14 ff.〕 has a very loose, inaccurate, and incomplete list, mingled with some {@anuvyañjana@} and other extraneous materials; this is cited below by page and line when it is important. Finally, a few stray lakṣaṇa are unsystematically mentioned in <ls>RP</ls> 〔46.13—47.12〕, and again 〔50.11—51.5〕; they will be referred to by page and line under the appropriate items. In modern literature, correlations of various <lang>Pali</lang> and <lang>BHS</lang> lists (but without the <ls>Gv</ls>, <ls>Bbh</ls>, and <ls>Mv</ls> lists) have been recorded by <ls>Burnouf, Lotus</ls>, 〔558 ff.〕; <ls>Müller, note on Dharmas</ls> 〔83〕 (but note that in a number of cases <ls>Müller</ls> here cites <ls>Dharmas</ls> itself inconsistently with his own text). In <ls>Mvy</ls> and <ls>LVa</ls> (as also in the stray fragmentary lists of <ls>RP</ls>) the order of all other texts is reversed, so as to begin with the head instead of the feet; in citing numbers I have reversed the numbering of these two lists, to facilitate comparison with the other lists; therefore when I cite ‘<ls>Mvy</ls> 〔32〕, <ls>LVa</ls> 〔32〕’, I refer to <ls>Mvy</ls> and <ls>LVa</ls> 〔1〕; ‘<ls>Mvy</ls> 〔31〕, <ls>LVa</ls> 〔31〕’ means <ls>Mvy</ls> 〔2〕, <ls>LVa</ls> 〔2〕, <ab>etc.</ab> I believe the following list is substantially correct and original, <ab>tho</ab> the precise language is not always certain; all important variants are cited. The order of the items in <lang>BHS</lang> varies greatly, no two lists being alike; but the relative order in the <lang>Pali</lang> lists is, I believe, always or nearly always supported by some <lang>BHS</lang> evidence, and I see no serious reason to doubt that it represents the original; it is therefore adopted here. {@1@}. supratiṣṭhitapāda (<lang>Pali</lang> suppatiṭṭhitapāda), <ls>Mvy</ls> 〔3〕; [Page459-a] <ls>LVb</ls>, <ls>Gv</ls>, <ls>Bbh</ls> 〔1〕; <ls>LVa</ls> 〔1〕 inserts sama before pāda; <ls>Mv</ls> <ab>prob.</ab> means this by 1 samā; <ls>Mv</ls> 〔ii.304.14〕 samā … caraṇā supratiṣṭhitā; <ls>Dh.</ls> 〔2〕 -pāṇipādatala(tā) for -pāda. —{@2@}. adhastāt pādatalayoś cakre jāte … (epithets), so <ls>Bbh</ls> 〔2〕, similarly <ls>LVa</ls>, <ls>Gv</ls> 〔2〕; <lang>Pali</lang> heṭṭhāpādatalesu cakkāni jātāni … (epithets); <ls>Mv</ls> 〔2〕 heṣṭā, also heṣṭā … <ls>Mv</ls> 〔ii.304.16〕; <ls>LVb</ls> 〔2〕 compresses the epithets into a long <ab>cpd.</ab> ending cakrāṅkitapādatala; <ls>Mvy</ls> 〔4〕 cakrāṅkita-hasta-pāda, and so <ls>Dh.</ls> 〔1〕 adding -tala and with pāṇi for hasta, which, <ab>tho</ab> supported by <lang>Tib.</lang> <tib>phyag</tib>, is only a false interpretation of adhastāt or semi-<lang>MIndic</lang> heṣṭā. —{@3@}. āyatapādapārṣṇi (<lang>Pali</lang> āyatapaṇhi), so <ls>Mvy</ls> 〔2〕, <ls>Bbh</ls> 〔4〕, <ls>Gv</ls> 〔5〕 (<ls>LVa</ls> 〔6〕 āyatapārṣṇipāda); <ls>Mv</ls> 〔3〕 dīrghā; <ls>Mv</ls> 〔ii.305.1〕. —{@5@}. mṛdutaruṇahastapāda (<lang>Pali</lang> mudutaluṇahatthapāda); <ls>LVa</ls> 〔4〕, <ls>LVb</ls> 〔6〕; <ls>Bbh</ls> 〔5〕 (<ab>mss.</ab> <ab>om.</ab> hasta, <lang>Tib.</lang> <tib>phyag</tib>, for which <ab>ed.</ab> pāṇi); <ls>Dh.</ls> 〔4〕 and <ls>Mvy</ls> 〔7〕 add -tala; <ls>Gv</ls> 〔7〕 mṛdūni … hastapādatalāni; <ls>Mv</ls> 〔11〕 mṛdu; <ab>cf.</ab> <ls>RP</ls> 〔47.10〕. —{@6@}. jāla-(jālāvanaddha-?)hastapāda; <lang>Pali</lang> jālahatthapāda, to which <ls>Bbh</ls> 〔6〕 jālapāṇipāda is closest; <ls>LVa</ls> 〔3〕, <ls>LVb</ls> 〔7〕 jālāṅgulihastapāda; <ls>Mvy</ls> 〔6〕 jālāvanaddha-hastapāda, <ab>cf.</ab> <ls>Mv</ls> 〔ii.304.14〕 (combined with 〔No. 1〕 above) jālāvanaddhā (caraṇā); <ls>Dh.</ls> 〔3〕 corrupt, jālābalabaddhāṅgulipāṇipādatala(tā); <ls>Gv</ls> 〔4〕 hastapādatale jālinī (<ed>2d ed.</ed>); <ls>Mv</ls> 〔12〕 jālā. —{@7@}. ucchaṅkha-(?)pāda (<lang>Pali</lang> ussaṅkha°), so <ls>Gv</ls> 〔3〕, and so read (ucchaṅkha) <ls>Mv</ls> 〔5〕 and <ls>Mv</ls> 〔ii.304.19〕, also with <ls>Mironov</ls> <ls>Mvy</ls> 〔8〕; 52433 old {@lokāntarikā@}¦, <lex>subst.</lex> <lex>f.</lex>, usually <ab>pl.</ab> (= <lang>Pali</lang> lokantarikā, [Page464-b] <lex>subst.</lex>, not <lex>adj.</lex>, ‘<ab>scil.</ab> Niraya’, with <ls>PTSD</ls>), {%interstice(s) between the worlds%}; they are dark, gloomy places, a kind of purgatories: chiefly in a well-known cliché, recorded <ls>SP</ls> 〔163.8〕; <ls>LV</ls> 〔51.10〕; 〔410.13〕 (and the first part, ending andhakārās, as abbreviation, 〔351.22—352.1〕); <ls>Mv</ls> 〔i.41.4〕; 〔229.20〕; 〔240.9〕; 〔ii.162.9〕; 〔iii.334.7〕; 〔341.12〕; <ls>Divy</ls> 〔204.22〕; 〔205.4, 13, 23〕; 〔206.5, 16〕; <ls>Samādh</ls> page 7 line 9; <ls>ŚsP</ls> 〔102.17〕 (abbreviated); and in <lang>Pali</lang>, <ls>DN</ls> 〔ii.12.10〕; <ls>MN</ls> 〔iii.120.9〕; <ls>AN</ls> 〔ii.130.24〕; <ls>SN</ls> 〔v.454.16〕. There are minor variants <acr>thru</acr>out, not all reported here, and in <ls>Mv</ls> the <ab>mss.</ab> are mostly quite corrupt and vary widely; <ls>Senart</ls> <ab>em.</ab> rashly; I shall quote a blended version which seems at least close to a common <ls>Mv</ls> text. For convenience the passage is divided into sections, (a) to (g); <ls>Divy</ls> lacks (b) and (f); <ls>ŚsP</ls> lacks (a) and (g); in <ls>Samādh</ls>, (b) is lacking, (a) and (c) come after (f); in <ls>Mv</ls> (all six passages) and in <ls>ŚsP</ls>, (b) comes after (c): (a) <ab>om.</ab> <ls>ŚsP</ls>; yā (a)pi tā (<ls>Divy</ls> adds lokasya; 〔204.22〕 lacks api tā, and so also <ls>SP</ls>; 3 of 6 <ls>Mv</ls> passages add loke) lokāntarikā (<lang>Pali</lang> lokant°); (b) omitted in <ls>Divy</ls>, <ls>Samādh</ls>, and <ab>prob.</ab> corrupt in all; I believe <ab>orig.</ab> had aghā aghasaṃvṛtā (<lang>Pali</lang> aghā asaṃvutā, for which <ls>Senart</ls>, <ls>Mv</ls> 〔i.406〕, brilliantly conjectured aghā aghasaṃvutā; the <lang>Pali</lang> <ab>comms.</ab> seem to me fatuous, and I cannot feel attracted by <ls>CPD</ls>ʼs interpretation of aghā, see <ab>s.v.</ab> {@agha@}; <ls>Mv</ls> supports <ls>Senart</ls>, and so in a measure do <ls>SP</ls>, <ls>LV</ls> and <ls>ŚsP</ls>); the <ls>Mv</ls> tradition seems to point to aghā aghasaṃbhūtapūrvā, in which with <ls>Senart</ls> I regard saṃbhūta as a corruption for saṃvṛta, or <lang>MIndic</lang> saṃvuta; close in sense, also, is aghā aghasphuṭā ({%full of misery%}), the reading of <ls>LV</ls> and <ls>ŚsP</ls> (in <ls>ŚsP</ls> after c); finally, <ls>SP</ls>, <acr>tho</acr> substituting (tāsu ya) akṣaṇāḥ for the first aghā, and omitting the 2d agha-, actually preserves saṃvṛtā(ḥ), alone among <lang>BHS</lang> texts (note that it has no negative! thus tending to show the corruption of the <lang>Pali</lang>); (c) andhakārā andhakāratamisrā(ḥ) (<lang>Pali</lang> andhakārā andhakāratimisā); so <ls>Samādh</ls>; <ls>SP</ls> <ab>ed.</ab> omits andhakārā (<ab>haplogr.</ab>), but <ab>v.l.</ab> has it; either it or andhakāra- is omitted in <ls>ŚsP</ls> and both <ls>LV</ls> versions (<ab>haplogr.</ab>); <ls>Divy</ls> andhās tamaso 'ndhakāratamisrā; <ls>Mv</ls> (very confused) seems <ab>orig.</ab> to have read, andhakārā andhakārāpitatvā (or °rāyitatvā) tamisrā (or ti°) tamisrāyitatvā (or ti°); (d) yatremāu (yatra ime, <ab>etc.</ab>) candrasūryā(v; or variants) evaṃ maharddhikā(v) (sometimes omitted) evaṃ mahānubhāvā(v); <ls>SP</ls>, <ls>LV</ls>, <ls>ŚsP</ls>, <ls>Samādh</ls> add other adjectives <ab>prec.</ab> by evaṃ; <lang>Pali</lang> yattha p'ime candimasuriyā evaṃ mahiddhikā evaṃ mahānubhāvā; (e) ābhayā (or ābhāya, <ab>etc.</ab>, <ls>Mv</ls>; <lang>Pali</lang> ābhāya) ābhāṃ (or ābhāsaṃ; <ab>om.</ab> <lang>Pali</lang>) nānubhavanti (so <ab>prob.</ab> <ab>orig.</ab>; <ls>LV</ls> <ab>om.</ab> nānu°; <lang>Pali</lang> nānubhonti, but <ls>SP</ls> nānubhavataḥ, <ls>Divy</ls> na pratyanubhavataḥ, <ls>ŚsP</ls> and <ls>Samādh</ls> na bhāsato, omitting ābhayā ābhāṃ before it; <ls>Mv</ls> clearly intends nābhisaṃbhuṇanti, all 6 times; <lang>Pali</lang> <ab>comm.</ab> on <ls>DN</ls>, 〔ii.433.23〕, attano pabhāya na-ppahonti, on which the ‘old ṭīkā’ cited <ls>CPD</ls> glosses … obhāsituṃ an-abhisaṃbhuṇanti, <ab>cf.</ab> <ls>Mv</ls>!); (f) ? not in <lang>Pali</lang> or <ls>Divy</ls>, <ab>perh.</ab> not <ab>orig.</ab>; <ls>SP</ls> varṇenāpi varṇaṃ tejasāpi tejo nānubhavataḥ; <ls>LV</ls> varṇena varṇaṃ tejasā tejo nābhitapato nābhivirocataḥ (best <ab>mss.</ab> nāti° for nābhi° both times); <ls>ŚsP</ls>, <ls>Samādh</ls>, na tapato na virocataḥ; <ls>Mv</ls> ālokena vā ālokaṃ na spharanti; (g) uncertain; not in <ls>ŚsP</ls>; <lang>Pali</lang> tattha pi appamāṇo uḷāro obhāso pātubhavati; <ls>SP</ls>, <ls>LV</ls> (in <ls>LV</ls> after insertion) tatrāpi (<ls>SP</ls> tāsv api) tasmin samaye mahata udārasyāvabhāsasya (<ls>SP</ls> mahato 'vabhāsasya) prādurbhāvo 'bhūt; <ls>Divy</ls> tā api tasmin samaye udāreṇāvabhāsena sphuṭā bhavanti; <ls>Samādh</ls> tā api tasmin samaye tenāvabhāsena sphuṭā abhūvan; <ls>Mv</ls> te (once tā) pi tena obhāsena sphuṭā abhūnsuḥ, with <ab>varr.</ab> The entire cliché means approximately: {%And even those world-interstitial-spaces%}, (which are) {%miseries and covered over with miseries, darknesses, glooms of darkness, —in which the moon and sun here, which possess such great supernatural power and dignity%} (or {%capacity%}), {%are not capable of%} (producing) {%light by%} (their) [Page465-a] {%light, …%} (f varies too much to admit a unified rendering,) {%even in them a great, magnificent radiance appeared (at that time)%}. —Besides this cliché, lokāntarikā occurs in, na ca vedayanti duḥkhaṃ °rikā vipadyamānā (? <ab>em.</ab>) <ls>Mv</ls> 〔ii.34.16〕; alone, <ls>Mvy</ls> 〔3062〕; lokadhātor °rikā duratikramā <ls>Dbh</ls> 〔58.11〕; sarva-°rikāś ca tasmin samaye mahatāvabhāsena sphuṭā abhūvan <ls>LV</ls> 〔86.19〕 (<ab>cf.</ab> the cliché, g); (na ca bhūyo) °rikā … prajñāyante sma <ls>LV</ls> 〔277.9〕.

; <L>14683<pc>517,1<k1>vyAkaroti<k2>vyAkaroti
58903 old {@vyākaroti@}¦ (and other, <lang>MIndic</lang> presents; also {@viyā°@}; in <ab>mg.</ab> 1 not only = <lang>Pali</lang> but also <lang>Skt.</lang>, see <ls>BR</ls> <ab>s.v.</ab> 2, hence only a few <ab>exx.</ab> here; <ab>cf.</ab> {@vyākaraṇa@}), ({@1@}) {%elucidates%}, <ab>esp.</ab> a question: … paripṛccheyaṃ, yathā me bhagavāṃ vyākariṣyati … <ls>Mv</ls> 〔i.57.3〕; 〔274.5〕 (see {@vyākaraṇa@} 1); bhagavān taṃ arthaṃ vyākare 〔ii.93.21〕; vyākuruṣva … kuta eti (<ls>WT</ls> with <ms>Ḱ</ms> enti) ime śūrā <ls>SP</ls> 〔307.1—2〕 (<ab>vs</ab>); asminn arthe vyākriyamāṇe <ls>SP</ls> 〔36.2〕 and 〔37.1〕; ity eṣā pañcamī bhūmī (<ab>mss.</ab> °myāṃ!) vyākṛtā … <ls>Mv</ls> 〔i.120.14〕 (<ab>vs</ab>); nāpi ye dharmāḥ vyākṛtās te avyākṛtā iti deśayāmi <ls>Mv</ls> 〔i.173.10〕; ({@2@}) (= <lang>Pali</lang> <ab>id.</ab>) {%prophesies, predicts%}, in general: (naimittikair vaipañcikaiś ca) vyākṛtam abhūt: maṅgaladvāreṇa kumāro 'bhiniṣkramiṣyatīti <ls>LV</ls> 〔186.16〕; similarly 〔211.3〕; <ls>Mv</ls> 〔i.197.9〕; so (<ab>sc.</ab> naimittikaḥ) 'pi tathaivāmṛtādhigamanam eva vyākṛtavān <ls>LV</ls> 〔268.5〕; (naimittikehi kumāro) vyākṛtaḥ, rājā cakravartī bhaviṣyati <ls>Mv</ls> 〔ii.32.7〕; (naimittikena ca) horapāṭhakena ca vyākṛto, yena kāryeṇa devadatto kumāro abhiniṣkramati, taṃ kāryaṃ na prāpayiṣyati <ls>Mv</ls> 〔iii.178.18〕; Vārāṇasyāṃ naimittikair (<ab>mss.</ab> nimi°) dvādaśavarṣikānāvṛṣṭir vyākṛtā <ls>Divy</ls> 〔131.20〕; rarely, pratyekabodhi is predicted, Vipaśyinā … sa sārthavāhaḥ pratyekabodhau vyākṛtaḥ <ls>Av</ls> 〔i.138.1〕; (sā Bhagavatā) pratyekāyāṃ bodhau vyākṛtā <ls>Divy</ls> 〔70.6〕; much more commonly, in fact constantly in most texts, perfect enlightenment or Buddhahood is predicted, always by an earlier Buddha, who declares that the person mentioned will attain his goal, often in a particular age and world; this constitutes {@vyākaraṇa@} (3), and seems to come to be regarded as a regular, perhaps necessary, preliminary to Buddhahood in Mahāyāna; it always occurs long before the event, under a Buddha of the remote past, <acr>tho</acr> it may be the Buddha immediately preceding the one for whom the prediction is made; sometimes a group prediction is made, all to become Buddhas in turn and each one to predict the next, <ls>SP</ls> 〔209.5〕 (<ab>vs</ab>) paraṃparā eva tathānyam-anyaṃ te vyākariṣyanti …; <ls>SP</ls> 〔27.3〕 (<ab>vs</ab>) anyonya vyākarṣu (°kārṣu? 〔§ 32.74〕) tadāgrabodhaye; see also <ls>SP</ls> 〔269.4〕; the person predicted is always in the <lex>acc.</lex>, or <lex>nom.</lex> in a passive expression; only seeming exceptions are <ls>SP</ls> 〔206.6—7〕 (prose) saced asmākam api bhagavān, yatheme 'nye … vyākṛtā, evam asmākam api tathāgataḥ pṛthak-pṛthag vyākuryāt (in Buddhaʼs reply, line 9, ahaṃ … vaśībhūtaśatāny anantaraṃ vyākaromi), and 〔215.7—8〕 (prose) yad bhagavān asmākaṃ vyākuryād … (asmākam is <lex>acc.</lex>, as clearly elsewhere even in the prose of <ls>SP</ls>, 〔§ 20.48〕); the goal is regularly <lex>loc.</lex>, in prose commonly anuttarāyāṃ samyak-saṃbodhau [Page517-b] (abbreviated an° sam° in my citations); rarely what look like <lex>dat.</lex> forms occur, <ls>SP</ls> 〔27.3〕 (above); 59131 new {@vyūha@}¦, also spelled {@viyūha@} chiefly in <ab>vss</ab>, and <ab>cf.</ab> {@vyūhā@}; <lex>m.</lex>, ({@1@}) (as in <lang>Skt.</lang> and <lang>Pali</lang>, {%mass, heap%}) {%mass, large amount%}: yā kāci rati-viyūhā divyā <ls>LV</ls> 〔36.16〕 (<ab>vs</ab>) = <lang>Tib.</lang> <tib>lha yi dgaḥ ba rnam maṅ ji sñed pa</tib>, {%what large quantities of divine pleasures%}; ({@2@}) in Mahāyāna works (not in <lang>Pali</lang>), {%arrangement%}, but with regular overtones of {%marvelous, supernatural, magical arrangement%}, <ab>esp.</ab> of Buddhafields; <lang>Tib.</lang> <tib>bkod pa</tib>; <ls>Jä.</ls> {%orderly arrangement%}, but it is more than that; the related <tib>ḥgod pa</tib> is also rendered {%decorate, adorn%}, and vyūha implies {%magnificence, splendor%}, as well as supernatural qualities; it seems very close to <lang>Skt.</lang> vibhūti as used <ab>e.g.</ab> in <ls>Bh.G.</ls> <ab>ch.</ab> 10 (see note 3 on <ab>vs</ab> 7 of my <ab>transl.</ab>), and {%supernal manifestation%}, which I chose for vibhūti, would do for <lang>BHS</lang> vyūha; note <ls>LV</ls> 〔317.19〕 (prose) tāṃś ca vyūhān vibhūtiṃ dṛṣṭvā bodhisattvasya, Māraḥ …, {%seeing the <ab n="Bodhisattva">B.</ab>ʼs supernal manifestations and marvelous power (splendor), Māra …%} The word is used in such titles as Sukhāvatī-vyūha, Gaṇḍa-vyūha, with this <ab>mg.</ab>, and is a special favorite in <ls>SP</ls> and <ls>LV</ls>; the translations of <ls>Burnouf</ls>, <ls>Kern</ls>, and <ls>Foucaux</ls> fumble it for the most part; hence the above attempt to make it clear; it seems to me essentially simple, <ab>tho</ab> no one English word is appropriate: (nāsmābhir eṣu … buddha-)kṣetravyūheṣu vā bodhisattvavikrīḍiteṣu vā … SPṛhotpāditā <ls>SP</ls> 〔101.2〕, {%we conceived no desire for … these supernal manifestations%} (or {%arrangements%}) {%of the Buddha-fields …%}; viyūha <ab>n. sg.</ab>, not <lex>loc.</lex> with <ls>Burnouf</ls> and <ls>Kern</ls>); sarveṣa etādṛśakāś ca vyūhā … tatha buddhakṣetraṃ 〔209.1〕 (<ab>vs</ab>), {%all%} (the Buddhas just mentioned) {%shall have just such supernal manifestations, and also (a) Buddha-field(s)%}; 60129 old {@śikṣā@}¦ (see also {@śiṣyā@}), ({@1@}) śi° tisraḥ (or, in <ls>Mvy</ls> 〔929〕, trīṇi śikṣāṇi), {%(the three) instructions%} (<lang>Pali</lang> sikkhā), <ab>viz.</ab> by the Vinaya (-piṭaka) in reference to moral conduct (adhiśīlam), by the Sūtra in reference to thought, intellect (adhicittam), by the Abhidharma in reference to wisdom, insight (adhiprajñam); correspondingly in <lang>Pali</lang>: see <ls>Sūtrāl.</ls> 〔xi.1〕; 〔xx.17〕; <ls>Mvy</ls> 〔929〕; <ls>Dharmas</ls> 〔140〕; śikṣāsu <ls>RP</ls> 〔30.11〕. The words adhiśīlam <ab>etc.</ab> were <ab>orig.</ab> adverbs (adhi governing the second member, {%in a manner referring to …%}) and are still so used, <ab>e.g.</ab> <ls>Bbh</ls> 〔373.20—21〕 adhiśīlaṃ (and adhicittaṃ, adhiprajñaṃ) śikṣā; <lex>loc.</lex> forms are also used in the same way, as adhicitte ca āyogaḥ <ls>Ud</ls> 〔xxxii.27(32)〕 = <lang>Pali</lang> <ls>Dnp.</ls> 〔185〕 (same text). These forms may be turned into adjectives: adhiśīlo vihāro <ls>Bbh</ls> 〔335.1〕; sa vihāraḥ adhicitta ity ucyate <ls>Bbh</ls> 〔338.21〕 (this usage seems not recorded in <lang>Pali</lang>). Often the stems adhiśīla-, adhicitta-, adhiprajña- are used as prior members of <ab>cpds.</ab>, in which case precise analysis becomes difficult; so <ls>Bbh</ls> 〔185.14〕; 〔333.2〕; 〔335.3〕; 〔338.24〕; 〔341.8〕; <ab>etc.</ab> But sometimes adhiprajñā-śikṣā is used as a <ab>cpd.</ab>, <ls>Dharmas</ls> 〔140〕, the prior member being then evidently taken as stem of a noun. As nouns, adhiśīla, adhicitta, and adhiprajñā, like their <lang>Pali</lang> equivalents, are used <ls>Mvy</ls> 〔930—2〕; <ls>Bbh</ls> 〔317.2〕 (parallel with adhimuktiḥ), [Page527-b] being then reinterpreted (with adhi = adhika) as {%superior morality, intellect, wisdom%}, see <ls>CPD</ls> <ab>s.vv.</ab> adhisīla, °citta, °paññā; ({@2@}) like <lang>Pali</lang> sikkhā (<acr>tho</acr> <ls>PTSD</ls> and <ls>Childers</ls> do not clearly recognize the fact), śikṣā also means {%morality%}, perhaps as a reflex of its use in the <ab>cpd.</ab> {@śikṣā@} (<lang>Pali</lang> sikkhā)- {@pada@}, <ab>q.v.</ab>: <ls>Bhīk</ls> 〔10a.1〕, after repetition of the five śikṣāpada the novīce says, teṣām … śikṣāyām anuśikṣe, {%I (will) imitate them%} (see {@anuśikṣati@}) {%in moral conduct%}.
;

; <L>15311<pc>536,2<k1>SreRika<k2>SreRika<h>1
61417 old <hom>1</hom> {@śreṇika@}¦, <lex>adj.</lex> (<ab>cf.</ab> {@a-śreṇika@}), a (relatively) complimentary epithet of a wandering mendicant, always with parivrājakaḥ: <ls>ŚsP</ls> 〔615.12〕; 〔633.13〕; <ls>AsP</ls> 〔8.21〕; 〔9.10〕. But apparently not a Buddhist; his knowledge is ‘limited’, {@prādeśika@}, <ls>ŚsP</ls> 〔615.13〕, <acr>tho</acr> superior to that of the aśreṇika. <ab>Cf.</ab> <ls>Rahder, JAOS</ls> 〔70.126〕. One might guess that śreṇika meant ‘members of a guild or (non-Buddhist) order of monks’; but śreṇi is not a normal expression for a religious order. In <lang>AMg.</lang> seḍhi (= <lang>Skt.</lang> śreṇi) is used of a certain stage of religious advancement among the Jains, and a-seḍhi-gaya (= <lang>Skt.</lang> *a-śreṇi-gata) means one who has not yet attained that stage; see <ls>Ratnach.</ls> <ab>s.vv.</ab> Could aśreṇika equal <lang>AMg.</lang> aseḍhigaya, and śreṇika, its opposite, one who has attained that stage ? Two Jain terms used, and applied to Jain or other heterodox monks? This is only a guess, and <ab>prob.</ab> not likely.
;

62833 old {@satkāya@}¦, <lex>m.</lex> (= <lang>Pali</lang> sakkāya), {%real, existent, body; individuality, personality%}: mā … imaṃ … satkāyaṃ kāyaṃ manyadhvam <ls>AsP</ls> 〔94.12〕, {%donʼt think this existent (physical) body%} (of Tathāgatas) {%is their body%} (but rather regard the {@dharmakāya@} as such); virtually = ātman, once at least in neutral or even favorable sense, prītibhakṣā bhaviṣyāmo satkāyenopaniḥśritāḥ (read °niśritāḥ) <ls>Ud</ls> 〔xxx.50〕, {%we shall feed on joy, relying on our selves%} (alone, not dependent on anything outside); but commonly in unfavorable sense, of the personality to believe in which is a heresy ({@dṛṣṭi@}, see next); satkāyasaṃjñīkṛtaṃ (<ab>sc.</ab> śarīraṃ) <ls>LV</ls> 〔208.13〕 (<ab>vs</ab>), {%formed <acr>thru</acr> the false notion of the personality%}; nārāyaṇabhūtaṃ satkāya-dharma-nistāḍana-tayā <ls>Gv</ls> 〔495.6〕, {%… because it puts down the qualities of the individuality%}. 63169 old {@saṃdhā@}¦ (<ab>cf.</ab> the <lang>Skt.</lang> <ab>mg.</ab> {%<ger>Absicht</ger>%}, <ls>pw</ls> <ab>s.v.</ab> 3, and {@saṃdhāya@}), {%(special, cryptic,) esoteric meaning%}, the ‘real’ meaning of a Buddhist text or doctrine, <ab>opp.</ab> to its prima facie or superficial meaning; <ab>perh.</ab> always in <ab>comp.</ab> with a word for {%speech, words%}, or the like; but see also {@saṃdhi@} (5); see {@ābhiprāyika@}, which <ls>S.K. De, NIA</ls> 〔1.5〕, is right in relating to this; my note in <ls>JAOS</ls> 〔57.185 ff.〕 is <ab>prob.</ab> misleading in regarding {%complete meaning%} as basic; <lang>Tib.</lang> regularly <tib>dgoṅs (te)</tib>, {%meaning, intention%}, often preceded, sometimes replaced, by <tib>ldem po(r)</tib>, {%in a riddlesome way%}; nevertheless the implication of the word is always {%fundamental, ‘real’ meaning%}, as is <ab>esp.</ab> shown by <ls>SP</ls> 〔60.12—13〕 (prose) yat punar bhagavann asmābhir anupasthiteṣu bodhisattveṣu saṃdhābhāṣyaṃ bhagavato 'jānamānais tvaramāṇaiḥ prathamabhāṣitaiva tathāgatasya dharmadeśanā śrutvodgṛhītā, {%but in as much, Lord, as we, not knowing the Lordʼs words as He really intended them%} ({%esoterically, cryptically%}, <lang>Tib.</lang> <tib>ldem por dgoṅs te bśad pa</tib>), {%there being no bodhisattvas on hand, in our haste heard and accepted merely His prima-facie words%}; so, saṃdhā-bhāṣya (<lang>Tib.</lang> usually as above) <ls>SP</ls> 〔29.7〕; 〔34.2, 10〕; 〔39.11〕; 〔70.5〕 (<ab>vs</ab>, <lang>Tib.</lang> <tib>ldem ṅag</tib>, omitting <tib>dgoṅs</tib>) and 8 (<ab>vs</ab>, <lang>Tib.</lang> as in 〔60.12—13〕 but <ab>om.</ab> <tib>ldem por</tib>); 〔273.14〕 and 〔337.2〕 (<ab>vss</ab>); saṃdhā-bhāṣita (<lang>Tib.</lang> generally as in 〔60.12—13〕) 〔125.2, 3〕 (see below; <tib>ldem por</tib> <ab>om.</ab> in 3); 〔199.2〕 (<tib>gsuṅs</tib> for <tib>bśad</tib>); 〔233.11〕 (paramasaṃdhā-bhāṣita-vivaraṇo hy ayaṃ dharmaparyāyas); 〔288.2〕; saṃdhā-vacanehi, °naṃ, <ls>SP</ls> 〔59.4〕 and 5 (here <lang>Tib.</lang> <ab>om.</ab> <tib>dgoṅs</tib>; in 4 <tib>ldem poḥi ṅag</tib> [= <tib>bśad</tib> or <tib>gsuṅs</tib>] <tib>rnams</tib>, {%riddle-words%}; in 5 <tib>ldem po ṅag</tib>); note Buddhaʼs words in [Page557-a] <ls>SP</ls> 〔125.1〕 na sahasaiva sarvajñajñānaṃ saṃprakāśayāmi, {%I do not reveal the Omniscientʼs knowledge all at once%}, given as reason for his hearersʼ failure to understand saṃdhābhāṣitaṃ, since (3) … durvijñeyaṃ … tathāgatānāṃ … saṃdhābhāṣitam. 63169 new {@saṃdhā@}¦ (<ab>cf.</ab> the <lang>Skt.</lang> <ab>mg.</ab> {%<ger>Absicht</ger>%}, <ls>pw</ls> <ab>s.v.</ab> 3, and {@saṃdhāya@}), {%(special, cryptic,) esoteric meaning%}, the ‘real’ meaning of a Buddhist text or doctrine, <ab>opp.</ab> to its prima facie or superficial meaning; <ab>perh.</ab> always in <ab>comp.</ab> with a word for {%speech, words%}, or the like; but see also {@saṃdhi@} (5); see {@ābhiprāyika@}, which <ls>S.K. De, NIA</ls> 〔1.5〕, is right in relating to this; my note in <ls>JAOS</ls> 〔57.185 ff.〕 is <ab>prob.</ab> misleading in regarding {%complete meaning%} as basic; <lang>Tib.</lang> regularly <tib>dgoṅs (te)</tib>, {%meaning, intention%}, often preceded, sometimes replaced, by <tib>ldem po(r)</tib>, {%in a riddlesome way%}; nevertheless the implication of the word is always {%fundamental, ‘real’ meaning%}, as is <ab>esp.</ab> shown by <ls>SP</ls> 〔60.12—13〕 (prose) yat punar bhagavann asmābhir anupasthiteṣu bodhisattveṣu saṃdhābhāṣyaṃ bhagavato 'jānamānais tvaramāṇaiḥ prathamabhāṣitaiva tathāgatasya dharmadeśanā śrutvodgṛhītā, {%but in as much, Lord, as we, not knowing the Lordʼs words as He really intended them%} ({%esoterically, cryptically%}, <lang>Tib.</lang> <tib>ldem por dgoṅs te bśad pa</tib>), {%there being no bodhisattvas on hand, in our haste heard and accepted merely His prima-facie words%}; so, saṃdhā-bhāṣya (<lang>Tib.</lang> usually as above) <ls>SP</ls> 〔29.7〕; 〔34.2, 10〕; 〔39.11〕; 〔70.5〕 (<ab>vs</ab>, <lang>Tib.</lang> <tib>ldem ṅag</tib>, omitting <tib>dgoṅs</tib>) and 8 (<ab>vs</ab>, <lang>Tib.</lang> as in 〔60.12—13〕 but <ab>om.</ab> <tib>ldem por</tib>); 〔273.14〕 and 〔337.2〕 (<ab>vss</ab>); saṃdhā-bhāṣita (<lang>Tib.</lang> generally as in 〔60.12—13〕) 〔125.2, 3〕 (see below; <tib>ldem por</tib> <ab>om.</ab> in 3); 〔199.2〕 (<tib>gsuṅs</tib> for <tib>bśad</tib>); 〔233.11〕 (paramasaṃdhā-bhāṣita-vivaraṇo hy ayaṃ dharmaparyāyas); 〔288.2〕; saṃdhā-vacanehi, °naṃ, <ls>SP</ls> 〔59.4〕 and 5 (here <lang>Tib.</lang> <ab>om.</ab> <tib>dgoṅs</tib>; in 4 <tib>ldem poḥi ṅag</tib> [= <tib>bśad</tib> or <tib>gsuṅs</tib>] <tib>rnams</tib>, {%riddle-words%}; in 5 <tib>ldem po ṅag</tib>); note Buddhaʼs words in [Page557-a] <ls>SP</ls> 〔125.1〕 na sahasaiva sarvajñajñānaṃ saṃprakāśayāmi, {%I do not reveal the Omniscientʼs knowledge all at once%}, given as reason for his hearersʼ failure to understand saṃdhābhāṣitaṃ, since (3) … durvijñeyaṃ … tathāgatānāṃ … saṃdhābhāṣitam. Note that this form seems to occur only in <ls>SP</ls>, while the <lex>ger.</lex> saṃdhāya is more widespread; saṃdhi, however, seems to be used, <ab>tho</ab> rarely, in the same sense, and once in <ls>Laṅk</ls> text has {@saṃdhyā-bhāṣya@}, <ab>q.v.</ab>, clearly in this same <ab>mg.</ab>, and <ab>prob.</ab> error for saṃdhā°.

; <L>17458<pc>612,1<k1>sparSavihAratA<k2>sparSa-vihAra-tA
70045 old {@sparśa-vihāra-tā@}¦ (once by error °vihāri-tā; <ab>etym.</ab>, see below), {%state of comfort, agreeable condition%}: <ls>SP</ls> 〔248.6〕; <ls>Bhīk</ls> 〔26a.3〕; in <ab>comp.</ab> with preceding sukha-, <ls>Kv</ls> 〔18.8〕 (here text erroneously °vihāri-tā); 〔89.13〕; oftener with sukhaṃ as separate and parallel near-synonym, <ls>Mv</ls> 〔i.256.10〕; 〔323.20〕 (here sukha-tā); 〔324.5〕; <ls>Divy</ls> 〔156.14〕; <ls>Av</ls> 〔i.326.1〕; 〔ii.93.16〕. See {@asparśavihāra@}; and {@phāsu, phāsa, (a)phāṣa(ka)@}. The <lang>Pali</lang> equivalent is (a)phāsu(ka), often with vihāra; and <lang>AMg.</lang> has phāsuya (-vihāra). <ls>Pischel</ls> 〔208〕 derives from *sparśuka; <lang>Skt.</lang> sparśavant, <lang>BHS</lang> {@sparśanavant@}, {%pleasant to touch%}, suggest how the development of <ab>mg.</ab> might conceivably have taken place, but <ls>Pischel</ls>ʼs form is unrecorded. In <lang>BHS</lang> sparśa- is the regular form in this <ab>cpd.</ab>, but others occur, see above. It may be only a hyper-<acr>Sktism</acr>. The -u of the stem seems to be universally found in <lang>Pali</lang> and <lang>Pkt.</lang>, and occurs in <lang>BHS</lang>, but never followed by -ka, a fact which is not helpful to <ls>Pischel</ls>ʼs etymology. The Jain <lang>Skt.</lang> form is prāsuka, interpreted as {%free from living creatures%} (pra-asu; of a dwelling, vihāra, suitable for Jain monks); this looks like a fanciful hyper-<acr>Sktism</acr>. Various other etymologies have been suggested, see the <lang>Pali</lang> <ab>Dictt.</ab>; none are convincing. Note the use of phāsuṃ, phāṣaṃ as adverbs with viharati. The forms phāsa, phāṣa are recorded only in <lang>BHS</lang>.
;
70045 new {@sparśa-vihāra-tā@}¦ (once by error °vihāri-tā; <ab>etym.</ab>, see below), {%state of comfort, agreeable condition%}: <ls>SP</ls> 〔248.6〕; <ls>Bhīk</ls> 〔26a.3〕; in <ab>comp.</ab> with preceding sukha-, <ls>Kv</ls> 〔18.8〕 (here text erroneously °vihāri-tā); 〔89.13〕; oftener with sukhaṃ as separate and parallel near-synonym, <ls>Mv</ls> 〔i.256.10〕; 〔323.20〕 (here sukha-tā); 〔324.5〕; <ls>Divy</ls> 〔156.14〕; <ls>Av</ls> 〔i.326.1〕; 〔ii.93.16〕. See {@asparśavihāra@}; and {@phāsu, phāsa, (a)phāṣa(ka)@}. The <lang>Pali</lang> equivalent is (a)phāsu(ka), often with vihāra; and <lang>AMg.</lang> has phāsuya (-vihāra). <ls>Pischel</ls> 〔208〕 derives from *sparśuka; <lang>Skt.</lang> sparśavant, <lang>BHS</lang> {@sparśanavant@}, {%pleasant to touch%}, suggest how the development of <ab>mg.</ab> might conceivably have taken place, but <ls>Pischel</ls>ʼs form is unrecorded. In <lang>BHS</lang> sparśa- is the regular form in this <ab>cpd.</ab>, but others occur, see above. It may be only a hyper-<ab>Sktism</ab>. The -u of the stem seems to be universally found in <lang>Pali</lang> and <lang>Pkt.</lang>, and occurs in <lang>BHS</lang>, but never followed by -ka, a fact which is not helpful to <ls>Pischel</ls>ʼs etymology. The Jain <lang>Skt.</lang> form is prāsuka, interpreted as {%free from living creatures%} (pra-asu; of a dwelling, vihāra, suitable for Jain monks); this looks like a fanciful hyper-<ab>Sktism</ab>. Various other etymologies have been suggested, see the <lang>Pali</lang> <ab>Dictt.</ab>; none are convincing. Note the use of phāsuṃ, phāṣaṃ as adverbs with viharati. The forms phāsa, phāṣa are recorded only in <lang>BHS</lang>.
